DEBATE.TITLE: TEACHERS IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether she has seen reports that President Reagan has authorised covert operations against the Government of Nicaragua. What action has the Australian Government taken to inform the United States of America of Australia's concern about the situation which is developing in Latin America? Will the Government tell the United States firmly that it supports initiatives, such as those offered by the French and Mexican governments, that will lead to a political solution to the problems of this region? Will it further say that those solutions should be based on social and economic reforms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I undertake to refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a response.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, refers to an article which appeared on page one of the Australian of Tuesday, 9 March 1982, concerning the possibility of Mount Newman Mines using steam locomotives to haul its iron ore to Port Hedland. I imagine that the locomotive referred to is the Ace 3000 type being proposed by American coal enterprises. Recognising Australia's vast amount of steaming coal, its relative cheapness and the proposed thermal efficiency of this computer- controlled, automatically-fired type of locomotive, I ask: Can the Minister have the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council look at this project and provide advice not only to Mount Newman Mines but also to the Australian National Railways and the State railways on its ability to provide a viable alternative to the current diesel electric locomotive? Besides the advantages of this type of locomotive, steam buffs would also benefit from the aura and poetry in motion that only a steam reciprocating locomotive can provide , without the backbreak and sweat incurred by the few of us left who might think that we can still fire a steam locomotive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article to which Senator Collard refers. I am interested in it because alternatives to oil are of great importance. Sophisticated developments of the use of coal firing are of great importance indeed. The Government, as an integral part of its national energy policy, is committed to research and development of alternative energy forms. I would be happy to ask the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council , through one of its technical standing committees, to look at the project and to provide the results of its evaluation to Mount Newman Mines. Honourable senators would know that the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council was established in 1978 to provide advice in these regards . Grants totalling some $80.2m, including $19.2m in 1981-82, have been provided to support approved individual projects. The NERDDC is supported by a number of technical standing committees comprising members possessing technical excellence across technological fields. The chairman of the Australian National Railways Commission is a member of the Council's technical committees. I will bring the matter to his attention. If the honourable senator will be good enough to provide me with the details of the Ace 3000 steam locomotive, its particular qualities having escaped me until now, I will ensure that they are passed to the Council. I confirm his enthusiasm and that of many people in the community for the stimulation of steam locomotive propulsion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, who fortuitously happens to be Senator Peter Baume, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, a question about the caves recently found in Tasmania. Is the Minister aware of the very recent reports of discoveries of seven more caves containing ancient Aboriginal artefacts on the Franklin River in Tasmania? Is the Minister aware that these new discoveries provide incredibly valuable sources of back-up information for Fraser Cave, already discovered on the Franklin River? If in the course of his answer the Minister can inform me whether the Fraser Cave was named after Eliza or Malcolm, I will be very grateful. There seems to be an area of doubt about that. I ask whether the Minister can confirm that research work on the Fraser Cave has been described by Professor Mulvaney of the Australian National University in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: With over 25 years field experience in Australia, I cannot envisage a single site excavated with such potential as this isolated place.
Can the Minister confirm that the proposed Gordon below Franklin hydro-electric development will completely desecrate and obliterate Fraser Cave, and also the seven new discoveries, forever?

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am not aware of the existence of seven new caves, I am aware of some of the matters concerning Fraser Cave to which the honourable senator has referred. I am aware of the comments of Professor John Mulvaney who is very active in pre-history matters. I believe that he is a professor of pre- history. From the comments he has made on Fraser Cave, I believe that it provides evidence of the most southerly extension of Aboriginal Australia and some evidence of the existence of Aboriginals in Australia something like 25,000 years ago-a very long time ago. It is my understanding that Fraser Cave will be in jeopardy if the proposals for the dam go ahead, but I have no knowledge about the other seven caves. If there are other matters in Senator Chipp's question I will have them referred to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to see whether a further answer can be obtained.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and it is about the export of arms by the Soviet Union. Is it a fact that the Soviet Union, during the past year, exported to developing countries nearly $6 billion in arms? Is it also a fact that the Soviet Union is supplying replacement arms and ammunition to both Iraq and Iran to enable that tragic conflict to continue? Finally, is there evidence that the Soviet Union is deliberately engaged in destabilising activities in the Persian Gulf region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information on this subject. I may need to seek additional information, but the latest figures that are available for Soviet arms sales to developing countries cover 1980. In that year such sales amounted to a minimum of almost $US5 billion. I say 'a minimum' advisedly because that is the extent of the information we have. Certain amounts of military equipment are provided to socialist countries allied to the Soviet Union, such as Cuba and Vietnam, at nominal or no cost. The figure for 1980 was a record and I have no doubt that the figure for 1981 will represent an increase on that.

ANSWER.PARA: The Foreign Minister also feels that arms sales are the major factor in the Soviet Union's economic relations with developing countries. The Soviet Union has been supplying arms to Iraq in fulfilment of contracts made before the Iran- Iraq war began. Iran has reportedly made purchases of Soviet weapons through eastern European countries. While there is no reason to believe that these sales have been undertaken specifically to prolong the war and weaken both countries, they will no doubt have such an effect. It is regrettable that the Soviet Union has not been able instead to assist Iran and Iraq to resolve their differences peacefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Education aware that the announcement that no fees will be charged for second degrees at institutes of higher education in 1982 was made after the closing date for enrolment in some courses? Was this a deliberate ploy on the part of the Government to discourage those would-be students who did not have ready cash to pay their fees, and consequently to give the wealthy an unfair advantage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the matter raised by Senator Elstob. It would be quite untrue to suggest that there was any attempt to discourage people going into tertiary education. In fact, as honourable senators will know, the document published by Professor Pollard shows that over the past six years there has been an increase in the number of students in tertiary education beyond the normal increase of population. There has been an encouragement into education rather than a discouragement, and that is the Government's policy. I will seek the information as to the first part of the question.

—I refer Senator Sir John Carrick, the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, to recent media reports which suggest that the operations of the Australian Antarctic Base, Casey, are to be curtailed and that staff shortages may force the closure of the base. Australia's participation in Antarctic research and exploration, its claim to part of this vast continent and the need for an Australian presence there in the face of growing interest by many of the major nations of the world are all factors which must be considered if these reports are correct. I ask the Minister to comment on these reports.

—I do not know whether Senator Kilgariff addressed the question specifically to the Leader of the Government, but I represent the Minister for Science and Technology and I think it would be more appropriate for me to provide the answer to him. The Government is not intending to close any of Australia's four Antarctic or sub-Antarctic bases. Antarctica is of strategic and scientific importance to Australia and is, of course, very important as well because of its natural resources. The Government is currently spending $58m rebuilding the bases in the Antarctic over a 10-year period. The rebuilding program is essential to ensure continued safe occupancy of Australian Antarctic territory in support of the science program. Resources will continue to be made available to maintain the Australian presence in Antarctica. As well as these programs, the Government is considering means of replacing the present Antarctic ships which re-supply the bases and which provide a limited marine science capability.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to an answer which he gave in the Senate on 23 February and in which he referred to 'the completely irresponsible prediction of the Premier of New South Wales that interest rates would rise to 18 per cent'. Is it a fact that 180-day treasury notes were sold yesterday at above 18 per cent, an increase of about 1 1/2 per cent since the previous week? Does he regard the comment of the Premier as so irresponsible as he was prepared to describe it on 23 February?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue to regard it as irresponsible. The Premier was obviously not referring to a particularity of a relatively minor factor of interest rates; he was obviously referring to the ordinary borrowing rates of the community. The ordinary borrowing rates of the community, including bonds and the overdraft rates, are in fact nowhere near that at all. I still regard the Premier's statement as irresponsible.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry whether his attention has been drawn to an article in the Cattleman of 17 February 1982 in which it was reported that United States cattlemen want Congress to legislate to require labelling of products using imported meat and for restaurants serving imported red meat to display an appropriate sign. While it is appreciated that the United States industry is divided in its approach to this proposal, has the Government any indication of the views of the United States Congress on the proposition and the effects that it would have, if carried out, on other goods generally traded and between trading nations generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the article in the Cattleman, a publication which I do not normally read during the week but which I sometimes read on a light weekend, and to the move which could be of some significance to the meat industry in Australia. A number of similar proposals-that is, proposals which would have required products containing imported meats to be labelled as such before retailing-have been put before Congress in the past and those proposals have not been successful. Some sections of the United States cattle industry continue to press for similar measures. One of those moves is referred to in the article that Senator Archer has mentioned in his question. It is not possible for me or the Government to predict how the United States Congress will react to any particular piece of legislation that might be put before it if, indeed, another Bill does eventuate, but the consistent practice of the United States authorities has been to oppose any such mandatory labelling. I do not believe we have any reason to think that that would change.

ANSWER.PARA: The Press article reports on one resolution out of a number on various subjects that were put forward at the National Cattlemen's Association meeting in late January. At that meeting the administrator of the food safety and inspection service of the United States Department of Agriculture put forcefully the contrary view and stated that the United States Administration opposed any proposals that would make mandatory any additional labelling for products containing imported meat. The Administration believes that, although American consumers have the right to be informed about the products they buy, they have a right to fair and reasonable prices for the products. Additional labelling for products containing imported meat could result in increased costs to consumers and possible reprisals against United States agricultural exports. The Australian Government, of course, will continue to take an interest in this matter and will resist any proposals of this nature, although, of course, in the ultimate decisions are made by United States authorities. But there appear to be important interests in the United States opposed to the sorts of measures which were discussed at that meeting.

Has the Minister seen an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of today's date in which it is reported that the New South Wales socialist Government's Minister for Health, Mr Brereton, has stated in the New South Wales Parliament that the situation in psychiatric hospitals in Sydney is so serious that the Army might be called in to assist? —My question is directed to Senator Sir John Carrick both as Minister for National Development and Energy and as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to a reply which he gave to a question without notice from Senator Button on 9 March and in which he quoted the Prime Minister as saying that the Government does not know what is going to happen to oil prices. Is it a fact that he visited Saudi Arabia recently and spoke to the Saudi Arabian oil Minister, Sheik Yamani? Is it also a fact that Sheik Yamani advised him that the price of Saudi Arabian light crude oil and, indeed, world oil prices generally would stay depressed for several years? In view of the Prime Minister's statement are we to assume that the Minister did not convey this information on future oil prices to the Prime Minister or is the Prime Minister conveniently pleading ignorance because he is frightened of the potential loss of tax revenue from a fall in petrol prices in Australia? Can the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that Australian petrol prices will fall in accordance with any future falls in the price of Saudi crude oil?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In January I spent six or seven days in Saudi Arabia and some days in Kuwait and Bahrain. In Saudi Arabia I was fortunate to have very detailed discussions with Sheik Yamani and other members of the Saudi Arabian Government. In the course of those discussions we canvassed the whole spectrum of energy problems in both the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and the oil consuming world. Sheik Yamani indicated that he had striven very vigorously to achieve stability in OPEC pricing by managing to bring down other prices to his bench mark and by Saudi Arabia moving to a price of $34 a barrel. He believed that this year if other circumstances were not to emerge there would be no rise in oil prices and that if no other circumstances were to emerge next year there might be a rise but the rise would not be as high as the inflation rate. That would be his goal.

ANSWER.PARA: But he expressed very serious concern that extra oil would be coming into the oil stream, primarily from Iran, which has run out of foreign exchange and must earn money, and also from Iraq. Therefore, oil might come on stream at significantly discounted prices and that might exacerbate the surplus situation and might make it difficult for the arrangement reached by OPEC to be sustained. He indicated that Saudi Arabia would look towards the possibility of reducing the surplus and thought that Saudi Arabia might be able to reduce its output from, say, 8.5 million barrels a day to as low as 6.5 million barrels a day. He canvassed the effects of the destabilisation on individual OPEC countries, such as Indonesia and others that might suffer very serious economic problems should their revenue fall. We discussed at length the desirability of a stable world energy situation. We discussed the fact that the surplus had in fact been brought about by the work of the members of the International Energy Agency, including Australia, by conservation, and, of course, by Saudi having increased its volume of output. That was the background.

When I came home I expressed that in full detail to the Prime Minister by letter and orally; so he has accurate information regarding my discussions. There is no difference between what I was told and what the Prime Minister said. It is true that nobody knows what will happen to oil prices. OPEC meets on 19 March. It will have to make decisions about volume. Saudi Arabia will then have to make decisions about price. Nobody can tell how much oil will be forced on to the market through, say, Iran, Iraq and other countries; therefore, nobody can tell what will happen to the volume and the price of oil. Therefore, in fact what the Prime Minister said is absolutely accurate. I have said repeatedly that we have an import parity pricing device, that we are geared to the benchmark price of Saudi Arabian light market crude and that our practice has been on 1 July and 1 January to look at what has happened to that benchmark and to make adjustments in terms of the price and the exchange rate. That in fact has been the pattern, and we have in the past moved downwards as well as upwards. That remains our policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, concerns the elimination of immunology research within the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the shortages of antivenom supplies for use in various poisoning cases. It is understood that part of the problem has arisen through internal staff disagreements but it appears also that reductions in funding to the Laboratories for the immunology research department has resulted from an attempt to have the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories pay its way as a commercial producer of pharmaceuticals. Can the Minister advise whether this is in fact the situation? Does he agree that specific funding for expanded immunology research should be provided by the Commonwealth Government regardless of the economics of the research costs compared with the revenue from the sale of various antidotes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not correct to say that immunology research at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories has been eliminated. It is not correct to say that there is a shortage of antivenoms produced by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I am grateful to the honourable senator for the question and for the opportunity to make those facts clear. Immunology research occurs in the areas of bacteriology and virology and in the production of antivenoms. The work is generally expanding and appropriate changes are occurring to take into account current advances in science and scientific understanding. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories level of research since 1961, when it became a commission, has grown significantly. So it is not correct for people to say it is being truncated. The current level enables valuable research to be carried out in such areas as immunology and in the application of immunological knowledge. Last year two new vaccines were introduced for two new diseases which had not previously been covered. As well, two new antivenoms for bee venom and funnel web spider venom are now undergoing trial at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

ANSWER.PARA: Each year all research projects are reviewed in the light of the needs of the community and the nation. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories pays for a considerable part of the research undertaken from its own profits together with some injection of Commonwealth funds. I understand that that annual review might involve some change in the research program-some additions and deletions. If the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories were not a commercially viable organisation, that is, a profit-making organisation, of course funds for research and development would be more limited. The Commonwealth Government has, in the past, provided significant funds to the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories for its national interest activities which cover various research and development works. Budgetary limitations, of course, would determine how much would be available from the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware that the latest survey by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research at Melbourne University showed that consumer confidence fell sharply to nearly the lowest level in the last nine years? Is the Minister aware that the Institute gives the following reasons for the fall in consumer confidence: Increasing and new taxes together with the cancellation of promised cuts to income taxes, a quickening of the rate of inflation, record levels of interest rates and a seemingly insoluble high rate of unemployment? What steps does the Government intend to take to bolster consumer confidence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the survey referred to from the Institute but I think it remains only for me to say that the Senate is aware of the Government's present Budget strategy and the financial policies. This strategy is designed to develop consumer confidence and investment confidence. I think if the statistics surrounding our economic achievements are surveyed as a whole, it will be seen that there is considerable confidence in this country. I will have a look at the survey that has been referred to. I will see whether there is any further comment to be made on it.

—Has the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen the emotive photograph and report in this morning's Canberra Times of an American Vietnam veteran who has tied himself to a cross in Lafayette Park near the White House in protest against the lack of treatment for Vietnam veterans being received in the United States? In the event of similar claims for illnesses arising out of service in Vietnam by Australian veterans, what facilities are available within the Minister's Department to ensure that Australian Vietnam veterans will not have to resort to such desperate measures to obtain proper care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the photograph and the story in this morning's Canberra Times. I was somewhat shocked to see that that, in fact, is the degree to which people in the United States still feel they are forced to go, apparently to draw attention to their plight. This Government has approached the problems of Vietnam veterans with a great deal of concern and has in recent times instituted special treatment programs for Vietnam veterans in urgent need. Of course, it is true that of 45,000 veterans who returned from Vietnam, some 7, 000 are currently in receipt of treatment and/or pension benefits from the Department of Veterans' Affairs whether or not those injuries are alleged to be due to herbicide exposure or other matters.

ANSWER.PARA: The facilities within our Department are offered in a variety of ways but chiefly via the new counselling centres which are being established throughout Australia. This is proceeding quickly and there will be one in each capital city by May. These centres are being staffed by expert counsellors in various areas. They will be able to direct people to community facilities if they are not available within the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Of course, they will be able to refer them directly to our normal hospital facilities available at repatriation general hospitals in each State. The repatriation general hospitals in each State have been instructed to look at the problems of Vietnam veterans in this country with a great deal of concern and have accepted cases of urgent need into their ranks where spare capacity has existed within the hospitals. That treatment has been going on for over a year and, of course, has been boosted in recent times by the advent of the counselling centre.

We see the major thrust of our treatment facilities for Vietnam veterans as centering on the counselling centres in each of the States with the object of focusing attention on the problems of Vietnam veterans, and by that means gaining experience and building up expertise in the treatment of Vietnam veterans and in such a way utilising the other facilities available within our Department and the community generally to assist Vietnam veterans in overcoming their problems. In that sense, I believe that Australia is doing a significant amount to help veterans. One cannot speak of what is happening in the United States of America without having a full brief on the matter, but it is clear that the Australian Government is meeting its responsibilities in this regard.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY INTO AUSTRALIA POST

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and follows, but in a different way, the question asked by Senator Bonner earlier today. Is there any truth in recent claims that Aboriginal activists are being trained in terror tactics to disrupt September's Commonwealth Games in Brisbane? Has the Queensland police report making such allegations been received by the Prime Minister and by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs? Is the Minister prepared to name in the Senate the six activists allegedly named in the report as being involved in planning such terrorism or will the Minister take other steps which will allow the Senate and the Australian public to know the basis of these claims so that, if the claims should tragically be true, any such violent plans can be isolated and frustrated from the very beginning? Finally, given the direct opposites in statements about this matter made this week by the Queensland Government on the one hand and by some Aboriginal leaders on the other, can the credibility of one or the other be established so that in any event the dangerous polarisation in Australia that is disastrously emerging over this matter may be prevented?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PETER BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up the last part of Senator Teague's question and say that it will not do anyone in Australia any good if we reach a situation in which there is polarisation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australia. I understand--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Ryan-Tell Bjelke-Petersen to stop promoting such stupid ideas.
Senator Walsh-Stop telling lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chattering from the other side does not help in what is an attempt to give a serious answer. There is no advantage to this country if there is polarisation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australia. To that extent, I think everyone should welcome the suggestion in Senator Teague's question. I have no information at all as to the particular matters which have been raised concerning training in terror tactics, a police report or the names of activists. I know of no activists who are being trained. I have received no report from any government in relation to these matters. I would hope that, if there were any event of this kind and if people were being trained in this way, the appropriate authorities would be giving this the attention that it should receive. The only kind of solution which will satisfy Australians is a solution that will bring Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians closer together. All Australians would like to see the Commonwealth Games proceed as an occasion of amity and friendship between the athletes of 42 countries.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that total moneys available from the Commonwealth to State sources for family support services in Victoria in 1982 amount to $1.4m, a cut in real terms of 9 per cent on 1981 figures? If this is the case, how does the Minister expect that the 'extensions of the Family Support Services Scheme' will take place? I refer to the media release of 19 August by the Minister and a similar undertaking in the Prime Minister's election speech in 1980.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CHANEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Youth Services Scheme, the Family Support Services Scheme was a pilot project undertaken by the Commonwealth and the State governments in concert after, I think, discussions between my predecessor and relevant State Ministers. The original scheme was to be a three-year scheme. It was a pilot scheme. It was an entry by the Commonwealth into an area primarily of State responsibility and general welfare. It was a new initiative for the Commonwealth.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Scheme was entered into by the Commonwealth under its Children's Services Program. The scheme actually commenced on a number of different dates in different States. So whilst there was a three-year pilot scheme, unlike the Youth Services Scheme, it was not neatly contained within a defined three-year period. As a result, the pilot stage of the various schemes concluded at quite different times. For example, Victoria finished its three years a full year ahead of any other State because it was that State Government, I think, which took the initiatives in this area. A decision was taken to fund the Family Support Scheme through to December of last year and that the scheme would then be extended and Commonwealth participation extended beyond the pilot phase for a further three years. In accordance with the election commitment, a further amount of $10m was committed and divided among the States. I do not have the precise figures before me; they may be somewhere in my brief but I would rather seek them and give a supplementary answer to the question at a later stage.

The point in respect of Victoria and, indeed, in respect of any State is that there are, of course, the States' own programs in this area. Essentially, the Commonwealth is involved in a form of supplementary activity. In the case of Victoria, the Victorian State Government announced, I think late last year or early this year, a substantial program of its own in the family support area. I think this was a $3m program. This is an amount considerably in excess of the program we are supporting under the Family Support Services Scheme. Any examination of Commonwealth funding in this area is merely an examination of a contribution towards a much wider system of welfare services.

I think there is a serious question to be addressed over the further three-year period that we have committed ourselves to in this program as to whether it is helpful to programs such as the family support movement that we have two governments involved in this area rather than one. I do not say that to predict a Commonwealth withdrawal from the field but I simply advise the Senate that this is an area in which there will be discussions between the Commonwealth and States because we have some administrative untidiness in having an area basically of State responsibility with the Commonwealth contributing to just a part of the activities. I think that gives rise to some confusion as to where funding responsibilities lie and as to where citizens should address their petitions and complaints when they see inadequacies in this area or want to see services extended.

As far as the actual extension of the scheme is concerned, the scheme certainly has been extended in a very literal sense. The original Commonwealth commitment was to a pilot phase of three years. We funded well beyond that pilot phase and have now committed ourselves to a contribution in this area for a further period of three years, the contribution being the figure mentioned at election time, namely, $10m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Program Guidelines for 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The program guidelines for 1982 for the Commonwealth Schools Commission basically form a document of detail of various programs, such as special education, English as a second language, multicultural education and ethnic schools, which are detailed for the coming year. I address my remarks, however, not to those detailed programs but to some items in the introduction which give a basis upon which the programs are proposed and give some indication of the methods of funding. I draw the Senate's attention to paragraph 1.2 which states:

The Government has decided that, from the beginning of 1982, the current retrospective adjustments for price-level changes will be replaced by a prospective allowance for price movements. In making this change, the previous arrangements for cost adjustment have been converted in their entirety to a prospective basis.

The problem that we have with this concerns the price movements that are currently able to be made. It is not possible, I believe, for State governments or for non-government school authorities to make those types of predictions closely enough so that their budgets, which in some cases, of course, are quite small, will not be thrown out of kilter quite dramatically. I call the Senate's attention to a similar provision which operates in relation to higher education. It was not possible, I believe, at the time when the Government made this decision to abolish the retrospective adjustments to know the outcome of the work value case that was currently taking place in relation to academics. The fact that that work value case was as successful as it was placed tertiary institutions in an extraordinary situation.

The Government, in response to that, was forced to make a retrospective adjustment. Although that retrospective adjustment did not cover all aspects of the costs which would have flowed to tertiary institutions, it covered the vast bulk of them. We believe that the retrospective adjustment is a much fairer and more equitable manner of funding such institutions. Under the current arrangements that are carried out according to section 1.2 of the report-I am thinking particularly of small schools systems-those institutions will be asked to make economic judgments that the Government itself has been unable to make. They will be asked to be accurate in predictions of future price movements that the Government and the Treasury have already admitted publicly they have been unable to make. I believe it is putting an intolerable burden on many of these school systems and independent schools to expect the accountant or, in many cases the principal who does the accounting, to have that level of expertise and capacity to make those types of predictions accurately. It seems to me that it is a retrogressive type of move that the Government has undertaken, obviously as an intended economic measure which will make its predictions of expenditure much better.

Certainly, the Government now will be able to predict quite accurately in relation to schools and tertiary institutions the amounts that they will spend. Unfortunately, it has moved the onus of proof, as it were, the onus of prediction, on to schools and tertiary institutions. I believe that this particular move in relation to schools which I am looking at in this report will eventually have to be abolished and that we will have to return to retrospective adjustments. I believe that we cannot ask school systems to carry that type of burden and to be so finely accurate in their economic predictions and in drawing up their own budgets.

That brings me to the second point that I wish to raise. In paragraph 1.4 of the introduction to the report in which the Government has requested the Commonwealth Schools Commission to look at the accountability of non-government schools it is stated:
The Commission has begun these consultations and will be proposing revised accountability arrangements, subject to Ministerial endorsement, during 1982.

The point I wish to raise-and I hope that the Commission will take note-is that those consultations will be as wide as possible and will be not only with non- government schools but also with government school organisations, particularly the Australian Teachers Federation and the Australian Council of State School Organisations. I believe that consultation in these areas may help us to alleviate somewhat the tension that has grown up between these schooling systems in Australia.

I think it has been one of the most lamentable aspects of recent educational policy that we have again managed to spark off a debate in relation to the level of funding between government and non-government schools. We were, I believe, arriving at a point in Australia of fairly general consensus on the part of all organisations about the relative levels of funding and of the relationship between those two very important systems of schooling in Australia. That has been seriously disrupted. It has been broken in many States to the point where those organisations are no longer in consultation. I believe that that has been one of the worst aspects of educational policy that has been pursued by the Government in recent times.

I hope that the Commission will not add to that serious tension which is already in evidence. I hope it will seek wide consultations, not only with non- government school organisations, but also with government school organisations with a view to arranging an organisation which is acceptable to all those who are engaged in the education of children in schools. I believe to recover that lost ground and to once again have those various organisations co-operating and working together for the benefit of all children in Australia ought to be a prime objective of the Government's intention in relation to schools. The last point I wish to raise relates to non-government schools referred to in paragraph 2.4. I note that there has been a philosophical shift in terms of the way the Government intends, in future, to fund. This has not been made public, to my knowledge, elsewhere. I cannot find any reference to any public statements by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) or to publications in which this item has been explicated in this type of detail. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that it states:

The Commonwealth Government provides general recurrent grants to non-government schools on the basis of two principles: a basic per capita grant to each non- government school and additional per capita grants to schools in need. The basic grant is 20 per cent of the Standard Cost.

I believe that is an important aspect and an important element of the Government 's thinking that really ought to have been highlighted elsewhere than in a document entitled 'Program Guidelines'. I hope that at some stage we may have the opportunity of a more detailed debate on the philosophical basis for the granting of funds to non-government schools. As I say, it is an area in which unfortunately for the whole of the schooling system in Australia there has been a great deal of acrimony and of disagreement in the Australian community. I believe that anybody looking at the Australian schooling system must accept that we will always have an important non-government school area in operation in Australia. We have the largest non-government school sector of any democracy in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The case for prospective supplementation is linked with the case for accountability in tertiary and secondary education institutions. In the distant past when tertiary institutions had incomes, for which they were directly responsible for accumulating, there was a very real accountability in those institutions for the use of funds. In any consideration of wage cases or the effects of inflation on costs in various areas of spending in tertiary and other educational institutions, the responsible executives of that institution would very responsibly and very accountably take account of the disadvantage if those cost increases became excessive. However, as time went by, the taxpayer, through the Commonwealth Government, has become the main provider of finances for education in Australia. Private benefactions and fee income have become almost negligible. In this event there was cost supplementation in the annual grants to educational bodies by the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, what developed in the last 10 or 15 years was that whatever increase in cost arose for those institutions the taxpayer had to pick up the tab. The executive officers of institutions did not have any direct accountability or need to exercise restraint in the determination of those cost increases. With the new way of proceeding by way of prospective supplementation there is no longer a calculation of cost increases after the event so that extra moneys can be made available to make up for that. Rather a prescription is made of expected inflationary factors that there may be in costs and prospective payments are made to account for them. That is done, as Senator Macklin described it, by way of the Commonwealth making an estimate. But once that prospective supplementation has been made institutions receiving those moneys know exactly the amount of money that will be available in the calendar year for the operation of their institutions. Knowing that exactly, they are in a position to be entirely responsible and accountable for the best use of those resources.

If they are able to argue, whether in work value cases before salary tribunals or in other areas of expenditure that have inflationary effects, the priorities as they see them for the spending of money they can influence the cost increases . To the extent that they can do that, there may be an increase in costs that is less than the prospective supplementation that the Commonwealth Government has made available. In the event that estimates lead to increases arising from inflation which are in excess of the prospective supplementation, that can be eased because, as the money is available from the beginning of a year, earnings through short term investment would be available to those institutions which to some extent would advantage them. I believe it is appropriate for the Parliament to expect of the Commonwealth Government that there be this transference to institutions of direct accountability. For that reason, I believe it is the responsibility of the Parliament to see the reasons for prospective supplementation rather than retrospective supplementation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the Commonwealth Schools Commission program guidelines I will also take into account what has been said by those who have spoken previously. It seems to me that the Australian education system suffers from a lack of competition or very unequal competition. It absorbs about 8 per cent of the Federal Budget and about 30 per cent of the State Budgets. During the past decade the education share of gross domestic product has risen from about 4 per cent to about 6 per cent. I think there are very many people who doubt that this greatly increased expenditure has led to any improvement in educational achievement. Those parents who send their children to church or secular private schools pay about twice for their child's education-once through the taxes which they contribute to a school system they do not use and again when they pay school fees. I know that there is a continuing classical argument to the effect that people ought to use the things provided by government and that they have no excuse if they do not. I think we have gone beyond that stage of argument. I think we can safely bury it.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of those people who choose a private education for their children are relatively poor. Many poorer families are locked into a particular government school, irrespective of their perception of its quality, through their inability to pay fees or by the school catchment areas. It seems to me that governments should ensure that every child of compulsory school age has access to an education that meets established standards. However, it is not necessary or desirable that governments should own and run all of the schools. Compulsory free education that does not restrict choice can be achieved either by paying all the institutions-government and private-equal per capita grants for the pupils they attract or by giving parents vouchers for a specified value of education. Children with special disabilities should qualify for a special subsidy in a manner similar to the presently paid isolated children's grant.

Primary and secondary level education is the responsibility of State governments rather than the Commonwealth. The States receive education grants from the Commonwealth under section 96 of the Constitution which enables the Commonwealth to make grants to the States on such terms and conditions as it chooses. The bulk of education funding is derived from State government general revenue. In any rationalisation of Commonwealth-State functions funding of primary and secondary education is likely to become entirely a State responsibility. Any policy changes to make the school system more equitable and more efficient must then be made by State governments. So long as the Commonwealth continues to fund, schooling grants should be made in such a way as to redress the imbalance in the funding of government and non-government school children. In fact, to some extent this is happening already.

I can only guess at the full consequences of removing present discrimination against children educated at non-government schools. Realistically, we could expect that initially taxpayers would be called upon to find additional moneys to pay the full cost of educating the 20 per cent of children not in the government school system. The children will move to those schools which provide better education and this will include some net shift from the public to the private system. He identified 22,360 people as being connected with tax avoidance schemes in 1980-81, involving a loss to revenue of nearly $1,000m. That was an enormous increase of 2,600 per cent in the extent of tax avoidance in Australia. More importantly still, the Government has done little to improve the efficiency of the investigation section of the Australian Taxation Office which, according to the Royal Commissioner's report, is chronically undermanned. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

There is a ridiculously short time available to debate a purchase of this magnitude-$478m, on the Government's own very optimistic estimates and $1,000m plus on our own-but in the 10 minutes available to me I want to try to give 10 reasons why the Invincible is a bad buy. Those reasons fall into three main categories. They are to do with strategic considerations, with the weaknesses in the ship and, thirdly, with the questions of finance and the cost effectiveness of the purchase. What I will be saying will be a prelude to a motion to be moved by my colleague Senator Sibraa in a few minutes time seeking authority from the Senate to refer this matter to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence for further and much closer scrutiny than it has received in the parliamentary process so far.

The first reason the Invincible is a bad buy is that it conflicts with the Department of Defence's own assessment of the nation's strategic priorities as contained in the Defence Force Capability Paper, 1981, which emerged into the public light via the Australian last weekend. That paper makes it plain that there is simply no primary requirement for anti-submarine warfare equipment of this kind. Although that was the main justification advanced by Admiral Synnott and, more particularly, by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) in justifying this purchase, the highest strategic priority for Australia at the moment is, according to the Department's own paper, air defence and the surveillance of our northern approaches.

The situation here is that the anti-submarine requirement has been met to some extent by other means. For example, Orion patrols, submarine patrols and sonar buoys, the upgrading of air and naval bases in the Northern Territory and Western Australia should, if that is our basic strategic priority, have higher priority than this purchase, as should fast corvette-class patrol boats. The carrier simply does not provide a quick reaction to attack situations in the north and north-west, as it could take up to five days to get there if it is not in dock, as it must be every four and a half years.

The second reason is that the carrier is simply not needed to protect our seaborne trade. Only a super-power could effectively cut off our sea trade. No other powers have the number of submarines necessary in that respect. Any power attempting to cut off our trade in that respect would also have to be prepared to commit aggression against ships from many other countries since the overwhelming majority of our trade is carried in foreign bottoms. Again, other faster or, for one reason or another, more flexible equipment, such as submarines, destroyers, helicopters and mine hunting vessels, could, it has been argued in all sorts of sources and places, guard more economically our ports and our stricture points, as it were, for Australian shipping.

The third reason is that, while it is true that the carrier will fit in well enough with a United States naval effort, albeit as a relatively minor contribution, it will tie up a very large proportion of the Navy's vessels in a task force if the carrier is to have any protection or extended capability at all. Indeed, it is evident that, on any view of what the size of such a task force would need to be, between a quarter and a third of our entire Navy would be tied up in one location in this respect. An attack on a number of different parts of Australia simultaneously would make rather good sense to an attacker under these circumstances since it would stretch our naval resources in very obvious ways. The carrier, with its own task force, would become a hindrance to effective reaction in those situations.

Fourthly, even in a task force situation the Invincible is, itself, undoubtedly vulnerable. Senator MacGibbon, among others, has made himself very clear. It has , in his public pronouncement, no close in air defence weapons system. Its area air defence missile system-the Sea Dart-may not be fully interoperable with the Melbourne's old radar systems and may, it seems, have to be replaced. There is the further point in this respect that its radar interrogation equipment and air navigation equipment have a limited range of about, I understand, 100 nautical miles, yet air and sea launched missiles can attack from well beyond that range. The Sea King radars are designed to find submarines and, with a radius of about 40 nautical miles, would not increase the carrier's horizon significantly in that respect. The carrier obviously will have to operate with DDG coverage and extension to give it any kind of extensive horizon.

The fifth point-going further to the question of the carrier's weakness looked at just by itself-is that the range of the carrier is clearly less than what the Navy has said over and over again it wants; namely, something like 10,000 nautical miles. The precise figure as to the range of the carrier is unclear, but the Government has quoted its unimproved range as 7,000 miles while the bible of naval shipping in this respect, Jane's Fighting Ships, and other published sources put it as rather close to 5,000 nautical miles. Whatever the true figure is, it is obviously substantially less than what the Navy has articulated as its own requirement.

Sixthly, the data link developed in the carrier cannot be used with the first three FFGs at least-those that are already commissioned or in the pipeline at the moment-since these vessels had their data link facilities removed, it will be recalled, as a cost cutting measure. For all those reasons there is vulnerability and weakness in the ship looked at itself. The final group of objections involves questions of finance.

The seventh point I make is that the costs associated with this purchase have undoubtedly been significantly underestimated. Just the bare bones have been presented in this ministerial statement. If one leaves aside entirely the cost of the short take-off and vertical landing Harriers-the decision in respect of it then has been postponed, but the Navy is clearly banking on getting them, as retailed at length in this week's Bulletin, and they will add at least another $ 100m to this project-the Navy's political presentation of this matter has made clear that the radar interrogation equipment and the aircraft navigation equipment are to be cannibalised from the Melbourne.

The Sea Dart area air defence missile system may also be removed. These systems , however, will need replacement-the Sea Dart possibly very soon; the radars at least when, if ever, fixed aircraft are provided. There is also the extra costs associated with modifying the ramp in the case of fixed wing aircraft ultimately coming aboard. The Sea King helicopters have a high attrition rate. It seems pretty clear that the eight helicopters that have been estimated by the Minister for Defence are simply not enough to create a workable operational environment. Many other points could be made in this respect. They are the kinds of points which justify our assertions that very much more than this expenditure announced by the Government of $478m is, in fact, involved in this purchase.

The eighth point I make is that, whatever the precise final figures turn out to be, the order of magnitude involved in this purchase represents one which is simply not cost effective to the extent that it is directed to meeting strategic threats, such as major attacks on our sea trade, which have, on the Defence Department's own assessment, a very low probability. Ninthly, the expenditure will unquestionably impose quite extraordinary strains on present defence budgets which are already under very severe strain from the recent pay rises and the cost escalation of a number of present equipment purchases. The Defence Force has already been issued with directives cutting training time and overtime and ordering the payment on various goods that have been delivered to be strung out for as long as possible. There has already been a slippage of up to two years in the purchase of a number of necessary items of equipment, such as 105 mm artillery and mine hunting vessels. It looks as if this is likely to get worse.

Finally, there are very real doubts as to whether this Government, possibly any other government, can meet the targeted overall defence procurement expenditure in the future if this purchase proceeds. It is clear that the Government will not meet its present targeted figure of 3 per cent of gross national product on defence, of which 25 per cent of that, in turn, is to be on capital expenditure. That is clear in the present environment. If one takes into account, in addition , the fact that all the projects presently on board are over budget, adding to that the carrier situation, it will clearly be impossible without a massive strain on Budgets of the future to support a purchase of this magnitude. The obvious need is for more flexible equipment rather than a major one-off big ticket cost number of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has stated at some length on behalf of the Australian Labor Party the many arguments that have been put forward by many areas of the community, including the Australian Democrats, in recent weeks against the purchase of the aircraft carrier. These arguments have been posed, I think, in many ways as questions. The thing that concerns the Australian Democrats more than anything else is that there have not been adequate replies. In other words, in response to detailed questions asking for information, both the Royal Australian Navy and the Government have tended to come back with vague, blurry statements which do not really answer the specific points of criticism. It is not the role of the Senate in our view to set itself up as the decision maker in the purchase of major defence materiel-far from it; let me make that clear. But it is very plain to the Australian Democrats that in this proposed purchase of HMS Invincible there is a major need for further investigation of the whole issue by the appropriate committee. It is clear to us that it is the role of the Senate, if the other place does not do so, to see that that happens with some urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: I briefly mention two points that worry the Australian Democrats about this purchase which we would like to see investigated more fully by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. One is this basic question of the vulnerability of Invincible. What will happen to her in time of war? That seems to us to be the key issue. What would happen to this ship if she were at sea in war time-possibly as a single ship, not heavily escorted at best- and was subjected to a determined missile assault from a large number of missiles either from the sea or from the air? I have asked a number of questions on this matter. I have had no replies to questions such as: Would this not mean that the ship would be sunk? People have talked to us about the Phalanx missile system. Everybody who has studied this knows that the quick-firing Phalanx would stop one or two missiles but would not stop missiles fired in salvos.

In September 1980 I asked the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) and hence, presumably, the whole expertise available to the Department of Defence, if there were any defensive system in the world that could prevent some missiles arriving at their target if they were fired in salvos. As I said, the single word answer to that was no. I think this poses some very interesting implications for Invincible if she goes to sea in time of war. Possibly there are answers. If so, let us have those answers. We have not received them so far. We ought to have them.

The second point I raise concerns the huge cost-well over a billion dollars-of this project. Again we have never had a final costing given to us by the Government of what this would cost Australia once Invincible were armed adequately with aircraft-I stress the word 'adequately'. This huge cost would limit the ability of the nation to buy more modern, effective and cost-effective weapons systems, such as fast, lightly-manned missile attack ships and small, high-speed vessels which are nonetheless excellent missile launching platforms. Of course, they are being used by virtually every navy in the world, including some of our closest neighbours, for that purpose. Why have we given this aircraft carrier project priority? For those reasons, among others, the Democrats will support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some worries about this program. I do not see the issue of buying HMS Invincible in black and white terms. I think one can make cases for its purchase. My worries stem from the inherent risks that come from the very limited operational role of this ship. I have been seeking reassurances on these points as carefully as I can for quite some while. At the outset I make it very clear that I am not against the concept of a full- scale aircraft carrier for the Royal Australian Navy if the case can be made that it can defend itself, as I said in a speech a couple of weeks ago. The power of that type of ship is considerably greater than the type of ship we are talking about in the Invincible. It does have the means through an airborne wing to range out to the launch platforms for missiles which are the major threat to a ship of this nature. I think that until these worries are resolved we are risking the security of the nation in a way that I personally am not prepared to accept.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reassured by the statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made last week that there will not be any short take-off and vertical landing aircraft bought for this ship. Those aircraft, as I pointed out in some detail, are operationally useless. They are not fighters. They have limited strike ability. They do not have reconnaissance capabilities. They have no ASW and AEW capacity. As a consequence of that, if we are not going to have any fixed wing aircraft, then the Navy is morally bound immediately to close down HMAS Nowra and get rid of all the assets it has in fixed wing aircraft-the A4s, the Trackers, the HS748s, the Macchis-all the fixed wing aircraft that it has. There is no longer an operational role for them with the retirement of HMAS Melbourne. That would go some way towards meeting the great costs that are involved in this program.

I am a little concerned with the public dissembling about the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation exercises and the way the ship was appropriate in that role. Goodness me, of course the ship was successful in NATO exercises. That is what it was designed for. It is a purpose-designed ship, built for a specific role. There are all these stories and pictures of Sea Harriers being photographed beside Russian MR aircraft. The aircraft flew over the ship. Even a slow aircraft like a Sea Harrier could formate upon them. That does not prove their operational role at all. I am worried about the way the Navy at its senior officer level-I differentiate between its senior level and the middle range of officers, some of whom are particularly competent-does not appreciate the vulnerability of large capital ships in a missile age. This is the reason the British Navy is selling the Invincible. It knows that it cannot live in big ships on the surface of the water. The British Navy cannot say in public: 'Look, we are going to sell the Invincible because it is too vulnerable'. The British Navy would never get sailors to go to sea in the rest of its ships. It has to be a little quiet about this. There are enormous risks here. These risks, as Senator Mason has said, have not been resolved to the satisfaction of this Parliament. If those risks cannot be coped with, one presumes that if we are involved in a war situation here we will have that war at a much lower technological level. Frankly, as a technologist, I do not believe that.

We have worries about the selection process, the way it was rushed through. We went through a process that lasted 13 years with the new tactical fighter. At every stage the position could be justified by the Government and by the Services. In this case we had a great rush to get things through. Life cycle costs and operational needs were not developed as fully as they should have been . People all over Canberra are talking about the closeness of the Defence Force Development Committee decision and the closeness of the Cabinet decision. Those two points in themselves do not mean necessarily that it was a bad decision but they do mean that there were powerful arguments against the purchase.

We have had reference to the matter of cost. The cost is very worrying because this is an unplanned purchase. We all know the difficulties that the Department of Defence is in at the present time. It means very probably that the Navy will not get the other essential things that it needs. It means that the Army will not get the things that it needs. It means that the Royal Australian Air Force will not get what it needs. I am very worried that we might see as a consequence of this some cut in the number of people in the Services. The Service that is likely to be cut, of course, is the Army. I do not think we can get away with a smaller number of Army personnel than we have at the present time. Of course, this would fit in with Navy philosophy. The Navy always states at public seminars: 'Well, we don't need an Army in Australia because if you need an Army it means that you have been invaded and you have lost the war.' It just so happens that historically in this century we have needed an Army more than any other Service-in World War I, World War II, Vietnam, Korea. It has always been the Army that has been the major Australian component in the Services. So the Navy's argument is nonsense.

The biggest risk of all, I think, relates to the fact that the Invincible is an alien ship and that ship is supplied from Great Britain. When we went to war in Vietnam the British Government cut off military supplies to Australia. I cannot conceive that one can say for 20 years that this ship with its hundreds of thousands of components-short life components that need full scale spares backing-will be guaranteed supply in the future by a British government about whose political nature we simply have no idea. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance
