SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party makes no apologies for again bringing before the Parliament the critical situation in the home building industry as a consequence of the Government's economic policies. We have done this time and time again in recent years only to have the Government defend the indefensible and to have the Government say that there is no problem in the industry and that market forces have to be left to sort out the difficulties facing an ever increasing number of the Australian people. Despite the Government's position, I think it has surely to be accepted that the housing crisis and housing problems become front page news in practically every newspaper in the country in more recent times. The problems of interest rates, the problems of increased rent and the problems facing young people anxious to obtain accommodation are clearly manifesting themselves and need to be accepted and understood by the Australian Parliament. But, of course, the Government still maintains its obstinate and obdurate position that it will not take the necessary steps to ease the crisis that exists in the Australian housing industry. For example, last Wednesday the Treasurer (Mr Howard) sought to play down any talk of a crisis in the housing sector. I will quote what he had to say :

SPEECH.PARA: We don't in my view have a situation which merits the description of crisis. That is a grossly exaggerated way of describing it.

Just two days later Mr Howard followed up that outrageous statement with a suggestion that interest rates were not a problem for home buyers, but that the real trouble was with house prices. That just shows, of course, how out of touch our Treasurer and our Government are. There have appeared recently in a number of newspapers very interesting articles by journalists concerning themselves with the question of housing. I refer to only one of those articles which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald at the end of February. In part, it stated :

The problem of housing finance in Australia is not-as the Fraser Government suggests-to make more money available for housing. It is to make the money that is available sufficient to cover the cost of buying a home, and to make it affordable for most people.

Of course, the Government still pointedly refuses to accept that fact. We do not deny that home prices are a problem, especially for the first home buyer, but we believe that the other problem, interest rates, is the matter with which we should be concerned. The Opposition takes issue with the Treasurer and the anti- social Government headed by Mr Fraser on this matter.

We believe-and I state it firmly on behalf of the Australian Labor Party-that there is a crisis in the provision of housing for the Australian people. We make no bones about it. There is in the housing sector a crisis of the proportions of the crises in unemployment and health care. We can quote so many eminent people in the housing industry. The Housing Industry Association, the Master Builders Association of Australia, and the Australian Council of Social Service have said that, as have the numerous building societies in our country.

We believe that the people of Australia perceive the current situation in housing as a crisis and that the coming elections in Victoria and Lowe will show the contempt they feel for Liberal mismanagement of the housing crisis. I remind the Senate that Mr Kennett, the Victorian Housing Minister, was very vocal about that matter following the last Budget which confirmed a 72 per cent cut in real terms for public housing since 1974-75. Last evening, Mr Thompson, the Premier battling to hold his rein in the State of Victoria, promised to make $60m available for home ownership in that State. If Mr Kennett was correct in his criticism and Mr Thompson was correct in his, why have they not been able to persuade the Australian Government to come to the aid of the States in respect of building houses? The fact is, of course, that at this late hour, as an election gimmick, Mr Thompson is now making promises.

If there is not a crisis, how does the Treasurer explain away figures of the following dimensions? Welfare agencies estimate the number of homeless people in Australia conservatively at 200,000; that is, 200,000 people living out on the streets, sleeping in Brotherhood bins or squatting in unused houses, and many others living in substandard accommodation such as caravan parks and the like. Rental accommodation across Australia is becoming harder and more expensive to get according to the Real Estate Institute of Australia. According to that Institute's figures, there has been a massive tightening in the rental market in every capital city. It is estimated that a vacancy rate of at least 4 per cent is needed to maintain a flow of rental accommodation, yet in Sydney, for example , the current figure is only 1.8 per cent vacant of total rental space.

There is an increasing cost of housing finance and a decreasing amount of money available for mortgage loans from banks, building societies and finance companies. Bank interest rates, for example, were about 5 per cent in 1968. In 1975, they had risen to about 9 per cent, for which the Labor Government was criticised by this Government. They now range from 11.5 per cent to 13.5 per cent and are obviously scheduled to go even higher. Building society rates have seen a similar surge from around 10.5 per cent in 1975 to about 15 per cent in 1981. In the last 12 months alone interest rates on bank and building society loans for housing have risen by some 2 per cent-an increase of about $50 a month on the average home loan repayment. Not only has finance for home purchases become more expensive; it has also become scarcer.

Funds for housing available from traditional sources are drying up, a trend reflected in the decline in new dwellings being built. Figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics recently reflect this trend-that high interest rates combined with low loan approvals force a downturn in the housing construction industry. The number of loan approvals for new dwellings has fallen by over 4,000 in the past year. That is a drop of 17.3 per cent in approvals in just 12 months. Yet the Government says: There is no crisis; there is no problem . Recent reports in the Australian Financial Review suggest that the slump in housing construction for the December quarter was the worst ever recorded by the Cordells survey group. The Government often trumpets the fact that Australia has the highest rate of home ownership in the world, but we all know now that that rate has fallen from something like 74 per cent to 71 per cent.

How can the Treasurer and the Government of which he is a part explain away these stark realities of the housing sector in any other terms than a crisis? Yet he does, and he ignores the high and rising interest rates, blaming everything else but the Government's own lack of economic understanding. The flow of funds away from housing and the dramatic cutbacks in Commonwealth funds for housing are at the crux of the problem with which we are concerned. The Treasurer also ignores the claim of the Real Estate Institute which has in recent days called the situation a crisis in no uncertain terms. We surely have to recognise that the downturn and the stagnation in housing are a direct result of the Government's economic policies. Housing has been deliberately downgraded, and suggested as such by the Department of the Treasury, to make room for private sector investment-often foreign investment and largely resource-based investment. Housing is the victim of the Liberal-National Country Party thesis that the public sector must be cut back to avoid the so-called 'crowding out'-to use their term-of the private sector. This is central to the Fraser Government's economic policy and Australians in need of housing are the victims. The fact that this economic policy is failing, that capital inflow has not occurred at the rate expected and that resource development is not as rapid as anticipated and boasted about has not led the Government to change tack.

The State of the Nation speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) showed that he has not learnt a thing and that he has no real basic concern for this problem. It showed the determination of this Government to press on doggedly, blindly and dogmatically regardless of who is hurt. In the past few weeks as the housing crisis has come to a head and as the elections loom, some State spokesmen and the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr McVeigh, have grasped at straws as they hope that by coming up with some gimmick or ad hoc scheme they will solve the crisis and convert it into solid short term political capital in the meantime. Interest tax deductibility, interest rate subsidies, granny bonds for pensioner investors and the revitalisation of the now-discredited Homes Savings Grants Scheme have been mentioned as palliatives to solve this problem. This sideshow approach, egged on by sensational reporting in some newspapers is, unfortunately, not the way to deal with the problem at all.

There may be some merit in some of these schemes and we do not dismiss them, but they cannot be just tugged out of the hat and put to work with the expectation that they will solve the crisis. It is more fundamental than that. Mr Fraser's departmental advisers have suggested this and yet Mr Fraser refuses to change his approach. He persists with a search for election tricks to save the doomed Thompson Government in Victoria by trying to suggest that this problem is on its agenda. Back in September and October last year Mr Fraser said that the Government would persist with its policies even though it was recognised that there were problems in the housing sector. If gone about in a piecemeal, ad hoc way, some of these proposals may run counter to the development of a suitable and equitable housing plan. The effect of solutions, such as tax deductibility and interest subsidy schemes could, if used indiscriminately, cost the average taxpayer in foregone revenue and effectively benefit only those at the top end of the market. There would be a negative redistribution of resources away from broadly beneficial and productive areas of the economy.

Honourable senators have to accept that the growing importance of the private and public rental market needs to be addressed. The current financial squeeze is having a dramatic effect in this sector of housing. Firstly, interest rate increases are encouraging private landlords to increase rents in order to maintain high returns on their investments. Secondly, as other forms of investment become more attractive, decreased investment in the housing market will result in a further decline in the supply of private rental housing. The growing shortage of rental housing leaves tenants fair game for increasing rents . It is particularly bad in my State of New South Wales. Recent predictions of an expected private rent rise of 20 per cent this year in Melbourne will probably confirm the same sort of trend as is occurring currently in New South Wales. In the public sector already facing strain as a result of the 72 per cent cutback in Commonwealth funds since 1975, rents will be forced up.

We need to look at the regional issue as well. The Prime Minister has sought to palm off responsibility to the States and score cheap political points by claiming that the cost of housing is higher in New South Wales and that this is the fault of the Wran Government. In fact, it is a situation closely linked to a long process of development in New South Wales. This development is continuing as last Thursday's Australian Financial Review pointed out. It stressed the continuing building and property boom in the coal-rich Hunter Valley. The Reverend Mike Nelson, chaplain at the Newcastle Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd steelworks, explained the social effects of this development on the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio in October last year. He said:

. . . the rental situation is out of hand and home building costs in the Valley have gone up 55, 60 per cent in the 12 months and home buying although it appears to have plateaued at the moment, has plateaued at a level where the normal sort of person in the Valley can't get into the market . . . for a three bedroomed house in Maitland, you're looking at between $80,000 and $100,000. Twelve months a go you were looking at perhaps $50,000 or a little less for a weatherboard. Now that's getting pretty close to 100 per cent escalation in many cases. Really we just don't have the economic capacity to cope with that, it's pitched at a particular segment of the population and the rest miss out.

Finally, we need to consider the economic impact of the current squeeze. In an economy where loan approvals for housing are falling, building approvals are falling, and Commonwealth funds are drying up, there can be no growth in employment or wealth. Yet, if funds were directed into the housing sector, working on the Bureau of Industry multipliers, they could be put to use creating jobs and wealth as well as providing socially needed housing. Surely, no one would argue that the housing industry is one that has a multiplier effect. None of the gimmicks and tricks dreamt up by Mr McVeigh or the Prime Minister's statement, vague as they are, confront these problems. Neither does Mr Howard's obsession with de-regulating interest rates which would just let loose chaos into an already weakened market so that people would pay still more and more for housing loans.

The Liberal and National Country parties, of course, have shown in debates in the past, and as debates continue, that they have no worthy solutions. They do not know what to do, so some of them act like Mandrake and try to conjure up new potions and formulas while others completely wash their hands of the whole sticky business leaving the free market forces to have their day. On that basis we know that there will be more casualties among the young people in our country who seek better and adequate accommodation. What is needed is a planned and co- ordinated approach to the general problem of housing that will address the social crisis caused by the current shortage and slot the housing sector into an overall approach to the economy that seeks to stimulate production, consumption and employment.

Such a housing policy would take some time to prepare and carry out. It would not be pulled out of the hat merely at the scent of an election, but would be planned at least along the following lines. Firstly, in the public sector arena of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement there needs to be a real stimulus. The Australian Labor Party pledges support in that area. Secondly, there needs to be a program of genuine assistance to the first home buyer. The Labor Party pledges its support for that concept. It needs to be one that would help the buyer jump the deposit gap between home prices and home finance available. The program needs to direct its funds to the needy, not the well-off home buyer. Thirdly, we need a policy of interest rate controls which ensure that those living in and paying off their home do not face massive repayment problems. Fourthly, we need to ensure an adequate and stable flow of funds at an affordable price in the private housing sector.

Labor is working towards these programs. We will be presenting, at the appropriate time, a revitalised housing policy that will seek to address itself to and redress the problems facing the average citizen in our country who requires accommodation. It will be a policy that will help to house Australians, encourage broad-based growth in the Australian economy, provide stability and employment in the housing industry and begin to meet the social and economic needs of our country. Mr Fraser's policy, the lack of policy, the Minister for Housing and Construction and the Government's lack of policies, all pay no more than lip service to this problem. They do not provide solutions which are fundamental to growth and development of a decent housing sector in our country. This Government stands indicted for its failure to accept its responsibility as a national government, as a government which claims to represent all of the people, and as a government that should accept its responsibilities to provide leadership to the private sector and leadership to the States so that each can play its role in providing decent accommodation at an affordable price to the majority of citizens who still want to become home owners in our country. We make no apologies for again raising this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gietzelt in his first and last words made no apology for bringing this subject before the Senate. Senator Gietzelt in his earlier words made what seemed to me to be some very curious statements. One statement clearly related to his total misunderstanding of the way the Australian free market economy operates. It was not a deliberate dissembling of that information, even if he did properly understand it.

SPEECH.PARA: One can only assume from those opening words that he was just going ahead with the same old politicking that we have heard in this place for some time. All he sought to do was to scare the wits out of people who might be contemplating the purchase of homes, without demonstrating any proper concern and without telling us what those Australian Labor Party policies are which will suddenly solve the problem. TALK.START.PARA: —That's not politicking.

—If Senator Robertson had listened carefully, I am sure that even he would have been able to divine the difference between his policies and some of those which other spokesmen for his party have mentioned over the last few months. SPEECH.PARA: On many occasions he has sought to cover this up with a concern for those who are in rental housing situations. What is Senator Gietzelt's solution? What do we hear? TALK.START.PARA: —Now tell as about interest rates.

—Before discussing interest rates, and just to set Senator Childs' mind at rest perhaps we should discuss some of the real issues behind the housing situation in Australia. SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the number of loans approved for dwellings during last year-I will come back to this later-has increased by 1.5 per cent to 109,917. TALK.START.PARA: —Not for people on the average wage.

—We will come to that in just a moment and perhaps we will be able to set the honourable senator's mind at rest, if he is prepared to listen. With regard to the general growth of the economy, which is the factor underlying all housing policies, there is clear evidence that the growth is continuing in this economy at rates above those of our international competitors. —Two-thirds of the Australian people.

—The proof of this Government's concern-I reiterate it for Senator Gietzelt's interest-has clearly been demonstrated by the commitment to increase the total amount of welfare funds available in the last Budget by some 18.9 per cent. No doubt every honourable senator is concerned in the short run for those people who might find it difficult to meet their repayment from current earnings. Of course, the increased flexibility of banks to look at alternative financing arrangements is fundamental to that point.

Quite apart from the fact that there is a degree of concern in the community and certainly within the Government about these matters, loans approved by trading and savings banks have increased in recent times, particularly in December. Does that not clearly demonstrate the success of this Government's policy in managing the money supply and ensuring a flow of funds into the traditional building finance areas, particularly building societies? These are the areas where money traditionally has been available at rates cheaper than those from other institutions. Clearly the Government's policies are bearing fruit. We can see in the months to come opportunities for increased building society loans which can enhance the opportunities for people to buy their own homes and to take part in the great Australian dream.

I understand that in contrast with this, there are some policies mentioned by some spokesmen of the Opposition. I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lionel Bowen, said on television on Tuesday night that one of the things he would like to do is to subsidise those who are lending money to borrowers for houses. Presumably what he means is that money will be paid by the taxpayer to lenders of money in order for them to reduce the rate of interest charged to borrowers. If anything smacks of political opportunism and a misunderstanding of the way the free market operates, it must be that kind of statement. Clearly, as I have just demonstrated, the sorts of policies relating to interest rates followed by this Government for the last year or two-as shown by figures-have led to increased moneys becoming available to the permanent building societies. More moneys will be flowing into the community in future. These are the ways in which the Government is succeeding in housing. Obviously its policies are working in the right direction.

Senator Gietzelt refused to address himself to one other issue, the significance of which he tended to denigrate totally. This matter concerns the increased cost of housing, particularly in Sydney. He claims that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said that this difficulty in the market is, of course, only a very minor part of the problem and that really the whole problem rests with interest rates. I ask honourable senators to tell people who live out in the western suburbs of Sydney and who pay $25,000 and $30,000 for a block of land whether that is the key issue. Let us hear about the person who has to pay $80,000 for a house in Sydney compared with the person in Adelaide who pays $40,000 or less and see whether that is a relevant issue.

If we look at the factors affecting this situation, it is pretty easy to analyse where Senator Gietzelt's real interests lie. We all know of some of his connections. The fact is that we hear of increases for trade unionists working in the building area which will significantly boost the cost of housing in the next few months. We know of a $29 a week increase for tradesmen which will be followed in July by a further $14. All this is capped off by a reduction in the working week from 40 hours to 38 hours. That clearly demonstrates the increasing cost pressures in this industry. That, coming on top of other matters which obviously will drive the cost of housing higher, means that more and more finance will be required in order to get the average person into a suitable home . Those are key factors.

If we are talking about an increase in the total cost of housing-as demonstrated by these statistics I have just cited-flowing on from wage increases in the future into the building supplies area, this may indicate a rate of inflation which might be in the order of, let us say, 10 per cent or 12 per cent. Now, for the average person trying to buy or build a home in Sydney, a 10 per cent or 12 per cent increase in the cost of a home of $80,000 adds up to a further cost of around $10,000. How does that compare with the very puny amounts of money that might be required to finance or to service each year a loan of say, $30,000 with increased payments of, let us say, 2 per cent arising from interest increases which amount to some $600 a year? We have an increase of $10,000 by way of inflation and an increase of perhaps $600 arising by way of increased interest rates. I ask Senator Gietzelt to tell me the real matters about which the people of this country are concerned.

The point is that we need to control inflation. This Government's policies are designed to that end. It is with success that we can point to the record of the last six years where inflation has been brought down from the Labor Government's high of 1975 to very respectable figures-on international standards-of today. It is those figures which are really showing the success of this Government's policies. This is why there are as many people in private housing today as there have been in the last four years or five years. This number is continuing to grow in absolute terms and that is why this Government's policies are succeeding .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps one of the most perplexing issues when we are talking about housing the Australian population is that this Government really cannot even make up its mind whether there is a crisis in the housing industry. The Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction (Senator Messner) has not helped the predicament one little bit. He has chosen to turn a blind eye to a very real problem in the Australian community. As one of my honourable colleagues said: 'If ignorance is bliss, he must be a very happy man'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few days we have seen a conglomerate of the most extraordinary statements being made by Ministers such as the statement made by the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) who said that he did not think there was a crisis. One would have expected that if any one should know the direct result of this Government's monetarist policies it should have been the Treasurer but he said that he did not think there was a crisis. He was followed fairly promptly by his Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who said that he thought there just might be a crisis. Then, of course, there was a quite categorical statement from the Real Estate Institute of Australia which ulitimately made this Government realise that there was indeed a crisis but, of course, that was tempered on Friday of last week when the Treasurer made the following statement: 'Interest rates are not really the problem for home buyers. The real trouble is with house prices'. I wonder how he applies interest rates to house prices.

The fact remains that this Government just did not know whether there was a crisis. It still does not know whether there is a crisis. I suggest that the people know that there is a crisis. One has only to look at some of the petitions that have been presented in this place by my colleague, Senator Giles, from Western Australia, petitions signed by 42,000 people which is almost a record for petitions presented in this place. Western Australia's Case for a Square Deal for Housing', dated January 1982. Of course, one of the reasons why this booklet was published by the new Premier was that he could not bear the odium of being a Liberal Premier when the Liberal Commonwealth Government was doing such terrible things to the people in this State. The State Government has prepared this booklet to set out the facts in its struggle with the Federal Government over housing policies.

We are concerned to show that home buyers, people seeking low-cost housing and the building industry are all suffering because of the Commonwealth's failure to take action to relieve the present situation.

The State Government knew that there was a crisis. Only the Federal Government did not know that there was a crisis. As I have said, on the one hand we have the Federal Liberal Government stating that it does not think that there is a crisis, or perhaps agreeing that there is a sort of a crisis but that it has nothing to do with housing or with interest rates; it is the cost of houses that are creating the problem. The Western Australian Premier, Mr O'Connor, continues:
The State Government is very concerned about the effect of increasing interest rates on the home purchasing public and the building industry.
It recognises that there is a relationship between high interest rates and house prices but the Federal Government or the Treasurer does not. Mr O'Connor continues:
The rapid escalation in interest rates is hurting home buyers in Western Australia more than in the other States.

Housing is an important industry in any community.

Good housing is a fundamental requirement for a vigorous and stable society. As well as providing the basis for family life, a house still remains one of the best forms of investment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case there is any doubt about it, of course there is a problem in the housing industry. I do not think that any of us would endeavour to indicate that there is not. What is needed, however, is some discussion on the nature and extent of and the responsibility for the problem, if that is going to help. These matters seem to be open for a certain amount of discussion. Before we start discussing the allegation that the Commonwealth is responsible for all the problems in the housing industry it should be remembered that the Commonwealth Government does not provide 95 per cent of housing in Australia, in fact it provides 5 per cent. Therefore the whole context of this debate is out of kilter. The availability, cost and everything to do with housing are matters for all three levels of government. The matter of public importance submitted by Senator Gietzelt states:

SPEECH.PARA: The critical situation in the home building industry as a consequence of the Government's economic policies.
Really, the word 'the' should not appear in that sentence and it should read:
. . . of government economic policies.

Government economic policies at all levels have a very severe influence on housing in general. I will deal with the levels of government one at a time. We will start with local government. Let us look at its performance in this area. How does local government get on in regard to its development and administration of the various regulations and approvals, the servicing, the facilities, the standards, the zonings and those sorts of things for which local government has the sole prerogative? What effect have local government decisions and requirements had on the cost of land and housing? Have local governments made every effort to eliminate the many unreasonable costs that were outlined in the report of the housing costs inquiry of two or three years ago? To the best of my knowledge virtually no action of any sort has been taken even though the report was directed in the many areas in which action could be taken. What about local government approvals? What about local government regulations concerning the standards of building and so on? Nothing has been done about those matters- nothing towards an improvement. Everywhere I go I find that the complaint against local government is that it is taking longer, it is costing more in interest, the standards are higher and the requirements that subdividers and developers are required to meet are higher. Funnily enough, all these things make housing more difficult and more expensive to obtain. I think we can fairly ask: How has local government helped in relation to the housing problem?

I will deal with the States next. In 1978 we produced a new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and, in 1981, further amendments were made to it. Every one of those amendments was designed to assist the States, to see that money went into newer areas, and that the States were given more flexibility and better opportunities to get the best possible value for their money. Have they done so? I do not think they have. How have the States got on with their zoning procedures, which constitute one of the big detriments to housing? Let us take New South Wales. Do honourable senators think that operations have improved in Sydney as a result of the zoning procedures there? I do not think so. Do honourable senators think that the States have a uniform attitude towards home ownership or towards providing relief from some of the costs that go with home ownership for first home buyers? Some do and some do not. Are the States more generously funding the terminating building societies, which are undoubtedly the most efficient users of money in the whole of the housing finance scheme? How much co-operation comes from the States towards the funding of aged persons homes and things of that sort? Have the States gone into competition on the open market for money? We can bet they have. Have they offered high rates, higher than housing interest rates? We can bet they have. In fact, we can ask whether it was housing money that they went out to gather. Of course it was. The States have reaped a lot of the money that would have gone into housing had they not extended their borrowings into these areas.

I shall make one or two brief comments concerning some of the States. Some months ago-in 1980-the Victorian Housing Minister brought down the Green Paper, a volume of some significance, a copy of which I have before me. That document was widely applauded when it was brought down. The fact that now much of what is in the paper has been converted into action is also to be applauded. There have been times when my remarks have perhaps not been quite coincidental with the sorts of remarks that have been passed by the Victorian Minister, but I have now to congratulate him on having provided for so many of these worthwhile proposals in the election Budget. I think it has demonstrated that Victoria, like any other State, can now see its own priorities. This is the best thing about the system that we have set up. The States are getting more and more opportunities to determine their own priorities. I do not blame the States if they do not place housing high on their list. That is up to them. I think that if we give them the money they should be able to waste it on whatever they like. If they want to waste it in other areas and not spend it on housing I do not mind, providing that they do not come back to us and expect us to foot the bill for their shortfalls.

Each State has different requirements. Even in the housing area some see their requirements as being different. At present there is quite a wide variety of conditions existing between various States. For instance, in Victoria the market has started to pick up a little; in Queensland it is going along fairly buoyantly; in Western Australia it is doing quite well; in South Australia it looks as though it has turned the corner; in Tasmania, regrettably, it has not; and in New South Wales it seems to be on a decline. That is the way it is as the moment. In New South Wales the problem is one of land and services. The appalling job done in providing adequate supplies of land for a very buoyant market is the one reason New South Wales prices are way beyond the realm of the average home buyer. The middle income buyer has very little chance in New South Wales through totally inadequate planning. A shortage has been engineered which keeps the price terribly high. Until such time as that is changed there will be no relief for home buyers there.

I give full marks for the availability of land in South Australia and now for allowing the private sector to merchandise it in the manner it does. Housing is getting across to the people at a reasonable price and it looks as though there is an adequate supply for years to come. Western Australia was referred to. I would certainly be the first to concede that that State has done the best job of all the States in the use of housing money in the last few years. The construction sector is going along reasonably well. The waiting lists for government assistance are very low and proportionately are the lowest in Australia, directly as a result of that State's excellent policies. I feel very sorry for Mr O'Connor because the States that have done very little to assist the welfare group have unfortunately weighed against Western Australia. I believe that because Western Australia has done such a good job it should not be penalised, but it has been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I venture to suggest that very few people in Australia, apart perhaps from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and Senator Messner, believe that the home building industry is not in a critical state. The Real Estate Institute of Australia believes it, the Housing Industry Association believes it, and anybody who has taken out a mortgage in the last five years certainly believes it. It would appear that even Senator Archer goes at least half way towards believing it. These people believe it because it is patently apparent, even to the proverbial Blind Freddie, that the situation in the industry is catastrophic both from the point of view of potential home builders, particularly young home builders, and from the point of view of those employed in the industry. Furthermore, it is also apparent that the situation is deteriorating.

SPEECH.PARA: If it were not deteriorating we would not have the plethora of rallies and complaints about rising interest rates, the sorts of stories that appeared in the Age recently about people being forced out of their homes because of rising interest rates, or the amount of correspondence that comes into offices such as mine and to those of my colleagues, although probably not to Senator Lewis since he does not seem to get any correspondence from anybody, if his speech of last week is to be believed. Nevertheless, the situation is becoming worse and it is becoming worse not because of any fault in local government regulations or State government zoning laws, as Senator Archer suggested, but because of what the Federal Government is not doing.

As an ex-mathematician I am quite prepared to admit that the selective use of statistics can come up with just about any answer one wants, but it will not stop me from using some statistics of my own if only to combat the extreme selectivity of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in his speech earlier this afternoon. I put it to the Senate that if Australia is to continue to be a country where a high percentage of home ownership is a reality and not just a dream, industry figures maintain that a commencement rate of between 155,000 and 160,000 homes is required annually. In fact, according to the figures available, in the vicinity of 130,000 to 135,000 homes are being commenced. That, I would suggest to the Minister, has nothing to do with increasing land prices or home prices; it has simply to do with the fact that people cannot afford to borrow money to build homes in the first place because they know that, within a period of three months, they will be forced into higher interest repayments than they anticipated originally. They cannot afford to borrow the money because they know that they will not be able to afford to pay it back.

In the decade between 1972 and 1982, the majority of which had a Liberal Party government, housing commencement rates fell by 42 per cent in Victoria and 48 per cent in South Australia. This occurred in the period when the results of the post-war baby boom were allegedly marrying and settling down, presumably settling down in a home of their own; yet that boom did not produce a commensurate boom in house building. One of the side effects at the moment, of the crash-I think we are faced with a crash-in the housing industry is the increased demand for rental accommodation, a factor, which pushes up rental as a logical consequence of increased demand. This, in turn, puts added pressure on the public housing sector. It is no wonder that Senator Gietzelt turned his attention to that matter. In South Australia alone, for instance, the waiting list for a housing trust home was in the vicinity of 21,400 as of December last year. South Australia is not an extremely large State and to have a waiting list for public housing of 21,400 is something of an indictment of Federal Government policies. This represents an increase in the figure of 19,700 for December 1980, so the position is getting more parlous. This brings about yet another question; that is, what is happening to employment in the housing industry? If homes are not being built for people to live in, clearly fewer people will be involved in employment in the industry.

In the first half of this financial year, housing commencements were running at a level of 138,000 but they dropped considerably-by 20 per cent-in the first two months of 1982. The effect of this on employment in the industry is fairly easily demonstrated. In this financial year, on a national basis, the shortfall of 20,000 homes meant an additional 40,000 people unemployed in the building industry. In addition of course, there is the unused manufacturing capacity for building material, which alone is worth approximately $40m. I recall speaking to the Senate late last year on the annual report for 1980-81 of the Department of Housing and Construction. I quoted a section from it. I will quote again the passage, which appeared on page 13 of that document. It states:

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics the construction industry directly employs about half a million people, some 8 per cent of the total employment in Australia. It is estimated that the jobs of a further 8 to 10 per cent are indirectly dependent upon the industry, being engaged in producing materials, parts, business, professional and transport services and so on. Altogether, more than one million workers (almost one in every six of those in employment) are dependent on the industry.
The report continued:
There is a higher component of self-employment in the industry
That is, in the housing industry-
than in many others. This reflects the prevalence of small sub-contracting firms in the industry, particularly among special trades in the housing sector.

Clearly, we can expect massive increases in unemployment figures for this industry alone in a period of limited home building. For the benefit of the Minister, let us take another look at the reasons for the downturn in building activity. Despite his inability to see what is happening in front of his face, they are not really difficult to find and have little to do with rising house or land prices. The simple fact of the matter is that people buying a home are caught in an ever tightening interest rate squeeze. Interest rates have risen four times between April 1980 and June 1981. I remind the Minister, if he needs reminding, that those were not the days of the dreaded Labor Government. In April 1980 building society loan interest was 12 1/4 per cent. It is now 15 per cent. Bank interest rates have risen in similar proportions. Every one per cent increase has added $238m to the home interest bill Australians are faced with. New home buyers are simply unable to accept the staggering burden.

It might be fine and dandy for the Minister to point out that building societies have record amounts of money to lend, but if the people they want to lend it to cannot afford to borrow there is not much point in them having the money. In 1970, taking out a 25-year loan of $30,000 committed the borrower to a total repayment of $63,000. That total repayment would now be $115,000 because of increased interest rates. There is no guarantee that rates will not rise further. That, if nothing else, puts home ownership beyond the scope of an increasing number of people in Australia. In addition, as I mentioned earlier, it puts increased pressure on welfare housing. I have mentioned the figure for South Australia. In Victoria in the vicinity of 60,000 families are eligible and waiting for public housing with little prospect of getting it. On a national basis the shortfall in that category, according to figures of the Housing Industry Association, is 280,000 dwellings. Again, I would suggest that if the Minister is implying that comments that I might make about people being out on the streets, or comments that Senator Gietzelt or anybody else might make about people being unable to maintain their mortgage repayments or being unable to find cheap rental accommodation are excessive, he needs only to look at articles which appear periodically in the Age and in other newspapers in this country.

Faced with this situation, the Government has taken no positive action to assist people. The action it has taken has only served to make the position worse. Partial deregulation of interest rates, the reduction of housing grants to the State in the past year's Budget by over $24m and the attempt to introduce a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on home building materials do nothing to assist an industry which is gradually going gurgling down the drain. Every Australian, except perhaps the most one-eyed if not actually blind Liberal voter, must be astounded at the fact that the present Government is apparently unable to come to terms with the problems that exist in the housing industry and with the problems facing those who would like to own a home. Neither the Australian Labor Party nor the Australian Democrats are at all backward in coming forward in suggesting ways and means around this. We are always prepared to offer advice. In fact, we are frequently prepared to go beyond that, coming up with resolutions and legislation to assist.

I was interested to hear Senator Gietzelt putting forward the policy of the Australian Labor Party. I suggest to the Minister that the policy put forward by the Australian Labor Party, which follows very closely that put forward by the Democrats last August, is not democratic socialism or any sort of left wing attitude to the economy but simple, plain common sense. Free market forces have done nothing to help the average Australian in the last six years of Liberal Government. Perhaps, just perhaps, it is time that this Government stopped trying to blame the Labor Government that was in power something like a decade ago, and an American Government which, I admit, is not doing great things for the American public but which can hardly be blamed for the Australian domestic problems and even the victims which is something to which the Liberals tend to stoop when they run out of anybody else to blame, and looked instead at its own actions. Control of interest rates and other positive measures to assist home buyers are not, as I believe has been described by Government members, voodoo economics. They are simply economic measures designed to help the majority of Australians. This country needs a bit of magic-voodoo or otherwise-if it is to have any hope of recovering from the mess the free market economy beliefs of this Government have already got it into.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time we got away from some of the cant and hypocrisy that has been talked about interest rates and got down to some serious thoughts about the problem. It is a problem particularly for home buyers with large mortgages and a small equity. I will return to this problem in a moment although it is worth pointing out right away that not everyone loses from high interest rates-lenders gain from high interest rates and a reduction in interest rates would result in a drop in the value of the insurance, superannuation and savings of many small people.

SPEECH.PARA: Two things must be said again and again about interest rates. Firstly, interest rates are the price of money. Short term interest rates are governed by the ordinary laws of supply and demand-the commodity in this case being the available supply of money. Secondly, interest rates cannot be separated from other parts of the economy. Interest rates are inextricably related to, for example, money supply, the rate of inflation and government Budget policy. Why are interest rates so high? Can government policy bring them down? If they cannot be bought down generally, can and should they be brought down selectively , for instance, in the housing area, the subject that we are discussing? Let us look at each of these in turn. Why are interest rates so high? In many ways our economic situation is the envy of most other countries. Real economic growth last year was 3 per cent; it is expected to be higher this year at a time when most countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development are expecting no growth or negative growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name one country that envies Australia.

—The United Kingdom and the United States of America are two such countries. Of course, out of growth comes more to share. The only way this Government or any government can achieve desirable social objectives is through sustained economic growth. This being achieved by this Government; it would be destroyed by the Australian Labor Party. Interest rates are closely related also to the inflation rate. The Americans have convincing statistics to show that interest rates are almost exactly 5 per cent higher than the inflation rate. If we want to get interest rates down we must lower the inflation rate. That is the key to lower interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has firmly faced this problem and used the budgetary weapons at its disposal to cope with it. The key weapon in controlling inflation is limiting the growth in the money supply. Of course, the Labor Party would let the money supply blow out as it did in the Whitlam years when it hit 27 per cent . This sort of thing might bring about a temporary dip in interest rates but, of course, before long inflation would soar and interest rates would follow. We hear over and over in this place proposals from the Labor party for more expenditure here, more expenditure there-more expenditure all the time. Of course, simultaneously the Labor party encourages grossly inflationary wage demands. We, I am glad to say, are more responsible. To head off the dangers of increased inflation and a wage explosion, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is aiming this year for an increase in the money supply of not more than 10 per cent or 11 per cent. So much for the supply side of the supply-demand balance which determines short term interest rates.

What about demand? The Government has taken two very significant steps to limit the demand for money. The Budget strategy was designed to dampen down just a little the so-called resource boom atmosphere in favour of more controlled, steady growth. This will, of course, ease the pressure on the money supply and, therefore, on interest rates. Even more importantly, we are moving to reduce government demands for money market funds which come through deficits. These demands, of course, include State and local government requirements as well as ours. In fact, last year their share of the public sector borrowing requirement was almost twice as large as ours. The Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, by preventing the collection of $500m in sales tax, will increase the public sector borrowing requirement and, therefore, increase interest rates. The crocodile tears that they are shedding about interest rates are the purest hypocrisy. I suggest that it would be irresponsible and probably impossible to do more than the Government is doing.

The British tried to put a strait-jacket on interest rates by saying that they must not exceed a certain level which, of course, was below the market rate. Of course, the obvious thing happened; various substitutes for money arose outside the market and other liquid assets took the place of money. The British did not, in fact, succeed in reducing the effective interest rates for those who were most in need. They had to use other sources of borrowing and finished up paying much higher interest rates than they would have if the Government had not interfered in the first place. Everyone must grasp the simple fact that a government cannot control both money supply and interest rates. It can control one or the other but not both. We are committed to controlling the money supply as a vital weapon in the battle against inflation. We therefore cannot control interest rates generally although we can help to reduce them by lowering the Government's demands on the money markets-and that we are doing. I repeat: Governments cannot control both money supply and interest rates. Governments try to only at their peril and to the great economic loss of the community.

If governments cannot control interest rates generally, what about doing it selectively? Can it be done? The answer is yes, but probably at great cost to everyone else and quite possibly to the harm of the people intended to be helped . The trouble is that if one holds down interest rates artificially people put their money somewhere else. If banks and building societies cannot get the money in they will not be able to lend. Would-be borrowers will have to go somewhere else for their money and probably pay exorbitant rates for it. This problem was clearly recognised by the New South Wales Minister for Housing, Mr Sheahan, when approving an interest rate rise for New South Wales permanent building society home loans. Mr Sheahan quite rightly said that building society interest rates on housing loans had to go up because unless those savings institutions were competitive and able to attract their share of investments home loan funds for housing would dry up. I do not want to minimise the burden of extra costs that high interest rates can impose on home buyers. I think we all deeply regret the fact that these rises are unavoidable. However, we should not completely lose perspective about the impact of these costs. A person on average weekly earnings who took out a mortgage loan of $30,000 three years ago at a rate of interest of 10 per cent would have seen his mortgage repayments rise by about $54 a month over the three-year period. However, his after-tax income would have risen over the same period by $226 a month.

What about direct assistance to increase the rate of house construction? Senator Haines was arguing that the rate of house construction was too low. The housing industry is currently building about 140,000 houses a year. Approvals in the last three years were steadily rising-118,000, 137,000 and 147,500 houses were built in successive years. This year it looks like between 135,000 and 140, 000 houses will be built. This is not a catastrophic drop. It is in certain localities, but not generally across the nation. The level is certainly below the capacity of the housing industry, but it is far less clear that it is really less than the community needs.

In home ownership we have a remarkable record. At the moment 38 per cent of Australians own their own homes outright-no question of loans involved. This figure by the way, has risen in the last six years from 28 per cent-the figure in the last year of the Whitlam Government-to 38 per cent. Nationally we have a home ownership rate of 72 per cent. This might be compared with other countries: In the United States the figure is 65 per cent, in Canada 62 per cent, in Britain 50 per cent, in France 47 per cent and in West Germany 33 per cent. We have 72 per cent of people in their own homes. Incidentally, Victoria has the highest figure in the nation-75 per cent. As Senator Archer pointed out, the figure for New South Wales because of its extraordinarily inept housing development policies is much lower-71 per cent.

Undoubtedly there are groups who are facing difficulties with housing at the moment. The three main groups, I would suggest, are, firstly, people who have borrowed in the last couple of years, particularly those who have since become one-income families; secondly, would-be first home buyers who are finding it hard to bridge the deposit gap; and, thirdly, some families renting in the private market. Dealing with these particular problems is a matter of co- operation between the Federal and State governments. The Federal Government has taken action in the past on the problem of bridging the deposit gap. I hope we will see the scheme changed to make it more immediately available at the time of commitment to the purchase, but the State governments-or the best of them-are taking action in other areas.

My own State of Victoria has many schemes to help these groups who have problems. For instance, in co-operation with the building societies, it has an interest subsidy scheme for low-income earners buying houses whereby they get an interest rate advantage of up to 5 per cent. There is a home renovation scheme at concessional interest rates for low income earners for repairs and renovations to their homes. There is a second mortgage scheme under which the maximum loan has now been raised to $20,000. There is an emergency housing interest relief scheme for people who are in crisis meeting their rising interest payments. They may have an interest subsidy for up to 12 months, although there are, of course, as there should be, stringent limitations on eligibility. The original loan must not be more than $35,000 and it must be shown that the new rate of repayment, after the interest rate rise, on the first mortgage is a greater percentage of income than it was at the time the mortgage was originally entered into.

Last night the Victorian Premier announced two new schemes which will go into operation this year. One is a scheme whereby the Government is selling land to developers under an agreement that developers will construct houses on the land for low income earners. The other is an interest subsidy scheme to assist families with incomes below about $20,500 a year on mortgages for houses up to $ 30,000. This will give these relatively low income earners-although the figure, by the way, is 130 per cent of average weekly earnings-an interest subsidy of 3 per cent in the first year, 2 per cent in the second year and one per cent in the third year. This applies to families who have bought their first home in the past three years and to those who will be buying housing in the next three years .

This is a business for the States, because there are different problems in each State. New South Wales has extraordinary problems, as I have said, because of the cost of housing there caused by the absurd policies of the State Government in the housing area. Different States have different problems. Victoria has targeted in on the particular problems of housing affecting the Victorian community, and the measures taken by the Victorian Government are a very sensible and effective means of helping home owners and would-be home owners in this very critical area of owning their own homes. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
