DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982CANNED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 March on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating these Bills cognately. They are concerned with rural exports and the quality controls which the government believes are necessary to maintain our markets for these goods. However, I wish to speak about another kind of export which does not need Government-sponsored quality control. I refer to the products of the much maligned mining industry. I wish to quote from a short article by Mr Jim Cameron , a New South Wales parliamentarian, which appeared in the Australian on Monday 10 February this year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Economically, mining has been carrying us on its back since the sheep jibbed at continuing to do so in the 1960s.
The mineral industry's readiness then to fill the breach created by the slide in our rural sector was fortuitous, to put it mildly.
It involved more than a step into the breach-it came close to a straight gallop to the succor of our reeling economy.

I think some of the other things that Mr Cameron said are of enough interest for me to seek leave of the Senate at this stage to incorporate the article in Hansard. I apologise to the Opposition for not placing this article into its hands beforehand. Perhaps the honourable senator in charge of the Opposition business could have a look at this article and at another one which I want incorporated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have a look at it too?
—I have no objections at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Gratitude to the mining industry for all it has done for us sticks in our craws like a sick boy's thanks for castor oil.
No winter wind that ever blew was half so unkind as our indifference here.
The mineral winners enjoy little relief from attacks which landslide on to them . How many of us can point to a single activity on which we depend as much yet are so sluggish to defend?
Like a trio of tunnels converging on a pit-head, there are three main directions of attack.

Firstly, there is the continuing saga of Greenies v Grubbers-the latter being one of many unflattering terms used to describe miners such as ''moles'', '' scratchers'' and ''fossickers''. The conservationists, or Greenies, are hostile to Grubbers for environmental reasons.
Secondly there are the Aboriginal lobbyists who are said to be concerned not for economic reasons but because of sacred sites.
And thirdly there are the most rapacious stake-grabbers of all-governments of all tiers and colors. Their reasons are economic to the core and scarcely disguised.
Easy pickings on a grand scale-this comes close to summing up their basic drive .

As far as it can be, of course, this is legitimised by fine words about protecting the public interest and shoring up the revenues. What a welcome treat many would find if these attacks were to meet one fate: unceremonious dumping in the mullock. If there is ever to be anything that could be called a fair divvying up of the lode, this really ought to happen. Mining, after all, if it can be called a lobby at all, is so unfashionable it has never known what it is to enjoy a soft ride.

In recent times, the competing fashionable lobbies have rarely known any other kind. They have usually managed to get their own way. The mineral industry's defensive public relations stance is overdue for discard. A real attempt is at last being made to change the static and adverse perception the public has of mining, but much more needs to be done.
In the understated words of a dragline operator deep in the continent's interior: ''Money in the till, that's what mining is all about.
''It represents more for the whole of Aussie.
''There's also a quid or two for me, the missus and the kids.''
Because he is honest, the scale of his understatement brings a wry grin to his face.
Philosophically, he adds: ''But, like in the bloody dictionary, the Greenies think beauty's always got to come before booty.''
The case put by the Greenies seems often to come down to this: a panorama without scars is better than one with them.
So put, this argument virtually carries itself.
But is the environment without either scars or local jobs as good as one with a few scars plus jobs and a high living standard?
Greater environmental sensitivity by the miners has also caved in part of the Greenies' case.
First-class revegetation work on dunes by the sand-mining companies is but one example.
Long on emotion, short on realism-this seems to epitomise the verbal, and sometimes more than verbal, assaults made by Greenies on Grubbers.

Concerning the sacred sites on which the Aboriginals rely, the gently pungent comment of Sir James Foots, an elder statesman of mining, was: ''We need these to be identified now-not after a mine has been discovered''.
But governments remain the heaviest inert mass of overburden.
Thank goodness the mineral industry has a sense of humour to season its responses to the outpourings of the leading politicians about it.
Otherwise the unconscious humour buried in them might never be unearthed.
Bill Hayden's recent commitment on behalf of the ALP to introduce a resource rental levy to tax excessive profits in the mining industry is a case in point.
Economically, mining has been carrying us on its back since the sheep jibbed at continuing to do so in the 1960s.
The mineral industry's readiness then to fill the breach created by the slide in our rural sector was fortuitous, to put it mildly.
It involved more than a step into the breach-it came closer to a straight gallop to the succour of our reeling economy.
Like a surprised pit-pony asked to bring off unaided one of the US cavalry's last-reel film rescues, the industry responded.
It has been a sure-footed prop sustaining our living standards ever since.
No Lone Ranger could have asked for a more faithful Silver.
Its reward has been to be taxed and imposted more and more by every tier of government.
Now the talk is of a resource rental tax. It takes a real sense of humour to hear that, and just neigh derisively-and carry on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think everyone accepts the truth that the mining industry rescued us at a critical time. I am concerned to see that the Government helps the industry lift us to another plateau of export which will again lift Australia's living standards. This will not cost the taxpayer a cent. Firstly, governments have to recognise a basic problem which is that Australian coal and iron ore ports are incapable of handling really large and profitable quantities of iron ore from Western Australia and coal from Queensland. The iron ore situation is perhaps more longer term than is the coal situation at the moment even though coal exporters worry about the world oil price drop. Sir Russel Madigan, Deputy Chairman of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, a man deeply experienced in mineral exports, is quoted in the West Australian of 6 March 1982 . The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's iron ore trade with Europe is in jeopardy, one of its founders warned yesterday.

In an apparent reference to Brazilian miners, Sir Russel said Australia's iron ore producers could not compete now in the European market with competitors who were closer and whose governments helped them get bigger ships and deeper ports.
Having circulated that article I seek leave of the Senate to have it incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the honourable senator might explain why he wants newspaper articles incorporated when they are readily available to anyone who is interested in them.
—Is that a straight no or am I able to explain?
—It is a conditional no, but you may explain why you want it incorporated.

—The reason I would like to incorporate these articles is that I do not believe that honourable senators necessarily read every single item in the news. They have many interests. In this case I would like these articles incorporated because I believe that most honourable senators read Hansard and then they will be sure of reading the articles.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-

The Hitachi Venture, launched in January, is the sort of ship causing concern to Sir Russel. At 272,000 dead-weight tonnes it is beyond the operating limit of the Pilbara ports, where the record shipment was a 264,591 dead-weight tonnes loaded out of Lauderdale for Cape Lambert. The Hitachi Venture, the world's biggest ore carrier, will be put into service after delivery on the Brazilian run.
Australia's iron ore trade with Europe is in jeopardy, one of its founders warned yesterday.

CRA Ltd's deputy chairman, Sir Russel Madigan, told a seminar on relations between Australia and West Germany in Canberra: ''Australian iron-ore producers do not make any money selling iron ore to Europe, including Germany. I don't know how long this trade can survive.'' He said the trade had developed on very favourable freight rates offered by shippers, who were then eager to get scarce backloads in the Australia-Europe trade. Somewhat ruefully, Sir Russel added: '' We were too successful,'' explaining that on a tonnage basis, cargoes to Europe soon began to exceed those consigned from Europe to Australia.

In an apparent reference to Brazilian miners Sir Russel said Australia's iron ore producers could not compete now in the European market with competitors who were closer and whose governments helped them get bigger ships and deeper ports. Speaking of trade between Australia and West Germany in general, Sir Russel said : ''Perhaps it is just as well we are having a symposium to faster economic co- operation between Australia and Germany at this time. He said that West Germany' s share of Australia's total export market had fallen from 7.5 per cent in 1978- 79 to 5.7 per cent in 1980-81. Australia's imports from West Germany had fallen from 3.1 per cent in 1978-79 to 2.5 per cent in 1980-81.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The article which has been incorporated includes a photograph of the Hitachi Venture which is a very large bulk carrier. As leave has been granted to incorporate the article I will not spend time reading the full caption. The important point is that it shows a photograph of a 270,000 tonne deadweight vessel which is well beyond the capacity of any of the ports in the Pilbara in Western Australia or in Queensland to handle. Concern about our lack of really efficient ports to handle big, profitably operating vessels I think is known to the people in the mining industry. I want the concern that I and others have made known to as many people in the Senate and anywhere else that I can make it known. This concern also has been expressed by Mr Lang Hancock who may not agree with everybody in this place about every subject, but he is vastly experienced in the iron ore trade. In the Weekend Australian of 27-28 February-I will not seek leave to incorporate that article, I might be in trouble if I do, but I think the article is worth reading to the Senate-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The answer . . . is to widen the market to encompass the world, instead of being tied almost exclusively to Japan.

This can only be done by the establishment of privately financed, owned and operated modern infrastructure to service jumbo ships which will enable freights to be reduced to enable our iron ore and coal to be delivered in worldwide markets at competitive prices.

That is the comment of one who is vastly experienced. His reference to the Japanese market intrigued me. I have the greatest respect for our best customer, but the Japanese are very hard, very shrewd and long-sighted negotiators. Iron ore development in Western Australia has been largely a response to Japanese demand on Japanese terms and conditions, one of which was that the shipping of the iron ore should be conducted in Japanese vessels of a tonnage most suited to the Australia-Japan run. These ships are comparatively small by today's standards and at present the Western Australian iron ore ports can take nothing bigger than these comparatively small ships. I also understand that it is really impossible economically to deepen or widen these ports and channels.

Australia is virtually excluded from the European and other markets for iron ore simply because we cannot ship economic quantities to those places. Naturally enough, this suits the Japanese better than it suits us. We certainly have to increase our selling options. We must have a new iron ore port on the Western Australian coast proximate to the iron ore fields. Hopefully, it will be done with willing private enterprise in much the same way as the proposed deep water port to be built at Port Clinton in Queensland, which I noted is the subject of an article appearing in a newspaper called the Morning Bulletin. I am not sure where that newspaper circulates, but it looks as though it is a Queensland paper . I ask honourable senators from Queensland to pardon my ignorance, but it is a newspaper I have not seen before. I found it to be an interesting article. It stated:
'The Government is seeking a location that could be developed into a port capable of handling ships of 250,000 tonnes', Mr Bjelke-Petersen said.
'We must be capable of handling the new generation of coal carriers if future exports to the European market are to be viable'.
The Premier said the Commonwealth would not allow the State to undertake studies of Port Clinton but preliminary hydrographic and seismic surveys had been done in the area to be inspected today.

We have to have something like this project. The article was headed 'Port Clinton looks a goer'. Indeed, I suppose that in Queensland it would have some suitable defence aspects as well. Coal exports from Queensland are absolutely vital to the Australian economy at the moment. The top foreign exchange earner for the last two consecutive years has been the coal industry. It certainly has revitalised our domestic economy. Making comparisons between the coal and wool industries, we find that in 1979-80 the coal industry was worth $1,677m and that in the current year it is worth $1,973m. Comparing those figures with those of the wool industry, which everybody formerly believed was what this country's prosperity depended on, we find that in 1979-80 the wool industry was worth $1, 595m and that in 1980-81 it was worth $1,749m. The coal industry, of course, has met the industrial needs of many countries and is an industry with virtually unlimited expansion potential, as our coal deposits are known to be immense, with no presently defined upper limit to the reserves.

We have consistently let down our trading partners with interruptions to contracted supplies. There was the 10-week housing tax strike, which caused some bother in this place. Then, with port and railroad bottle-necks in New South Wales, our major customer for coal, Japan, has been actively moving over the past few years to broaden its supply base to ensure that it becomes largely independent of reliance on Australia within a few years. The New South Wales coal ports, by any standards, are industrial nightmares. Concentrated into small areas, easily controlled by militant unions and owned by one State monopoly, they do not cater for the cost-effective, largest bulk carriers which are needed to trade competitively across the world.

As was noted earlier, Japan, in order to protect its own interests, is currently encouraging, by contract, and investing in coal export facilities in Siberia, China, the United States of America and Canada. South Africa and Colombia, which are also on the oceanic rim with ready access to Japan, are rapidly developing their vast coal export potential. I think it is vital that we have at least one deep water port capable of handling ships of at least 250,000 deadweight tonnes on either side of Australia-one for Western Australia's iron ore and one for Queensland's coal. The ports should be developed not by government but by private enterprise. I was very gratified to see a report detailing words of Sir Charles Court, former Premier of Western Australia, who was visiting New South Wales during the weekend. He was quite specific in his remarks that governments just cannot do this sort of thing and should not even try to.

It seems to me that if we intend, which we must, to develop our iron ore exports beyond the Japanese market, where we are a captive, it is absolutely essential for us to have a new and large deep water port on the Western Australian coast. If we are to hold our share of the coal market-Japan again is our largest customer-on this side of the Australian coast we need a large deep water port in Queensland. The best proposition at the moment appears to be Port Clinton. I will leave my remarks at that. It seemed to me that the necessity for these ports was an important enough reason for me to take part in the first reading debate on these Bills. We must make sure that the prospects for the future-while we look after the present rural exports-regarding essential minerals are taken care of. They can be profitably taken care of only by having bigger and more efficiently operated vessels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take advantage of this first reading debate on a money Bill to expose what might be called the Grace Bros rip-off. I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter of blatant exploitation of the consumer. Whilst there is little that can be done about this case at this stage, my mentioning it here may alert otherwise unsuspecting consumers, particularly migrants. The case involves Grace Bros as international removalists , although it concerns a local job that company was doing in Hobart. The matter arose a few weeks ago when an English migrant came in to my office angry and concerned about being locked into a very costly situation for him and one over which he had no control. His furniture and personal effects were at the time en route from the United Kingdom by sea. He had come ahead of those goods.

SPEECH.PARA: After his arrival in Hobart he received a letter from Grace Bros in Hobart saying that he would have to pay $755 to have his goods moved from the Hobart wharf to the company's bonded warehouse only a few kilometres away and then to his new home in a Hobart suburb only a further few kilometres away from the warehouse. This charge of $755 amounts to more than 25 per cent extra compared to the total cost of bringing the furniture and household goods the 20,000 kilometres or so from England, that charge being #1,448 sterling. That charge was for bringing the goods from his home in England to the Hobart wharf. The goods involved amounted to something in the order of 15 cubic metres of furniture and household goods in 62 packages. If honourable senators want to visualise the amount involved, on my assessment that is about the equivalent of a bathroom crammed full of goods.

I appreciate that packing costs are similar in each of the two operations, regardless of distance, but the comparison is still ridiculous. My constituent was shocked at the quotation and so was I. It did not seem a very warm welcome for Australia to give him to his new home. He and my staff went about obtaining three other quotes for the same job. While there was some difference in these quotes, none came within cooee of the Grace Bros' quote. The three quotes obtained for the same work were $235, $140 and $200. I understand that other migrants in this position, who get locked into having Grace Bros do the job, whether they like it or not, have made complaints on several occasions to the Customs Bureau in Hobart. Like me, the Customs officers are helpless in this regard.

It was suggested to my constituent that he obtain the bill of lading from Grace Bros and arrange for his own removalist to do the job. As I understand it, Grace Bros were appointed to do the job by a firm of international shipping agents in the United Kingdom without the knowledge, again as I understand it, of the client involved. However, Grace Bros would not give him the bill of lading because, he was told, his goods were in a container shared by two other people. The firm also would not tell him the names of the other people so he therefore could not contact them for some joint action to obtain a lower price. Grace Bros did tell him he could arrange to have the goods removed from Grace Bros' bonded warehouse after they had been moved there by Grace Bros. He was told he would be charged only $340 to take his goods from the container on the Hobart wharf the few kilometres to the warehouse.

A member of my staff spoke to the manager of Grace Bros in Hobart who detailed the supposed costs involved. He gave a long and complicated list of costs involved including the need to write, telex and telegram the United Kingdom about the safe arrival of the goods and a charge to have the Customs and quarantine officers inspect the goods at the bonded warehouse. I will list the items supposed to make up the total cost. These were: Acknowledgement of the bill of lading to the shippers in England, shipping agency fees-remembering that , of course, these are goods that have already landed in Hobart-and a $125 fee to receive the shipment into the terminal. There is other correspondence between the shipping agents, et cetera, a container lift fee on the wharf, cartage to the bond store, another cartage lift fee, unstowing the container, acknowledgement of the safe arrival of the goods to the United Kingdom shippers, de-hire of the container, storage until Customs officers clear the goods and then, before the goods are removed, a checking of each package. There was also another receipt to the UK and return of documents to the UK, Customs and quarantine inspections which include the transportation of these officers and providing an attendant to go through the goods at request. The quote for that was $85. There was to be an additional fee if quarantine officers decided to fumigate the goods. That cost would be only about $18 extra for the amount of goods involved. A fee of $300 was therefore charged to deliver the goods from Grace Bros store to the suburban home.

The manager said that there were no unreasonable charges. When the amounts of the other quotes were mentioned to him, he said those quotes would have been given because the competitors knew that Grace Bros were involved. In fact, that was not the case. The quotes were sought without any mention of the name of Grace Bros to any of the companies spoken to. When my constituent tried to engage another firm to move the goods from Grace Bros warehouse to his home none of them was happy about doing it when Grace Bros involvement was discovered. My constituent had to pay the full $755. The letter sent by Grace Bros to him in which it was stated that the quote was $755 also stated that that charge covered Customs and quarantine clearance, port landing, depot handling and delivery, et cetera. A new arrival could be forgiven for believing that the Customs and quarantine clearances referred to are fees imposed by the Commonwealth. In fact, there are no such charges in this regard. As I said, the only charge would be the cost of fumigating the goods, if indeed that were necessary. That would have cost only about $18 for the size of the consignment involved. My constituent was trapped and had to go along with Grace Bros. To add insult to injury, the day his possessions were actually dispatched from the warehouse, the removalist would not take them into his house until he had been paid the full $755.

It strikes me that this is a clear case of exploitation and greed. Obviously, Grace Bros charge excessively. Some of us have always thought that. In any case, that company's quoted rates are hardly competitive. What is worse is that because of the container system where several clients share a container, that firm is able to tie people up and prevent them from obtaining more competitive prices in the market-place. To me it seems that effectively this is a restrictive trade practice that should be investigated. I hope the public has been warned by this. Unfortunately my warning will have little effect on potential migrants still in the United Kingdom or elsewhere who may never have heard of Grace Bros until they get a letter demanding what appears to be an enormous amount of money for a simple transportation job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of this debate at the first reading stage of the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill 1982 and the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982 to bring to the attention of the Senate and perhaps the people of Australia, through the media, a matter that is very near and dear to my heart. It has been said in this chamber by a former Minister that on the matter of Aboriginal affairs I tend to become rather emotional. For that I make no apology. So as not to disappoint our former colleague, Jim Cavanagh, I will continue my emotional stance. To set the scene for what I have to say, I will read from a verse written by a famed and wonderful person by the name of Nan Ingleton. She titled the poem 'A Curlew Cries' and in brackets under the title is the notation 'For Senator Neville Bonner'. The poem reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Our decades drift, as dust, across the void
On alien gusts, the Dreamtime tatters fly;
While dying campfires hold the dark at bay,
Through halls of power . . . one haunting spirit-cry:
''I am your ghost, Australia, mourning, still,
The trespassed shore, the broken tribes . . . I stand,
Translating tears, for men unversed, in grief,
That mine may summon justice . . . in my land!''

That poem is by a very fine and wonderful person who has written many poems. I think that perhaps sets the scene for what I am endeavouring to do here today. The matter that I want to raise is not unknown to those who sit in this chamber. It is not unknown to many people throughout Australia. It is the matter of the reserve lands of the Aboriginal people in my State of Queensland. This matter has been going on ever since a statement was made by the Premier of Queensland some 12 months ago. He stated that the Queensland Government intended to abolish the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in Queensland and that the Government intended to have a second look at the reserve lands. He said that the Government would be looking at perhaps giving the Aboriginal people living on those reserve lands tenure of 50 years, in other words, a 50-year lease. He said also: 'We will have to keep very tight control of these areas. We will not allow them to become black enclaves' and all those kinds of statements that he has made on a number of occasions when Aboriginal people have started talking about land rights in the State of Queensland.

I do not think we are talking about land rights in the sense in which that matter has been spoken about on so many occasions. What we are talking about is the return of the reserve lands in Queensland that have been set aside by governments, as I have said here before, for over 100 years. These reserve lands were set aside because it was felt that they were not good for agriculture and for all those other purposes for which non-Aboriginal people want land. They were set aside for Aboriginal people as an administrative convenience to keep the Aboriginals all grouped together so that the Government would know where they were. In this way it would protect the graziers, the waterholes, the sheep and the cattle and would keep all the aboriginals segregated and perhaps away from the prying eyes of the world at large.
A further statement was made by the Premier of Queensland in a media release on 1 March 1982 in the following terms:
. . . title to Aboriginal and Islander reserve lands would be vested in the elected councils through Deeds of Grants in Trust under existing provisions of the Land Act.

When I read that first part of the statement, I thought: 'Jolly good'. The Premier also said that there would be a type of limited freehold in the sense that the lands could never again be sold, disposed of or alienated from the Aboriginal people. That is exactly what I would like to see. I would like to see those lands handed back to the Aboriginal people through their elected councils but in such a way that they could never again be capable of being alienated from the Aboriginal people.

I was elated when I started to read that statement. But a little further in the statement we find that the deeds of grant are to be held by the Government, in one of its offices in Brisbane, and that Aboriginal councils would be able to lease the land to individual Aborigines or groups of Aborigines. The councils would not have the power to do that themselves. They would then have to go cap in hand to the Minister for Lands and Forestry who would have to give his approval. If we are talking about giving people something with security of tenure, something with which Aboriginal people can work and with which to progress themselves and their own people, I do not believe that the proposition that has been put forward is giving any sense of security or is any way different from what the Aboriginal people in Queensland already have.

I am not alone in what I am saying. Perhaps at this juncture I should make it quite clear that whatever I say here today and the propositions and arguments that I put forward are in no way to be taken as a criticism of my colleague, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, with whom I have worked ever since he came into this place. I have worked with him on a number of committees and he has shown great understanding of and empathy for the Aboriginal people. I do not want my remarks to be taken in any way as criticism of his efforts and those of his Department on this very issue over the last 12 months-they have worked consistently behind the scenes trying to bring about a better deal for Aboriginal people in Queensland-nor should it be taken as a criticism of my Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser as, in my opinion, he has done more for Aboriginal affairs than any other Prime Minister. I wish to get that clear at the outset.
I said a moment ago that I was not alone in what I was saying. I do not think that I am alone. A letter which I have before me states:
Dear Sir,

We, the Anglican and Roman Catholic Bishops of Queensland, met in annual conference last Friday. Among other matters we discussed the announcement concerning the transfer of title of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Reserve lands to the respective Community Councils.
Like many in the community, we are asking what security is offered to the Councils and residents of those reserves.
Our hope is that the security offered will be guaranteed by an Act of Parliament.
I will elaborate on that part of the letter later in the debate. The letter continues:
The proposed use of 'Deeds of Grant in Trust under existing provisions of the Land Act' would not seem to be sufficient to provide adequate security of title.
I make these points very strongly. The letter continues:

If Deeds of Grant in Trust are appropriate legal devices for the transfer of title (and that is for others, expert in the law, to determine), they should surely be created so that they might never be varied or terminated except by Act of Parliament.
This does not appear to be the case when we read the statement from the Premier of Queensland. The letter continues:
Otherwise would not the tenure for those living on the reserves remain as at present, that is, subject simply to the Queensland Government's discretion?
We note in the Press Release the Government's assurance that consultation has taken place.
I will talk about that a little later on. The letter continues:

We should like to renew the appeal made by the Moderator of the Uniting Church and our two Archbishops in July last year that such consultation should be ' widespread, lengthy, and in conformity with the particular character of the Aboriginal people'.

We hope that the tenure bestowed will give the State's Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders all the security and powers they need to choose between life on their lands of historical significance and life in the cities and towns.
The same tenure needs to be assured to thousands of other Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders living on Country Reserves. This emphasises the need for the widest possible consultation.

It is our hope, therefore, that the Queensland Government will legislate in Parliament for security of tenure after due consultation with the people on the reserves and their elected representatives, and after concerned community groups have had an opportunity to scrutinise the proposed laws.

That letter was signed by John Grindrod, Brisbane, John Lewis, North Queensland, Hamish Jamieson, Carpentaria, George Hearn, Rockhampton, Ralph Wicks, Assistant Bishop, Brisbane, Francis Rush, Brisbane, Leonard Faulkner, Townsville, John Torpie, Cairns, Edward Kelly, Toowoomba, Bernard Wallace, Rockhampton and John Gerry, Brisbane. Are we now going to start saying what has been said about me and a number of other outspoken Aboriginals? Are these people activists? Are these men who signed the letter-all bishops and archbishops-now to be branded as activists or radicals as I have been branded by the Premier of Queensland because I speak out on Aboriginal affairs? Will they be branded in the same way? I certainly pray that they will not.
Another area of support comes from the Courier-Mail in its editorial way back on 4 November 1981. It stated:
It is time the Federal and Queensland Governments stopped their huffing and puffing over Aboriginal land rights.

The Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, is not helping matters with his belligerent attitude. Too often it seems he is more interested in the wealth that comes out of the land than the people who live on it.
That is only part of the editorial from the Courier-Mail. I have before me an editorial from the Queensland Times dated 2 March 1982 and headed: 'Land rights offer still too limited'. It reads:
The Queensland Government's decision to grant Aborigines limited freehold tenure of existing reserves will not satisfy Aboriginal demands for land rights.
The offer from the Government continues to place a number of restrictions on Aborigines, the most vexatious of which is a denial of mineral rights.

Are the editor of the Courier-Mail and the editor of the Queensland Times now to join the ranks of the radicals and the activists to which I, Charlie Perkins, Steve Mann and a few others belong? Are they now to be put into the same category as we are? The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs issued a Press release some time ago on the Commonwealth Government's four point plan for the reserve lands in Queensland. The Press release stated:
In relation to the current events in Queensland, Senator Baume said that the Government has already said that it would wish to see the following four principles satisfied:
The integrity of the present reserve boundaries be maintained.
Secure tenure for occupants and preservation of their rights to use the land.
Local communities to play a significant role in the management of reserves.
Full consultation with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders before any decision is made.

In my humble opinion none of those criteria have been filled under the present proposal. I am told at this stage that it is only a proposal to be put into the form of a Bill. As yet no one has seen the Bill. I do not think anyone will see the Bill because the constant practice in the Queensland Parliament is to bring in a Bill at about midnight, as was the case with the Aurukun and Mornington Island Bill. Not even any of the Liberal-National Country Party backbenchers had seen that Bill previously. It was introduced at about midnight and rushed through the Parliament with almost no debate whatsoever. That is what will happen if this Bill comes in. There will be no debate in the Queensland Parliament because the Bill will be rushed through in the early hours of the morning. I think one should call the Queensland Premier Mr Daylight because he seems to like to do things in the early hours of the morning. Let us look at these deeds of grant in trust. Some of the incidences of and restrictions on such title would be:
The deeds of grant in trust may be granted-
I note the words 'may be granted'-
by a Governor-in-Council for any public purpose. A public purpose covers all manner of things from aerodromes to cemetries and-
coincidentally-
includes Aboriginal reserves.
These provisions can be looked up in the Queensland Land Act. I continue:
The trustees (in this case, the Councils) are liable to pay any survey fees. The Governor-in-Council (effectively Cabinet) may cancel or vary the deed of grant at any time.

I am sure that my colleague on the Opposition benches, Senator Jones, would have some understanding of the kinds of things that happen in the Queensland Parliament. There would be no debate. The current Governor-in-Council-the Cabinet-can do any of the number of things about which I am about to speak. Another provision is:
The Governor-in-Council may declare the land to revert to the Crown for any reason that it appears desirable to do so.
We are talking about land that is supposed to be handed back to the Aboriginal people. this is what can happen which Aboriginal land comes under the Queensland Land Act. I repeat:
The Governor-in-Council may declare the land to revert to the Crown for any reason that it appears desirable to do so.
That covers a whole range of things. A further provision is:
The Governor-in-Council (Cabinet) may remove any trustee
In this case the Aboriginal elected councillors-
from office if it is of the opinion that it is 'in the public interests' and in its absolute discretion may appoint new trustees (Councillors).
Despite the fact that these councillors are duly elected, the Government would have the power to remove them and replace them without going through another election. The next provision is:
The trustees' (Councils) books of account must be open and available at all times to the Minister for Lands.

Why must their books be open to the Minister for Lands? Why should they not be open to an auditor? But no, the books have to be open at all times to the Honourable Russ Hinze-'honourable' in inverted commas. He can go and inspect the books at any time he wants. I understand that he will be in his present position for a considerable time. Another provision is:
The trustees-
Again, the Aboriginal councils-
have power to surrender the land back to the Crown.
Who can imagine the Aboriginal people wanting to surrender the land? We are fighting so jolly hard for it at the moment that I could never see them wanting to give it back. It is also provided that:
The trustees-
Again, the Council-
could lease blocks of land to particular families only if the Minister for lands gave written approval.
Again, the Honourable Russ Hinze has to give written approval before the Aboriginal people can lease their own land. That provision continues:
The Minister may, in his absolute discretion, refuse such approval.

I emphasise the words 'absolute discretion'. He does not even have to give a reason. He can say: 'No, you cannot do that'. If my son Patrick wanted to set up a turtle farm or an oyster farm on Palm Island we can imagine what Russ Hinze would say to that. He would say: 'There is no way that Bonner is going to get a lease'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would win that bet.

—No worries at all; I would win it hands down. That is only an example of what could happen. That could happen to anyone. It could happen at Mornington Island, Doomadgee, Aurukun, Cowel Creek or anywhere at all. It is further provided that:

SPEECH.PARA: The trustees-
Again, the Council in this case-
leasing houses or land to families must charge the highest rent which can reasonably be obtained.

Why is there a need for that? Why should an Aboriginal council do that? It should be trying to charge the lowest rent that it possibly can within keeping with what the people can afford, to encourage people to have their own homes and to enable them to live in decent surroundings. A further provision is as follows :
A lessee (family in possession of a house) could only enter into a mortgage with the written consent of the Minister for Lands.

If an Aborigine who wanted to build a house at Doomadgee or Hope Vale or somewhere like that after this legislation comes into being wanted to borrow some money from the Aboriginal Development Commission he could not do it without the written consent of the Minister for Lands. It is provided that:
The Minister for Lands (and not just the trustees) may cancel any lease if he is satisfied its conditions are not being met.

Again, the Minister-not the Aboriginal councillors and not the owners of the place-has authority to cancel. So the people do not own the land under the proposal that is being put forward. The next provision is:
Any person whose lease is so cancelled is not entitled to any compensation for any improvements made to the land by him.

That is provided for in the Land Act under which the Queensland Government is going to give this deed of grant to the Aboriginal people with all these powers vested in the Minister. Let us take the situation of a group of Aboriginal people on, say, Bamaga, who decide to have a banana plantation, work their insides out, fall the scrub, grow the stuff, and do all the improvements. The Minister, in his absolute discretion, may suddenly cancel the lease. They will not be compensated for all the work they have done, for all the banana trees that are growing there or for all the fruit that may be on them because it involves the absolute discretion of the Minister.

Legislation states that the police are empowered to remove any person whose lease has been terminated by the Minister for Lands. The Minister may whistle up the boys in blue and say: 'Get this Abo out of here'-that is the type of term I know he would use-'he is trespassing because I have taken his lease back.' The legislation states that the trustees-again in this case the Council-may not allow any person to occupy any land on a reserve for more than a month without prior consent in writing of the Minister for Lands. Gosh, the Minister is a great guy! He comes in on every crack of the whip. The legislation also states that if the trustees-again in this case the Council-be in default in regard to mortgage payments relating to reserve land, the land may be sold by the mortgagee. We have been trying to prevent that land being sold or repossessed in any shape or form so as not to alienate it from the Aboriginal people. The Minister may do this.

The Act further states that the Land Court may hear an application by the Minister for Lands if he be of the view that the area of any reserve land exceeds that reasonably required for residence, et cetera, and the Court is to exercise any excess from the deed of grant. The Governor-in-Council may resume any land needed for public purposes, including airstrips, scenic purposes, camping places, departmental purposes, experimental farms, pasturage reserves, quarries, et cetera. The Government is not letting the Aboriginal people have the reserve lands at all because under this legislation it can do all these things. It can excise the land from the lease for airstrips. That is okay because the Aboriginal people may want an airstrip. What are scenic purposes, camping places, departmental purposes, experimental farms and pasturage reserves ? It means they could take half of, say, the area of the reserve lands of Doomadgee and lease it to a pastoralist because the Act states 'for pasturage reserves'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take Palm Island for tourism.

—Take Palm Island for tourism-whatever you like. The Act further states that it would not be necessary for a person desirous of entering trust land for mining or prospecting purposes to make an application to the Mining Warden or to obtain consent of the trustees. The Governor-in-Council would be free to give permission for such entry under the Mining Act in Queensland.
—It is a disgrace.

—And we are told that the Queensland Government has moved a long way. It has not moved one iota, in my opinion. I hope that many honourable senators will read that part of the list in Hansard because it is important that we understand that a red herring has been thrown in front of everbody-that the Queensland Government is doing the right thing for the Aboriginal people. Why are these activists such as Charlie Perkins, Neville Bonner, et cetera, kicking up a row?
—Ha, ha!
—Senator Macklin should not laugh because he would be branded as an activist in our state of Queensland, as he well knows.
—Just as well we have activists, otherwise how would we know about it?

—If we did not have a few activists we would not know about it and the legislation would go through. The Federal Minister has given me an assurance that he is still confident that we can get a better deal. I am not confident. I have no confidence in the Queensland Government moving one little bit on this issue. The issue has been given coverage all over Australia by all sections of the media. I have not yet found one section of the media that has not supported the kind of things we are asking for in Queensland: Security of tenure and the right to determine our own future as far as reserve lands are concerned. We do not want something that can be taken away at the drop of a hat or at the whim of a government, Cabinet, a Minister or the Premier. If there is a shift and we get proper security of tenure of those lands-limited freehold with a right of determination by the Aboriginal people- I will be the first person to stand up in this Parliament and apologise from the bottom of my heart to the Queensland Government.
—It won't.

—I do not think I will need to do that at the moment. What do we come to? We come to this: The criterion that the Minister said the Commonwealth would accept is nowhere near what has been proposed by the Queensland Government . What should we do? In 1967-this has been said time and again-the people of Australia overwhelmingly supported a referendum giving the Commonwealth Government the power to make special laws for Aboriginal people. The Commonwealth Government has that power. If the criterion laid down by the Commonwealth Government is not met under these terms, the Government has no alternative but to exercise that power and to resume, under Commonwealth laws, those reserve lands and do what it did in the Northern Territory. I have some statistics of the area of land held by Aboriginal people. These statistics are contained in a speech which the Minister gave some time ago. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, representing 1.2 per cent of the population, now hold title to some 9.6 per cent of the land area.
I take it that he is speaking of the land area of Australia. He continued:
They hold 738,032 square kilometres. More than half of it is inalienable freehold.

It is interesting to note that not one solitary acre, hectare or square kilometre of that land is in the State of Queensland; it is in the Northern Territory and South Australia and a small portion is in Victoria. Another interesting fact is that it was a Liberal Government that gave the land rights to the Northern Territory. It was a Liberal Government in South Australia that gave land rights to the Aboriginal people. It was a Liberal Government in Victoria that gave land rights to the Aboriginal people. None of the other States until now, including Queensland, has given one solitary hectare. Not an inch of that land is in my State of Queensland, despite the fact that all the Aboriginal people are asking for are the reserved lands that have been set aside for Aboriginal people for over 100 years.

All they are saying is: Now that you are abolishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders legislation, you are throwing us out on their own, but do not throw us off our land. Let us retain our land.' All we are asking for is pure and simple justice. We have an area comprising 9.6 per cent of the total land mass of Australia-it sounds a lot in terms of smaller nations-but Australia was once wholly and solely owned by the indigenous people. All they have so far is 9 .6 per cent. All we are asking for in Queensland is approximately 1.2 per cent, and we cannot have that.

I thank the Senate for its courtesy in listening to me, again in my perhaps emotional way. It is an emotional issue; it is something that is burnt indelibly on my heart and I cannot do otherwise than fight the only way I know, through this Parliament to ensure justice for those of my people who live in my State of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take advantage of the first reading of these money Bills to carry on with a matter which I first outlined in the Senate on 23 February. Some honourable senators will remember that on that day I spoke about a blatant mail order fraud which was operating out of Queensland. Although the mail order company had its headquarters in Queensland, it was doing business throughout Australia. It was advertising in national magazines. Because it was advertising in respectable magazines people thought it was a respectable firm. In fact, it is a crooked firm. The firm I mentioned in particular was operating under the name 'June Taylor' and had a post office box at Spring Hill, an inner suburb of Brisbane. I do not think that 'June Taylor' is an actual person. The manager, or the person who has a close association with this firm, is a Mr Robert Clark, who lives in one of the Brisbane suburbs. This was all mentioned on 23 February and I do not intend to go over it again.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned on that day that the magazines that ran the advertisement for this person should have been more careful about the firm before they ran the advertisement because those who read the Australian Women's Weekly, for instance , would have thought that it is a respectable magazine and, therefore, the company must be a respectable one. I outlined last month that the Australian Women's Weekly found out that the firm was not respectable and it will not advertise for it any more. I also mentioned on that date that perhaps Australia Post should look into whether it should continue to give this person a post office box, but I do not know whether Australia Post can, in fact, do that. I mentioned that this misleading advertisement stated that 100 dolls would be available for the price of $19.95. I outlined how the advertisement was quite enticing and how people reading it may think that they would be getting a good deal in getting these 100 dolls that were supposed to please one's daughter or the girl next door.

I described to the Senate a couple of the dolls that 'June Taylor', which I think is an alias for Robert Clark, had sent to me. I held them up in the chamber. I remember Senator Kilgariff saying that he needed a telescope to be able to see these dolls from the other side of the chamber. They were not dolls, they were just plastic figures. He certainly would have needed a telescope to see them. To give some indication of the size of them I have brought a matchbox into the Senate chamber. One can see that they are not the height of a matchbox, so they are quite small. In fact, I could have put two of these figures into a match box and closed the matchbox quite easily.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to table the matchbox?

—If I could I would probably try to incorporate it in Hansard but I think that that might be a little difficult! On that day I showed two small figures. They were not anything like the dolls that this person was advertising. I thought that that was bad enough, but obviously what has happened is that 'June Taylor', in sending these figures, sent something which is quite different from what is usually sent because after I spoke in the Senate on 23 February a person who lives in Canberra came to me and said that he had ordered some of these dolls and he showed me some of the 100 dolls he had received in the post for $19.95. If Senator Kilgariff needed a telescope to see the other dolls from the other side of the chamber, he would need a more powerful one to see the 100 little dolls this person received. They are just plastic figures of the type that one might get in a cornflakes packet or a packet of weeties. As I hold them up against the matchbox, honourable senators can see that they are even smaller. The dolls are actually about two-thirds of the size of the matchbox. I have only three of them, but I have calculated that I could fit 12 of them into a matchbox, not just the two I was able to fit in earlier.
—Inflation is the problem.

—I do not know that it is inflation, deflation perhaps. It is absolutely absurd that for $19.95 one should be sent 100 figures of that kind made out of cheap plastic. Twelve of them would quite easily fit into a matchbox . This person is an absolute fraud. He ought to be exposed. People should understand that if they send for material from this person they will not get anything that is of any value at all.
—The Trade Practices Act should deal with it.

—I took along some of the dolls that one of Senator McLaren's constituents had originally passed on to me. On 23 February I mentioned that I was first shown some of these dolls by one of Senator McLaren's constituents. Senator McLaren got in touch with me because this person was operating out of Brisbane. The trade practices people and the consumer affairs people apparently find it fairly difficult to deal with this person because of the way he structures his advertisements. The advertisements are quite enticing but there is nothing in them which is untruthful. I guess that as long as one can still define that small figure as a doll he is getting by quite easily.
—Surely it is deceptive advertising.

—It is certainly deceptive advertising. I really cannot see how he gets away with it but apparently he has got away with it so far. I honestly think that one could get 100 dolls of that type for a couple of dollars in a chain store-perhaps not the ones that he sent to me but the ones he sends to his customers. He charges $19.95. If he is able to do that the other things that he is selling are probably just as bad.

SPEECH.PARA: I will outline some of the things that he is selling so that people can beware of getting anything from this person. He is selling the Cross of Antron. I am not quite sure what the Cross of Antron is supposed to do, but it is supposed to be pretty good. The name on the acceptance form is not 'June Taylor'; it is ' Lydia Stalnaker, House of Isis, Box 533, Post Office, Fortitude Valley'. This is the same person.
