SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity at the first reading stage of these money Bills to open up for discussion the report on alcohol, cannabis and heroin called Social Policies on Drugs and put out by the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence. The three drugs chosen were treated with varying priorities. In the report 2 pages were devoted to alcholol, 8 pages to cannabis and one page to heroin. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Workshop decided to spend a greater amount of its time in dealing with one drug in depth, rather than attempt to give superficial attention to the whole field. Cannabis was chosen as the drug for detailed consideration; however, the participants were also able to discuss alcohol and heroin and the conclusions reached have been recorded.

I, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, was one of the participants invited along. Unfortunately, the workshop met between 7 and 9 April and during the Senate sitting hours; so I was able to attend on only two occasions. When the workshop met it was obvious that I was not going to be in agreement. I asked the workshop members whether they would put in their introduction that I was not in agreement with many of the opinions expressed by them. They very obligingly did so. The workshop said also that other participants did not necessarily agree with all the matters contained in the statement. However, the statement represents a consensus and is put forward for discussion.
There were 13 participants. They were people who covered a very wide spectrum of our society. They made recommendations to the Government. I read from their news release which stated:
The group believes possession, use and home-grown marihuana should be legal, as for beer. All other production would be prohibited and punished by law.
They suggest in the report:

(c) That for the production, manufacture and distribution of cannabis in Australia, a feasibility study be entered into with a view to creating a government monopoly and to ensure a standard and uniform quality; and
(d) That research be conducted to complete data gaps concerning cannabis use . . .
They elaborate on that. They suggest also:
(a) That an Act similar to the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act (UK) 1974 be legislated for . . .

I am completely opposed to the legalisation of home-grown marihuana for personal use and to an investigation into a monopoly by the Government of the production, manufacture and distribution of cannabis. First of all, let us look at the 'legal and home-grown' question. If we say that we will allow the use of home-grown cannabis to be legal, how many plants are we talking about? Nobody has suggested how many plants would be allowed to be home grown by one person or perhaps for family consumption. Nor has anyone suggested the variety of cannabis plant which should be allowed to be used.

The content of THC-the intoxicant of the cannabis plant-within the varieties which have been grown in Australia and America varies between nought per cent and 14 per cent. The working party has not suggested that we grow cannabis with only a certain THC content. It varies considerably. If we allow people to grow their own cannabis, we have to tell them that they can use only the dried leaves and that they must not use the rest of the plant, because the THC content of the flowering tops is considerably greater. If we allow people to use the resin of the plant and if we allow them to 'thrash' the plant, they can get hashish and hashish oil. Of course, there was no suggestion by the working party that hashish and hashish oil would be desirable things to legalise. The working party has very bravely said: 'We will allow people legally to grow their own marihuana '. It has completely ignored the fact that, once people are allowed to grow their own, we cannot possibly control what they do with that cannabis plant- whether they use the leaves, the flowering tops or the resin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think you have spent too much time on drugs, Senator?
—It might be a good idea if Senator Button investigated this matter just a little because he could make some intelligent comments. But at the moment he is not making much sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go on to what we know about the plant cannabis or about marihuana. The working party admits openly on page 7 of its report that it knows very little about it. Indeed, it comments on the Eighth Annual Report to the United States Congress from the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. It quotes from that report, as follows:

Unfortunately, the present limited knowledge is often interpreted as indicating that marihuana is 'safe'. More accurately, there are many areas in which the parameters of risk are simply unknown . . . Among the long-term effects are possible lung damage in heavy users, possible genetic and chromosomal effects . . . The implications, if any, for humans are as yet unknown.

But the members of the working party say that they do not know much about it. In 1980 that annual report to the United States Congress, also stated a section not quoted in the report AFADD, it also said:

The chemistry of marihuana smoke has commanded considerable attention in recent years. Some 150 compounds have been identified in the smoke itself. One of them, benzopyrene, known to be carcinogenic, is 70 per cent more abundant in marihuana smoke than in tobacco smoke.
One of the carcinogenic compounds found in marihuana smoke is 70 per cent more abundant in it than in cigarette smoke.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is whether it should be a criminal offence.

—I am very glad that Senator Tate has walked into the chamber because I know his attitudes in this area. Indeed, we will be debating this matter at the University of Tasmania on Monday week. So, I am giving the honourable senator the opportunity to get all the information possible from me to make some sort of effort to combat my argument. I have no problems in that area whatsoever. I am very happy for him to be sitting listening.

SPEECH.PARA: The working party aclnowledged it knew very little about it. It did not evidently read on in that eighth annual report to the United States Congress far enough to see that it stated that there was 70 per cent more of a carcinogenic compound in marihuana smoke than in tobacco smoke. But it ends up by saying: 'We do not believe, in present knowledge, that the effects are worse than tobacco or alcohol'. Of course, it does say: 'If you legalise it, for heaven's sake you must put a health warning on the packet'. Then we will have to go through again what we are going through with tobacco! It is a quite incredible situation!

There are some things that we know about THC. We know that, unlike alcohol which is expelled very rapidly from the body, THC is stored in fatty tissues. We also know that THC, taken in combination with alcohol, has not just the doubling effect but a multiplier effect. We know that if someone smokes marihuana today, because THC is stored in the body there is a slow release over some time for up to a couple of weeks. We also know that if a person smokes marihuana today and goes on an alcohol binge in perhaps a couple of days, that person will not be quite sure how intoxicated he is when he gets into a car to drive. He knows that he he has had so much alcohol but has no idea how intoxicated the slow release of THC will make him. So, we have some sort of knowledge. As people have been using cannabis for many years, why do we not have more knowledge?

Because of new technology and new techniques for detecting and measuring cannabis products in the blood, we are now able to do research that previously was not available to us. It is a great pleasure for me to see former Senator Cavanagh sitting in the gallery because I know from past experience that he agrees with me in this area. The report for 1981 of the International Narcotics Control Board was released only on 28 January 1982, after the working party had made its deliberations. I quote a considerable amount of that report. It said:

While in some circles in a number of countries there remains an erroneous belief that cannabis is harmless, mounting scientific evidence shows significant health hazards resulting from cannabis abuse including cancer. On the positive side, there is also evidence in one country that publicising such research findings among a high risk youth population has led both to a somewhat diminished appeal of this drug and to a certain reduction of its use . . . the board wishes to recall that inadequate exercise of drug control on the part of one Government can affect the situation not only in that country itself, but also in other, particularly neighbouring, countries.
In other words, the Board is there warning the Government that if we relax penalties it will not be just Australia that is affected but also neighbouring countries.
The United Nations has appealed that we do not do that. However we come then to the recent--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I genuinely missed that. Who produced the report?

—It is a report of the International Narcotics Control Board. It was released on 28 January 1982. There was an embargo on it until 28 January 1982. The report then mentions recent developments. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Board notes that the problem of cannabis and its products (including marihuana, hashish and hashish oil) continues to dominate the illicit traffic in many countries and that the non-medical consumption of cannabis is far higher than that of any other substance subject to control. Furthermore, the drug is being used in ever more harmful forms.
. . . Whereas marihuana, consisting mainly of dried leaves and stems, has a potency range up to 8 per cent THC, the solvent extracts of the leaf material, flowers or resin . . .
I have gone into this-
can have a potency of up to 60 per cent THC. Consumption of such potent cannabis , unavailable 10 years ago, has risen steeply.

In previous Reports the Board noted that increased cannabis consumption might reflect a widespread belief that cannabis is harmless. Accordingly, the Board called for accelerated scientific research to elaborate more definitive conclusions about adverse health consequences.
The report goes on to the various studies that have been undertaken and reported in the report. It states:

Diverse studies carried out in a number of countries show that heavy cannabis use can produce acute psychotic reactions, lowered resistance to disease, and adverse effects on the reproductive and endocrine systems, the lungs and even on personality. Moreover, sophisticated pulmonary function testing in many well- controlled studies concludes that cannabis smoke is more injurious to the lungs than tobacco. Its smoke contains over 2,000 compounds. These include such well- known toxic agents as carbon monoxide and cyanide and . . . carcinogenic substances . . .
The article continues:
Furthermore, these studies consistently conclude that cannabis use interferes with learning, with psycho-motor functions, with driving motor vehicles, and with doing any complex task.

The importance of the research itself and the dissemination of its findings can help to alter the drug abuse picture. This is illustrated in the case of one high risk group, when such knowledge resulted in decreased cannabis use, showing that young people themselves respond to evidence of potential hazards. Therefore , Governments should take action to ensure that such evidence is made known to the public at large. They should also conduct research to enable them to monitor changes in national drug use levels and in related public attitudes and perception.
I am very sorry that Senator Chipp is not here but some of the other Australian Democrats are. They may also care to listen to this and perhaps convince--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the inference of that?
—I would like Senator Chipp who has come out publicly--
—Senator Chipp votes for himself, and I vote for myself. Do not include me.
—I am very glad to know that you are talking so strongly.
—Senator Chipp made that abundantly clear.
—Yes. I am delighted.
—You have not even heard my views.

—I am delighted to hear the honourable senator say that. There was no inference, and you seem very touchy. There is no inference that you would be voting the same way as Senator Chipp. I said that Senator Chipp was not here and that perhaps you could tell him and ask him--
—You can tell him.
—Well, I am very happy to hear you are so upset about it because that indicates to me that you may not agree with Senator Chipp on this subject.
—I don't want you making inferences.
—It would be very interesting to hear later that perhaps the honourable senator may have something to say on the matter.
—That is almost worth a point of order, that sort of nonsense.
—I could not agree with the honourable senator more.
—Well, why do you make such stupid statements?

—That one party might tell the Leader of the other party of the debate in this chamber, I think, is quite proper. Having now highlighted some of the more recent knowledge regarding the consumption of marihuana or cannabis, perhaps it would be right for me to get back to the report. On page 7, as I have already indicated, the report states that the Committee knows very little about it. Then they quote from the United States Congress report saying: We don't know much about it. They then go on to say: Because there is such a grey area and we do not know a great deal about it, then policies which are to be adopted should not be such as to increase dramatically the levels or duration of marihuana use. So they say: Good, we do not know a great deal about it; there is a great grey area out there. So we really should not have policies that would increase the use of marihuana. They then throw their arms in the air and say: But let us legalise it for personal use, let us allow people to grow their own. After all, we do not know a thing about it and we think that it is not any more harmful than alcohol or tobacco. That seems to me to be quite incredible, quite illogical and quite contradictory.

SPEECH.PARA: As you may be aware, Madam Acting Deputy President, the Senate Standing Committee did some in-depth research in the area of this drug. We brought out a report entitled 'Drug problems in Australia: An intoxicated society'. At that time we had the same sorts of things brought to our attention as this Committee presently did. Its concerns were the same concerns as were expressed by the working party. The news release states:
On present medical knowledge, the group believes marihuana . . . is possibly less harmful than alcohol and tobacco . . .
But the latest report certainly rules that out. The news release states that the committee:
. . . could not accept the intolerable social costs related to prohibition- criminal syndicates and corruption in particular had to be destroyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point.
—Okay, Senator Tate. The news release continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It also attacked society's double standards in condoning, and even encouraging the drugs of the older generation (e.g., alcohol, tobacco), while severely punishing those of younger Australians' (e.g. marijuana) actions which cannot be justified either ethnically or medically.

So they are saying that the adult population, because of its previous lack of knowlege in the area of tobacco, has had tremendous problems and shocking problems with its health. There is no need for me to inform the Senate today of those problems. They are well known to everyone. The adult population of Australia has had its problems and the cost to society generally is enormous. I do not believe that anyone in the Senate would have deliberately introduced tobacco hundreds of years ago had we had the foresight and the knowledge of the problems and effects that tobacco would have on our health.

We do not have the knowledge in relation to cannabis. It is coming out. For heaven's sake, do not let us make the same mistake and say to our young: 'Look, we do not know the problems that you will face with your health. We are just becoming knowledgeable about it. Results of research are coming out about it. But we do not care; we are not particularly concerned about your health. It is fair because we are ruining our health with tobacco products which we can no longer take away just because people are addicted to it that we say to you that we will legalise cannabis for you so that your health can suffer perhaps to a far greater extent by smoking this particular weed.' That was the main concern of the Committee. I want to quote from the remarks of one of the witnesses who came before the Committee when it was inquiring into drug problems in Australia. This was possibly one of the most enlightening comments we heard from anyone. He was a marihuana smoker. When asked to tell us the difference between cannabis and alcohol, he said:

Cannabis differs from alcohol in one very vital aspect . . . If one is asked if one wants a drink there is no implicit inference that one will or should get drunk-however with Cannabis 'do you want a smoke' means 'do you want to get stoned'. The inference is direct, precise and almost always implicit. The act of getting stoned is very deliberate. It is shared in turns and in comparison with alcohol short and quick. Getting stoned is rarely incidental to smoking as getting drunk may be to alcohol.

I believe that this report should be debated in the community. I believe the Government should make the facts available from the international report. If the report 'Social Policies on Drugs' has done nothing else it has brought forth further discussion enabling considerable new evidence to be brought to light which, according to the International Narcotics Control Board, every government in every country has a responsibility to bring before its people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in the first reading debate on these money Bills which seek to increase certain levies, about the problems of small business and what small business runs into in the collection of a number of taxes, particularly sales tax. I take the example of a constituent of mine in Queensland whom I asked early last year to keep a record of the problems with which he found himself involved regarding the collection of such taxes. This constituent lives in a country town in Queensland, has invested his savings in that town and has established his family there. In seeking to expand his business, he became a manufacturer as well as a retailer. In Australian Taxation Office jargon he became a retailer-wholesaler.

SPEECH.PARA: His special problems are with exemptions. He said, to use his words, that ' exemptions are the stuff-up'. He works in an area which has connections with agriculture, automotive electronics. In the case of agricultural exemptions he must claim from the original supplier. He is expected, therefore, to shuffle through several cubic metres of invoices, find the particular invoice and claim from the supplier quoting his invoice number, the part number, the make and the exemption number. Because his is a small business in a country town he must keep a fairly wide range of parts but he would not have a great turnover on some of them. Some of these parts may sit on a shelf for up to two years. He has estimated in his stocktaking that he would need to label over 5,000 individual items and that would have to label them with the name of the supplier, the invoice number, the cost price and the date of purchase. That is obviously a preposterous economic proposition for a small businessman involved in his type of industry. For every exempt retail transaction he is engaged in he is expected to fill out a certificate and is expected to know the part of the relevant Act under which that exemption is claimed. He also must be extremely careful because there is no redress from the customer in this type of transaction. It is virtually between him and the Taxation Office.

Taxation Office officials do not seem to understand the problems of small business in this country. For example, the businessman I am talking about often has to go to a farm. He may go there, for example, to fix a tractor and the owner may be away. Farmers have a fair idea of the areas in which they are exempt and therefore they expect to see the exemption noted at the bottom of the bill that is sent. My constituent mails out the bills with the exemption certificate if the farmers are not there when he does the work. Often farmers fail to return such certificates and the small businessman of whom I am speaking is then under an obligation under the Act to follow it up. It is his responsibility to get that done. If he fails to do so he is in breach of the Act . Every once in a while an official from the Taxation Office visits, goes through all the files and discovers that many of these cases have not been followed up. The businessman is then issued with a stern warning with possible threats of penalties and the like.

This happens not only to the single businessman of whom I speak but also to thousands upon thousands of small businessmen in this country. What we are talking about adds up to an enormous cost to small business, the largest employer in this country. After the small businessman has managed, if he can, to get over that hurdle of the exemption certificate he is not yet out of the woods -not by any means. Let us take another example that came out of this man's files . I will quote from the sales tax exemption certificate that the businessman fills out, giving examples of the types of insertions of detail provided by the constitutent:

I hereby certify that the 3 only horseshoe nails purchased from . . . on 2.2.82 is for use as a part of a horse for use in manure farming and exemption is accordingly claimed under item 117 (2) first schedule of the Sales Tax ( Exemption and Classification) Act.
The form is then signed and dated. Taking another item from my constituent's files, it reads:
One battery retainer bolt 20 cents Less 30% trade 6 cents Plus sales tax 2 cents

This may look fairly straightforward, but how much did the retainer bolt cost? Honourable senators should not forget what I was talking about at the beginning. The tax is based on what this retainer bolt cost. Did it come out of stock bought last June or last November when he also purchased some, or did it come out of the stock he bought last week when he also purchased some of these battery retainer bolts? In the above example the businessman determined that he owed the Taxation Office the princely sum of one cent on this transaction. Unfortunately for him, he cannot persuade his staff to do the necessary paperwork when he happens to be out fixing tractors. They give such items away free.

Their argument to my constituent runs as follows: 'If we fill out all of those forms for you to get one cent for the Government, you will lose less than your profit margin because we have not been able to work on the cars that are in your repair shop'. Therefore, they say to him 'It makes sense to give away the retainer bolt rather than to waste your time and our time filling out the forms' . While this particular businessman sees the merit in that point he is rather disconcerted that in order to collect 1c from the Government he must lose his 6c , 14c or whatever in profit on the item. After all, he is in business and he must stay in business. He must sell his goods at a reasonable profit margin.

Unfortunately, the particular businessman of whom I speak also is rather industrious which is partly a downfall under this private enterprise government. He was determined not only to retail a range of goods but also-he feels now rather stupidly-determined to get into the manufacture of batteries. He sought to expand his business in the town and indeed, was able to provide additional employment for two people in his business in the manufacture of batteries. For this private enterprise crime of becoming a manufacturer and providing employment in a country town, he is attacked by the bureaucracy with an extraordinary amount of paperwork. Unfortunately, he manufactures hard rubber batteries. Since most of these are for agricultural machinery and are consequently tax exempt-again, unfortunately for him-he buys his component parts free of tax and adds tax to his batteries when a normal sales transaction occurs .

He also sells across the counter to other people who may come to buy a particular battery. The tax payable would normally be charged on the sale price but our businessman wholesales as well and the tax applicable is imposed at the lowest wholesale rate, according to the Act. As a consequence, all the batteries have to be wholesaled since to add the necessary tax would price his product- produced locally, providing local employment and assisting in decentralisation in this country-way above the price asked by a large manufacturer. Again the small businessman suffers. The businessman seeking to provide employment and business in a small country town suffers at the hands of large multinationals in this area. Perhaps he has not supplied particular political parties with sufficient funds.

Would it not make sense in relationship to this item to look at alternatives which may, if the Government wishes, raise the same amount of tax but not build into the whole methodology vast amounts of paperwork and vast costs? Would it not make sense to look at some other notions-for example, some type of turnover tax collected once a year when he puts in his submissions to the Taxation Office in the normal course of events? Would it not make sense to look at other types of options which may lessen the amount of paperwork imposed on businesses which are not geared to cope with that type of work. Of course, we saw as late as yesterday that the Government wished to press ahead with the establishment of sales tax on a further range of small businesses in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you discussed that with the RTA?

—I am suggesting a range of possible options that the Government may wish to look at. These are the types of options that it may be able to look at, in discussion and collaboration with the people of this country, to lower the amount of paperwork and bureaucracy. There are a range of options operating around the world which would be beneficial if applied to our small businesses. I am quite sure that in discussion with small business we would find many solutions. One of these, of course, may be to collect taxes-as I just said-only upon the tax returns that small businessmen have to put in each year. While that may deprive the Government of a continual flow of funds it may also save small businessmen enormous amounts of money.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take the example of an actual sales tax return from the person I am discussing. The businessmen had to claim $5 directly from the Taxation Office as a credit for goods purchased and the tax paid thereon by statutory bodies and by various government departments. He had to put in a further claim for $28.24 previously paid and which now could be claimed due to the price shifts plus late exemptions that arrived from a couple of farmers in the previous month. The businessman then had to tally all his retails sales for the month and add to this labour and other exempt portions of the wholesale section of the business he was so stupid to start. He then added to this the retail price of manufactured goods. Then he had to take off the wholesale selling equivalent and the sales tax. After that he had to remit $231.25 to the Government in sales tax .

However, if he had been allowed to take out of that amount costs of collection, in particular the cost of collection for this classic piece of bureaucratic paper shuffling-which I have already set out-and if he were actually able to charge the Government for his time in the same way that he charges people for batteries and to fix tractors-or charges anybody else for his labour-he would have remitted to the Government this month $39.25. I believe that would be equitable and fair. But the Government, being a great champion of free enterprise, of course wishes to make sure that small businessmen do not charge the Government for their labours. I believe it is perfectly reasonable that he should charge the Government if he is operating as an unpaid tax collector, in the same way that he charges someone to fix a tractor. His time is his livelihood; it does not belong to the Government. If the honourable senator sitting on the other side of the chamber who is laughing about this matter would like to talk to small businessmen he might discover that they would jump across the counter-not considering it a laughing matter-and do damage to his face. Small businessmen in this country are riled indeed at being imposed upon time and again and at being imposed upon yet again by the Government's seeking to raise additional taxes in this area.

In other words, the cost of collection in this month for the small businessman- the record of which he kept for my scrutiny and very carefully kept for his records-on $232.25 collected for the Government was $192. He cannot recoup that from his customers in that town. He cannot pass that amount on. I am sure that the Government would say 'Look, don't worry about it; just pass on the cost to the consumer'. He would be driven out of business and have to close down his manufacture of batteries because he could not compete. There would be a subsequent loss of employment in that country town. There would indeed be a loss in relation to the types of things that the Australian Democrats believe should be done in this country. We believe that every policy brought forward by this Government should make sure that we have not yet again penalised small business and prevented proper and adequate decentralisation. The last point I raise is one which I think needed to be raised in the Senate. It relates to the various proposals which the Government brought forward in the last Budget. Indeed, it is rumoured that the next Budget will attempt to bring them forward yet again. I will read from what a principal of one of the Brisbane primary schools had to say. She said:

You would know that children are requested to bring money to school for activities such as cultural visits, excursions. Any monies that are collected by the school other than P. and C. money have to be entered in our Internal Account which is subject to government audit. This requires teachers to have cash collection books and every cent that is produced by any child on any day has to be recorded in that book. At the end of the day that cash collection book has to go to the office and the administrator, usually the Principal, has to record teachers collections for every day, no matter how small or how large. A receipt has to be written for every teacher. This receipt is posted in the teacher's cash collection book by the administrator. The administrator then has to enter into a large analysis book the details of every receipt issued. TALK.START.PARA: —Just as a British Labour Government cut off support for any equipment of British manufacture to the Australian forces during the Vietnam conflict-a move which failed and had to be withdrawn owing to the forthright action of the Australian Prime Minister of the day-we now have the totally untenable position of having a piece of major equipment of great complexity in need of assured spares support dependent on the political views of the British Government of the day. There is no problem with the present British Government. It would sell arms to any country in the world but times and attitudes change and we want support for this ship for 20 years. It must be a condition of sale that the British Government gives an unqualified undertaking to provide full support for the life of this ship.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my intention now to go into a technical debate. I would be delighted to do so but in 10 minutes I cannot. However, I heard members of the Australian Labor Party debating the ship's radar in the other place. The move to transfer the identification of friend or foe equipment from Melbourne to the Invincible is a perfectly reasonable one. It is just adding a function to the existing radar equipment. While I have had no first hand experience of the radar in the Invincible, my belief is that it would be as good as any in the world, knowing the manufacturers and the state of the art of the British in this field. In the absence of a clear statement from the Department of Defence as to the strategic concept of operations for the Australian defence forces, one is at a loss to see the use of a ship such as the Invincible. All it provides is a platform for some anti-submarine warfare helicopters. We have to demonstrate some capability in ASW so that we are not held to ransom or blackmailed too easily by any country with a missile firing submarine. On the other side of the coin, if all we want is a platform for ASW helicopters and a ship with command, control and communications functions, then there are ways of buying this at a fraction of the cost.

My worries about this ship go back to its basic design. It was built for a specific role. It was to be an advanced ASW ship to operate under the protection of land based aircraft, to be an integral part of a complex fleet with all the sensors required. The Royal Australian Navy wants to use it in an entirely different role as a capital ship in a task force. In any list of worries about the decision, one certainly has to include the objectivity of the RAN and its ability to decide in the national interest. The only doubt that I do not have about the Navy's senior officers is their sincerity, for they really believe that what they are doing is correct. The purchase of this ship sets in an inflexible mould the maritime responses possible to Australia for the next 15 or 20 years. If the decision is correct, then everything is fine, but if it is not then we are in big trouble.

Every analysis performed by the Department of Defence of the provision of this type of ship for Australia-I instance the Naval Tactical Air Power at Sea Study- has emphatically shown that this type of ship was the least cost effective and the least appropriate option available to the forces. The greatest fear of all, though, relates to the vulnerability of this ship. For defence, it has only decoys and an area defence missile system in the form of the Sea Dart, which is quite useless against sea skimming missiles. Even if the close-in weapons system Phalanx is fitted, this is not a secure system. When it works it is very effective but it can never be 100 per cent effective and even if it could be, simultaneous multiple missile attacks would overwhelm it. Looking ahead a few years to when missile speeds will possibly treble to Mach 3, target acquisition, electronic counter measures and anti decoy features will be refined, radar stealth technology will be incorporated and the advantage which already lies with the attacker will be even stronger. This is a very high risk venture. Frankly, I do not believe in gambling with the security of the nation.

DEBATE.TITLE: LEGAL AID COMMISSION OF THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1980-81

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a fairly bland and brief report which conceals a fairly turbulent history, in particular the resignation of a former director of the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission, Mr Peter Sharkey, following a long history of conflict with the private profession in the Australian Capital Territory and a good deal of frustration within the Commission. The report makes no reference to the subsequent appointment, following Mr Sharkey's departure, of Mr Wheeler as the Director of Legal Aid in the Australian Capital Territory, notwithstanding the view that is held in many quarters that this appointment was , for a number of reasons, less than entirely just to Mr Tony Hardiman of the existing Commission. Generally, a most unhappy set of events has surrounded the operation of the Austalian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission and that has to some extent been the subject of exploration within the Senate Estimates committees. As I have said, it is in some ways surprising that so little of that history is evident in the text of the report before us this evening.

Even so, the report on its face demonstrates a number of unhappy features about the operation of the legal aid system. For example, it reveals on page 2 that the staff ceilings within the Commission have been a continuing problem involving a reduction from 33 to 29 office bearers in the period between mid- 1980 and the end of 1981-approximately 12 per cent of the resources of the Commission. The squeeze is on, and with the demand for legal aid continuing to rise, cuts of this kind inevitably restrict the proportion of the work which can be done by salaried practitioners. As we have argued so often in this place, that is the only way in which a rational system of legal aid can be delivered in this country, given scarce resources and ever increasing demand. It is a matter for regret that the razor gang exercise late in 1981 further applied a cost squeeze and has produced considerable internal tension within the Commission which is not recorded-because of the chronology, I suppose-in this report.

I think the membership of the Commission, which is dealt with on page 1 of the report, also justifies some comment. There have been significant changes in the composition of the Commission, notably involving the replacement of two community representatives with two nominees of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). This has created a situation of, again, some conflict of an unfortunate kind which perhaps bears further explanation, as no doubt it will receive in the Estimates Committee hearings of this Parliament shortly. There is no proposal currently on foot to ensure that a commisioner is appointed who can represent the staff of the Commission. There have been repeated calls for this by the staff, by the unions and by certain members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. These calls have been met with point blank refusals by the relevant authorities. That again is a matter of regret so far as the Opposition is concerned. Another aspect which justifies comment on the operation of the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission is the way in which the private profession in the Australian Capital Territory has less than gloriously continued to campaign actively against the position of the Public Defender, a full time officer, in effect, of the present Commission. I note with some pleasure that this attack seems to have been beaten off at present but it can by no means be assumed, given the history of this Commission in a whole variety of contexts, that that situation will continue. I am advised that the relationship has improved recently but that relationship, I fear, will always be a relatively delicate and volatile one, given what seems to be the prevailing attitude in the profession in the Australian Capital Territory which is one of something less than a total acceptance of the values of the purpose for which the legal aid system in the Australian Capital Territory and elsewhere was set up. There are some concerns arising from the financial aspects of this report. Approximately $ 90,000 is still outstanding from liabilities accrued in 1978-79 as at the end of the 1981 financial year. Also it is recorded on page 8 that the total liabilities, mainly in the form of commitments to private practitioners, are well in excess of the total assets of the Commission.

There are many other points that can be made in respect of the Commission, but in deference to the agenda of this chamber I will not stop to make them now. I simply repeat that the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission has been something of a volatile organisation in recent years, deservedly receiving a good deal of criticism from a variety of sources, not least from the community it purports to serve. We in the Opposition have been unhappy about it. We will continue to be unhappy about a number of aspects of it. It would help in the future, in perhaps a slightly more detailed debate than is possible tonight, were the report of the Commission to be a little more forthcoming about some of these issues that have been controversial within the Australian Capital Territory, and this one is controversial.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for consideration of reports having expired, the Senate will proceed to General Business, Notices of Motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all Bills and amendments to Bills introduced into the Senate from the commencement of the Budget Session 1982 should be accompanied by a financial impact statement which shall contain the following information for each of:
(1) the balance of the financial year; and (2) the following two financial years-
(a) the estimated costs to Government (if any)
(b) the estimated revenue of Government (if any)
(c) the estimated savings of Government (if any)
(d) the estimated financial burden (if any) which will be imposed on industry or other sections of the community; and
(e) the estimated savings (if any) which will be of benefit to industry or other sections of the community.

This motion provides that from the date a Bill or an amendment to a Bill is introduced into the Senate, as from the commencement of the next session-in other words, the Budget session for 1982-all Bills and amendments should be accompanied by what I have called a financial impact statement. I did not devise those words; others devised them and I have adopted them. That statement would contain financial information in relation to the Bill being introduced. I have detailed the five items which I think should be included: The estimated costs to government, if any; the estimated revenue of government, if any; the estimated savings of government, if any; the estimated financial burden, if any, which will be imposed on industry or other sections of the community; and the estimated savings, if any, which will be of benefit to industry or other sections of the community.

I think the purpose of this proposal is obvious. It has been concerning me for many years that the Parliament considers legislation without any real knowledge of what the cost of that legislation will be to both the Government and to the community. I have no doubt that governments are aware of what the legislation may cost the Treasury in relation to expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we need to know.

—As my colleague Senator Teague said, we need to know. I thoroughly agree with him. Frequently, if we ask, the information is supplied to us, but it does require someone to ask. Often the cost is foreshadowed in the Budget statements. I have no doubt that if any honourable senator wishes to know the cost to government, the estimated revenue of government, the estimated savings to government-in other words, the first three items mentioned in my proposed financial impact statement-he can obtain it fairly easily from the Ministry or by asking in this chamber at some stage during the course of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The kernel of my proposal is set out in the last two items; in other words, those which talk about the financial burden or savings for industry and other sections of the community. We can appreciate that an assessment of the direct cost to the public of some such legislation is frequently available. For example , a taxing Bill can be assessed as to the direct cost, but my financial impact statement asks that we go further and find out the indirect costs of compliance. We now protect civil liberties. We have the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee which look to protect civil liberties within the community. We have environmental impact statements to protect the environment. But frequently, although we all-when I say 'all' I mean all parliamentarians-believe that we are here to protect the taxpayers, the voters and the consumers within the community, legislation passes through the chambers without the financial impact of that legislation being adequately understood by the legislature.

I openly acknowledge that the problems of assessment of a financial impact statement may not be easy to solve. I recognise that governments have limited resources but it seems to me that the best institution to provide this information is government. I am grateful to my colleague Senator Missen who suggested to me that we give consideration to adopting the procedures in the United States. In the United States there is a Congressional Budget Office which produces a budget for the Parliament in parallel with the budget produced by the Executive. The Parliamentarian, when discussing the Congressional Budget Office, stated:
Still another support agency for the legislative branch appeared in 1974--
This was in the United States-

namely the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) established by the Congressional Budget Act. While responding to requests for specific analysis, the most important responsibility of the CBO is to prepare a congressional budget in parallel with the executive budget. A foresight provision is also included in the Act, directing the CBO to issue in each fiscal year a five-year projection of the costs of continuing current federal spending and taxation policies. For any public Bill or resolution reported by a congressional committee, a five-year estimate of cost must also be made.

Honourable senators can see that that Congressional Budget Office must have a very large staff and must produce financial information which is absolutely invaluable to the United States Congress. But I must say that in these years of restraint I could not support the establishment of such a committee at this stage. I hope that if the Senate adopts this motion which I have proposed and if the Government is able to provide reasonable and adequate estimates-they are only estimates, and I recognise the difficulties of them-this Parliament may not have to go down that path. The cost of legislation and regulation and the uncosted cost of such legislation and regulation may indeed be very great. There has, in fact, been an attempt to estimate that cost by the Confederation of Australian Industry which, in July 1980, published a paper on Government Regulation in Australia. On page 76 of that paper the Confederation gave estimates, based on certain figures which are set out on previous pages. The Confederation's paper states:
. . . then direct private sector compliance costs might be of the order of:
$720m for Federal regulation;
$1,744m for State government regulation; or some $2,500 million in total.
The CAI paper goes on to say that those figures are highly qualified. It states:

It must be emphasised that no validity can be claimed for the above figures, since we have no way of knowing if the compliance costs of survey respondents are representative of private sector compliance costs in general. However, we consider that the above figures are likely to be minimum figures for direct compliance costs attributable to the 3 or 4 Federal and State government agencies most affecting each survey respondent.

I have personal knowledge of a very substantial expense created by a regulatory body. During the Estimates committee meetings in April 1981, the committee that I was chairing heard from the Public Service Board about an additional estimate of some $2,400 to enable the Public Service Board to provide certain information which had been sought from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I questioned an officer, through the responsible Minister, about this matter and ascertained that staff had to work overtime to fill out this questionnaire and to obtain the information that had been asked and that the Public Service Board estimated that it would cost $2,400 in additional payments. That seemed to me to be a very substantial sum just to fill out a questionnaire and it was done by an organisation which, no doubt, has access to computers and all sorts of machinery means of obtaining this sort of information. I went on to ask how many of these questionnaires had been sent out in Australia. Of course, the Public Service Board was not aware of that. Later I had the fortune also to have members of the Australian Bureau of Statistics come before the committee. What I questioned them about that statistical report and survey I discovered that it had gone out to about 10,000 to 12,000 businesses across Australia. Based on the estimate of the Public Service Board, to complete this report and survey industry in Australia had had imposed upon it a burden of between $24m and $28m. This was for a pilot survey. This had gone through certainly without the Parliament knowing about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the subject?

—I am sorry, Senator Chipp, I am unable to recall, but it is recorded in Hansard of April 1981. I do not doubt that it was a very valuable pilot survey. It may well be that it was reasonable for the ABS to seek that information. I am not being critical in that sense. I am simply pointing out that industry in Australia had been confronted with a bill of, say, $25m which it was unable to meet. If we analyse the situation, that really means that the consumers will ultimately have to pay another $25m. That is one example which comes readily to mind. Unfortunately, the proposal which I have put tonight will not, in fact, cover that because I am dealing only with legislation. That was done in another way. Clearly, there are major problems in connection with costs incurred by or burdens placed on industry and the community through regulations and through the actions of statutory authorities and governmental bodies, not only just by regulation but also in some other way.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be realised that the burden is frequently different, depending upon which body is asked to provide the information. It may well be that the Public Service Board, for example, with its access to computers and all other items, is able to provide information that is sought in such a way cheaper than it would be for a small business which does not have the staff involved in administrative and clerical work able to provide the information. Of course, I have little doubt that that statistical report and survey which went out from ABS did not, in fact, go to small businesses but went to major businesses which probably had the capability of supplying the information. I understand that at a subsequent stage that survey was not continued with but was withdrawn when it was realised how difficult it was to provide the information.

I do not want the Senate to think that I am criticising the ABS or any other body in connection with that. I am not talking about that at all. I am talking about that purely and simply as an example of the sort of cost which the community can have imposed upon it without the legislature really being aware of this expenditure.

I had a quick look through the Bills Digest today and I looked at some of the Bills which have come before this Parliament and about which perhaps we ought to have known something of the costs, both direct and indirect. For example, there is a Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill. The purpose of that Bill is to clarify the Government's original policy intention in regard to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980. It would be more than very interesting to know, I think it is probably essential that the Parliament ought to know, not only what would be the cost to government of that sort of legislation but also what might very well be the cost to industry and, ultimately, the consumer for this legislation to go through the Parliament. It seems to me to be very reasonable to ask the Government to provide some estimate of the cost.

I recognise, as I said before, that it may be difficult to make an estimate but I suggest to the Senate that until such time as the Government starts to make these estimates we will not know whether it is extremely difficult. As it starts to make these sorts of estimates the Government's officers will become much more expert at making the estimates. I would have no objection to the Minister responsible openly saying in the Senate that this was just a best guess based on the information available; but surely it is better that the Senate knows what is the Government's best guess in relation to this matter than that the Senate passes the legislation without having any of the knowledge at all.

I believe that the proposal would receive wide support from industry. When I gave notice of the motion I received letters from a number of bodies congratulating me on the proposal-from companies indicating that they thought that it was an excellent idea. I had correspondence with the CAI indicating that it supported the idea. I believe that industry throughout Australia would do its best to provide the Government with the answers as to cost which it needs to make on these estimates. Of course, industries frequently lobby us and tell us what they estimate the cost of some legislation will be if they are trying to stop it. That would be, in my view, a countering measure so that we had a government estimate rather than just an industry estimate of what the cost would be. The first paragraph of the Australian Industries Development Association's Bulletin for February 1982 in relation to the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System states:

The philosophical basis underlying the recommendations of the Campbell Committee is 'that the most efficient way to organise economic activity is through a competitive market system which is subject to a minimum of regulation and government intervention'.

It is that regulation and government intervention that I am interested in analysing and having costed. I believe that public disclosure of this information would enable honourable senators to consider the financial implications in their decisions. It would provide much more effective debate in the chamber about the legislation being introduced. I ask the Senate to accept the motion standing in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate my colleague Senator Lewis on his initiative in bringing forward this motion tonight covering financial impact statements which will accompany Bills passing through this chamber. I believe that should the Parliament accept the general tenor of the intent of this motion, it will, indeed, be breaking new ground and opening up new developments. I use the term 'general tenor' of the motion because I think as this debate continues it may be found necessary to develop forms of words that may have a greater practicality in implementing the whole intent of what Senator Lewis is bringing forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulties that I see are basically in paragraphs (d) and (e) where we call on industry to provide estimates. In this area I think it will be very difficult even to get good guesses. I regard this motion tonight as part of a growing sophistication or our parliamentary processes whereby this Parliament demands that it be much better informed so that it can make a more informed judgment on Bills which pass through this House. All too often, I think, we have seen hasty legislation come before us based on little more than temporary political expediency. I believe that this sort of requirement could act as a check or as a brake. At least somebody in the chamber should say: 'Shouldn't we consider the cost not only to government-be it Federal, State or local-but also to the community which we are supposed to serve?'

At other times I think parliamentarians have a rush of enthusiasm to put into a legislative framework many of their good intentions without realising again the cost to government and the cost to the community. Not only our Government but also all governments throughout the world are finding it increasingly difficult to balance Budgets. Indeed, all governments are finding it difficult to reduce public expenditure. At the same time, because of what is known as the tax revolt that is occurring around the world, governments are finding it difficult to obtain revenue. I think this is a good check and balance process which is required of all parliaments. If we can introduce something along these lines we, and particularly Senator Lewis who has moved this motion, will have offered a very constructive contribution to the Parliament.

I believe it is not beyond the powers of the Department of the Treasury or the Department of Finance to be able to give us an estimate of the cost to government. I do not believe it is beyond the powers of Treasury or Finance to give an estimate of revenue to government. I think we have to try to measure what can be measured initially because, after all, this is a starting point. Senator Lewis referred to best guesses probably being better than none. But I think possibly we should start from the approach of trying to measure those things that can be measured. I think that when one analyses a lot of these matters one finds that there is a heck of a lot that can be measured that currently is not measured and which we do not attempt to measure. I think we are all looking for savings to government. We have a number of committees of Parliament, like our Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, other expenditure committees and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which devote a great deal of time and attention to these matters. I believe that here is something that we can achieve within the parliamentary process before the Bills get off the ground-in other words, before the damage is done. My reservations are in relation to the fourth and fifth financial years which follow those provided for in the motion, and the estimated financial burden which will be imposed on industry or other sections of the community.

I acknowledge that there will be occasions when it is impossible for Budget Bills to be referred to industry because of the secrecy provisions that are essentially required. I believe that we run into a problem here. I think it is not beyond us to devise ways and means of trying to get over this approach- possibly, this is where Senator Lewis made reference to the best estimates that may be necessary in relation to the charges which are imposed on industry. In the circumstances where there are Budget Bills we cannot really ask industry what will be the cost to industry of a matter that comes through under the Budget. At the same time, I do not think we could ask industry the savings which would be of benefit to the community or sections of the industry as a result of Budget-type measures.

I believe we could get some estimate by approaching such bodies as the Australian Minerals and Energy Council, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry and these sorts of bodies to attempt to assess the costs or financial burdens of the legislation that we are likely to introduce. The community would have difficulty, I believe, in assessing the likely impact. We find this in many pieces of legislation that currently pass through this House; the Bills may have lain on the table for quite some time. It is not before the Bills are put into practical effect and have an impact on our day to day lives that the people in the community suddenly realise the costs or the savings that those Bills might generate.

Despite the fact that we might try to ask for this information in advance unfortunately there is not a lot of forward planning or thinking as to how these Bills will impact financially on our lives. We can take a guess but it is not really until we get into the practical reality of living it out on a day to day basis that the full cost and the full impact will come before us. the estimates will not be all that accurate initially but I think as time evolves we will develop processes whereby our sophistication in measuring these impacts on the community will develop. Therefore, I would like to see further debate on and reason brought into this matter so that we can get the right ultimate form of words which will develop, I believe, in time. This is undoubtedly a wonderful starting point and I commend the motion wholeheartedly to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, compliment the normally unobtrusive Senator Lewis on bringing this matter before the Senate tonight. He scoffed at me a week or two ago when I said that the Australian Democrats come into this chamber prepared to change their minds on issues. I came into the chamber tonight having only his naked motion before me. I thought there was something sinister here, but he has persuaded me with his logic and eloquence that this is a very serious matter. —No, push it through.

—It is a pity really that there will not be a vote tonight. I hope he does.
—I gave notice on 4 December 1980. I have been waiting for this thing to be debated. I hope that it will be concluded this evening. I have been trying desperately to get it on.
—I thought the honourable senator indicated by his head movements that he had no wish to have it completed tonight.
—Oh, I do. I want this put to the Senate tonight. I am sorry if you misunderstood me.

—I would like some indication from the Minister for Finance ( Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) or from the Government Whip. —Should we not have parliamentary officers as distinct from Government officers providing this sort of service to private members?

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with other senators who have spoken, I welcome the discussion that has arisen from Senator Lewis's motion. I think in the short debate that has been held some very useful points have been made. Senator Lewis's motion is that all Bills and amendments to Bills brought into the Senate be supported by a financial impact statement that provides estimates of gains or losses of government revenue and the cost and the recurring annual costs to the Government, industry and other sections of the community in implementing the legislation. Senator Lewis has had this notice on the Notice Paper for some time. He has given considerable attention to the matter. I have had discussions with him. I remember that last year we discussed it. I think he, at one time, felt that every Bill that was brought in ought to have a clause in it with the financial implications in the Bill. We then discussed whether the second reading speech of a Minister ought to have this type of information in it. We have now heard tonight what he believes would be the effect of the provision of a financial impact statement in the form that he has suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: A second reading speech, I think, as he said earlier, should provide estimates in the first, second and third years of operation in respect of any costs, revenue and savings to the Government and of financial burdens and savings to industry or other sections of the community. These matters were discussed between us last year on a number of occasions. I believe that as a general principle, disclosure of information concerning government costs, revenue and savings expected to arise from proposed legislation leads to more informed parliamentary debate. Where proposed legislation is expected to have significant effects on the Government, it is already common practice for Ministers to disclose that fact and to provide any estimates that can be reliably made. I think we are all aware that many second reading speeches do have the proposed anticipated costs of a particular provision in the year in which it is introduced and then the full year costs are often given. Equally, if it is a Bill affecting the raising of revenue, similar figures would be provided as reliably as possible at the time of the second reading speech.

I am sure that honourable senators will appreciate, however, that there are good and sufficient reasons for not making public comprehensive financial estimates for a series of years. These reasons were set out in detail in a statement made in another place on 4 March 1980 by the former Minister for Finance, the late Mr Eric Robinson, in response to the report of the House of Representative Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled 'Parliament and Public Expenditure'. That debate and his comments were recorded on page 581 of Hansard for 4 March 1980.

Briefly, the Government's forward estimates are necessarily based on current knowledge and are subject to substantial uncertainties. If the figures are disclosed they could lead to rigidity in expenditure because of the implicit commitments particular interest groups tend to read into such figures no matter how much they are qualified. As a result, the Government's budgetary flexibility could be severely curtailed to the detriment of the responsible conduct of economic policy. In a few cases, there could be objections to disclosing even first year estimates, for example where a measure has sensitive foreign relations implications. In other cases, such as omnibus legislation, first year estimates may be impossible to calculate with any accuracy or only with an unwarranted allocation of scarce departmental resources to the task. Nevertheless, having said those things, I am basically in sympathy with the suggestion that government costs and revenue information be provided wherever appropriate. I do believe that the Senate has made a significant contribution to requiring that information in the Estimates committees which we hold for the Budget Bills and for the Additional Estimates each year. I think the probing by honourable senators on costs and, if applicable, the savings, does lead to a great deal more information being provided over the years by the departments as they seek the approval of the Senate for their estimates and their appropriations.

However, it generally would not be possible to provide information about the financial costs and savings for industry or other sections of the community. Many government measures involve costs to some sections of the community and benefits to others, often of an indirect kind. But the net impact, whether in the aggregate or for particular sections, cannot usually be measured with any precision. I think it is in this area that I would perhaps find more difficulty in being able to provide the sort of information that Senator Lewis is seeking in the motion. Undoubtedly there are costs to industry in the preparation of applications for some of the government programs. There are requirements of government, requirements of the Australian Statistician and those sort of things . I think modern government probably has brought about a fairly active form filling process in industry and community groups.

For me to estimate that sort of information or for the Government to estimate it would lead to a lot of assumptions that may not always provide the accuracy that it may be felt could be usefully extracted when any measure was introduced. To attempt to make such estimates which might be entirely misleading could be a costly and complex process necessarily involving consultation with bodies outside the Government. This, of course, would not absolve the Government from the need, when formulating legislation, to take account of the assessed impact on industry or other sections of the community. I recall that during Question Time in this place just a day or two ago I was asked a question regarding, I think, the collection of tax in one form or another, the administrative costs involved in collecting that tax and whether some attempt was being made to equate the administrative costs with the tax that might be collected. That could be done where an internal matter was involved but for the Government to assume the costs that industry might have in the preparation of its tax return and all that sort of thing would lead to a lot of generalisation and assumption that may not necessarily be entirely accurate.

As I have said, Senator Lewis and I have had discussions about his motion. I have written to him indicating that I will be seeking the views of the Government on a proposal that-with a view to meeting as far as possible the need he has identified-in future the financial impact of proposed legislation be included in a Minister's second reading speech where it is practicable and appropriate to do so, giving estimates that can reliably be calculated in respect of any significant costs, revenue and savings to the Government arising directly from that legislation. I think that what I have just said indicates to Senator Lewis and to the other honourable senators who have expressed interest in Senator Lewis's motion that, as far as practicable, the Government would attempt to meet the requests of the motion in future proposed legislation so that it could give an outline of the sorts of costs involved. As I have said, on many occasions this already occurs.

With those remarks, I just say that I welcome the debate that has been held on this motion. I hope that an active interest in Senator Lewis's motion might lead us all to having better information and more financial guidance on legislation that is proposed by government.

DEBATE.TITLE: PECUNIARY INTERESTS OF FORMER MEMBER AND MINISTER

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate requests that the Prime Minister table the statement of pecuniary interests provided by the former Member for Curtin as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs; in particular, that the Prime Minister make public details of the financial affairs of the former Minister in so far as they relate to the disposal of the companies Stirling West Pty Ltd, Greenbank Pty Ltd and Frederic Salon Pty Ltd, and their association with the companies Hulldale Pty Ltd and Rickford Administration Pty Ltd.

I gave notice of this motion more than a year ago. At the time notice of that motion was given, the honourable member for Curtin was Mr Ransley Victor Garland who at that time was the High Commissioner designate to London. He has since been knighted, an action which I might say tarnished any vestige of gilt-spelt g -i-l-t-that may have been attached to imperial honours. There has been a multitude of pious statements, particularly from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) about the maintenance of ministerial propriety in the Fraser Government. I select only one of dozens that could have been selected for mention. On 12 March 1978 the Prime Minister said in an electoral broadcast:
My Government has demonstrated again and again our fundamental commitment to restoring integrity to public administration in Australia. Our record in this regard is without parallel in our history.

The accuracy of the second sentence could not be justifiably disputed-that is that the record of this Government in the area of ministerial propriety is without parallel in our history. It certainly is. But the first sentence with its reference to a fundamental commitment to restoring integrity to public administration in Australia, as with all areas of the Fraser Government, is a piece of rhetoric which has not been matched by performance. Of course, the most frequent and spectacular breaches of ministerial propriety under this Government have been committed by members of the Country Party or the National Country Party-whatever it calls itself these days. The present Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) on his own admission is still the custodian and beneficiary of misappropriated money--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walsh has imputed impropriety on the part of members of the Country Party.
