SPEECH.PARA: Another major breach of ministerial propriety to which the Prime Minister himself was an accessory-at least after the fact if not before-was committed by Mr Nixon some years ago and exposed at the end of last year; I think on 5 December to be precise. It was then disclosed that Mr Nixon, as Minister for Primary Industry, had made a decision relating to levies due, levies payable by and payments due to the Murray Goulburn Dairy Co-operative in which he was a shareholder. Those actions were defended by the Prime Minister on the grounds that Mr Nixon was a minor shareholder in the company and in any case the decisions that he had made were decisions financially adverse to the company. On the second point the claim was only partially correct. One of the decisions made by Mr Nixon had been financially adverse to the company and another had been favourable.

In any case, the Bowen guidelines, officially stated to have been adopted by the Government, make no allowance for whether a Minister is a minor or a major shareholder in a company. I quote from paragraph 8.7 of the report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest where it says:
(a) when directing the business of the department he administers a Minister should inform the Prime Minister of any real or apparent conflict of interest that arises;

It can scarcely be argued that a Minister making an administrative decision to make payments to a company in which he is a shareholder is not a case involving not just an apparent but real conflict of interest, small or large. The recommendations from the Bowen Committee continue:

(b) the Prime Minister, unless he asks the Minister to divest himself of the interest, should either arrange for another Minister to deal with the matter or else give explicit authorisation to the original Minister to proceed with it; and
(c) in any event, the Prime Minister should have the matter recorded.

The defence used by Mr Nixon and by the Prime Minister to that recommendation and the clear breach of that recommendation, said to have been officially adopted by the Government, was that Mr Nixon was only a minor shareholder which does not account, even in the language of this Government, for the clear statement that a Minister must either divest himself of the interest or arrange for another Minister to deal with the matter. There is an obligation to do that, to inform the Prime Minister and, in any event, for the Prime Minister to have it recorded. As far as any statement which has been made by the Prime Minister or Mr Nixon reveals, none of those things was done. This led to numerous newspaper reports or judgments. I will quote just one of them. It is from the Melbourne Age of 5 December 1981-I think it was a Saturday issue-written by Michelle Grattan. It states:

Mr Fraser argues that Mr Nixon behaved perfectly properly. He maintains the Bowen report only specifies that a Minister 'should' divest shares in a business which deals with his department-not that he 'must'. He goes on to say that Mr Nixon must hold the shares if he is to continue to supply milk to the co- operative.
It continues:

Mr Fraser also says that Mr Nixon has no obligation to tell him he was considering matters affecting Murray Goulburn, because his decisions cost the company money. But the Bowen guidelines make it clear the Prime Minister should be informed, regardless of what decision is likely to be made. And anyway, the decision on the interest allowance, taken by Mr Nixon on the advice of the Australian Dairy Corporation-

I interpolate that that was the third attempt to get the Corporation to recommend that, having been persuaded finally by Mr Al Wallace who was kicked into a supernumerary position in the Department of Primary Industry only last week-
involved a change of rule which did in fact benefit the company.
I could go on quoting from all the responsible newspapers in the country which came to exactly the same conclusions, as indeed anyone who can understand simple English must come.

If the Bowen guidelines were complied with in the Nixon-Murray Goulburn case, as the Prime Minister asserted, the guidelines are meaningless. As a prominent, even prestigious, member of the Liberal Party still serving in this Parliament remarked a few years ago about another matter, to wit, the acquittal of Senator Webster by Sir Garfield Barwick sitting as a Court of Disputed Returns in 1974: 'If Webster was not caught by section 44 (5) nobody can be'. If Nixon was not caught by the Murray Goulburn affair under the Bowen guidelines nobody can be.

The National Country Party, however, does not have a monopoly on impropriety in this Government, a fact attested to by the record of Ransley Victor Garland. I shall not canvass at any length the charges brought against him for breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in 1976 when, on his own admission, he was a party to the transfer of $500 to an independent candidate in the Senate election in the Australian Capital Territory as a pay-off for the allocation of Liberal preferences from that independent candidate-I might add that two crinkly $50 bank notes had been pulled out of Mr Garland's pocket on that occasion on his own admission-and the subsequent peculiar verdict of the Canberra magistrate who said that there was a prima facie case to answer but no jury properly instructed would convict. I am told by people familiar with lawyers' jargon that this is a contradiction in terms.

The particular subject of this motion is the affairs of Ransley Victor Garland as they pertained to the three companies: Stirling West Pty Ltd, Frederic Salon Pty Ltd, and Greenbank Pty Ltd. I shall give the details of one of these companies as revealed by searches of the Corporate Affairs office of Western Australia, which details are replicated almost precisely and certainly in substance in the records of the other two companies. Stirling West was originally incorporated in 1961 with two shareholders, Ransley Victor Garland, usually known as Victor Garland, and his father, I. V. Garland. By 1970 the shareholders in the company were Victor Garland and Surenne Pty Ltd, a Garland- owned company. The directors were Ransley Victor Garland and his wife, L. M. Garland.

On 10 February 1978 the branch register was transferred to Peat Marwick Mitchell and Co. of Cavanagh Street, Darwin. The application to transfer the register was lodged by Rickford Administration Pty Ltd of Melbourne. Three days later, on 13 February 1978, Victor Garland and his wife resigned as directors of the company. They were replaced by Matthew Joseph Sheedy, chartered accountant of 2/11 Auburn Grove, East Hawthorn, Victoria and Ian David Stafford Collie, solicitor of 30 Kintore Street, Camberwell, Victoria. On the same day Victor Garland's wife resigned as secretary of the company and was replaced by Matthew Joseph Sheedy whom I have already mentioned and one R. M. Evans of 28 View Street, Peppermint Grove, who were joint secretaries. A fortnight later, on 27 February 1978, the address of the company, and the company register, was changed to Melsom Wilson and Partners of 37 St Georges Terrace, Perth, the application again being lodged by Rickford Administration of Melbourne.

On 20 March 1978 the share capital previously held entirely by Victor Garland and Surenne Pty Ltd-the Garland company-was divided into 9,950 ordinary shares at $2 each and 50 B class shares at $2 each. On 21 December 1978, some nine months later, R. H. Judson of Ferrier Hodgson Green and Co. of Collins Street, Melbourne was appointed liquidator of the company. On 9 October 1979, 21 months after the original changes of directorship, the liquidator distributed the assets of Hulldale Pty Ltd which by that stage comprised only a $4.55 dividend on 111 shares making a total distribution of $505. The public record reveals no other details of that quite long gap between 20 March 1978 when an extra 10,000 shares were issued in the company and 9 October 1979 when it was finally liquidated. Incidentally, the shareholders and directors of Hulldale Pty Ltd and of Rickford Administration are the Sheedy and Collie noted previously.

It is unfortunate that there is a gap pertaining to the detail in the public record but it is perfectly clear to anybody with any common sense that nobody indulges in a shuffle among two States and one Territory over a period of 18 months for changes of directors and secretary and a major issue of shares for a company which is worth only $500. It is equally apparent to anyone peripherally familiar with the murky, amoral world of tax avoidance that this two State and one Territory shuffle was conducted to dodge taxes. It bears all the marks of a dividend stripping operation, one of the operations which was facilitated by what is known as the Slutzkin scheme.

It is ironic, I suppose, that this motion should finally come up tonight on the same night as the Australian Broadcasting Commission Nationwide program should be giving a detailed account of the tax dodging procedures and some of the individuals exposed and named by the Royal Commission into the activities of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union in Melbourne. It is ironic that the sordid affairs of Ransley Victor Garland should be discussed in the Senate on the same night as Nationwide is talking about the sordid affairs of convicted criminal, tax dodger and former business associate of Sir Phillip Lynch, Mr Durtson. Mr Collie, who along with Mr Sheedy, clearly conducted a business the purpose of which was to provide facilities for white collar crime, has previously complained about being named in respect of this case. I should say that Mr Sheedy has not formally complained as has Mr Collie. In response to Mr Collie's protestations I invited him to supply the details pertaining to these cases which are not available, for whatever reason, on the public record. He declined to respond to that invitation. That reticence, coupled with what is clearly shown about the activities of this man and the companies of which he is director , reveal him to be one of those moral defectives in the legal profession who abdicate all responsibility on the grounds that they are only providing objective legal advice. They remind me of those medical personnel who collaborated with the Nazis in conducting medical experiments in concentration camps.

What of the Prime Minister's role? On 10 September 1980 my colleague, John Dawkins, addressed a question to Mr Garland, who was still a Minister in the House of Representatives, regarding these matters. He asked him as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to make a statement to the House providing the details of the transactions. In reply to his question Mr Garland said with respect to the Bowen guidelines:
. . . the Government announced its policy in relation to that. I am abiding by those guidelines, as is required by the Prime Minister.

One of the things required by those guidelines and endorsed, so Mr Garland says, by the Prime Minister, is that the Prime Minister is to be provided with a declaration of pecuniary interests. The Prime Minister did not disassociate himself from Mr Garland's answer. The Prime Minister's silence must have been taken as consent and agreement. The Prime Minister on his own tacit admission was informed of Mr Garland's business activities, including the circumstances pertaining to and the reason for the details of the disposal of these companies in what was very clearly a dividend stripping operation.

I have no doubt that that question and some other contemporaneous events were responsible for Mr Garland's decision a couple of months later to retire prematurely from politics. I have little doubt that he was probably assisted in making that decision by Prime Ministerial pressure, not because he had done something which was reprehensible but because of the usual reason-he had been found out. That is the usual reason for this Prime Minister taking any action on ministerial impropriety. I guess one would have to be fairly naive to believe that prior to Mr Garland's premature retirement from politics the question of his subsequent appointment as High Commissioner to London was not discussed between the Prime Minister and himself.

It was an appointment which led to criticism, subsequently publicised, by Lord Carrrington, the British Foreign Secretary, by the Australian Public Service Association and, of course, a good deal of other criticism. It was, according to reports published in British newspapers, among other things, an embarrassment to the Queen and, I might add, a disgrace to Australia. With respect to those London newspapers I cite just one reference from the Daily Express of 4 January this year. The William Hickey column, which is arguably the most widely read column in any newspaper in the United Kingdom, discussed the Queen's reaction to Mr Garland's appointment and indeed his subsequent knighthood. The article states:
She has little discretion in such matters, being pretty much obliged to accept Fraser's advice on honours, whatever private doubts she may harbour.

Nothing that can be done now can erase the damage done to Australia's reputation and prestige abroad by this appointment. Nothing that can be done now can cancel the doubts and clean up the sullied reputation of the Fraser Government with respect to ministerial propriety. But at the very least the Senate is entitled to a formal statement from the Prime Minister as to his knowledge of this matter ; and it is entitled to the details pertaining to the disposal of these companies since the Prime Minister, by his own tacit acknowledgement, his consent by silence, has those details. Either he has those details or he was an accessory to the misleading of Parliament by Mr Garland on 10 September. Of course we all know that the Prime Minister would not be a party to anything like that, so clearly he has the details.

The Senate ought to assert its moral right. I understand it has no power to compel the Prime Minister to disgorge the sordid history of the second and third Fraser Governments in this way but it should insist on its moral right to be provided with the information on this matter which is of central relevance to the question of ministerial propriety.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh has moved a motion that requests the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to table statements of pecuniary interests of a former member and Minister of this place and to give details of financial affairs and certain business transactions. Senator Walsh, in the course of his speech, made a series of completely uncorroborated and unsubstantiated allegations. Mr Deputy President, the procedures-and they are well known-are that under this Government each Minister is required by the Prime Minister to make a statement of his pecuniary interests. It has never been suggested that that statement would be a public document at all, nor is it intended that it should be a public document at all.
—For very good reasons.

—That is so. The fact is that the Bowen Committee laid down certain procedures regarding Ministers and their pecuniary interests. Ministers observe those interests, as they have done over the years on this side of politics whereby in Cabinet if a matter concerns their interests they indicate to the Cabinet that that is so. In fact that is an impeccable procedure which has been observed over the decades and will continue to be observed. It is not the intention of the Government to make public property of pecuniary interests. The facts are that those details are entitled to be preserved in their ordinary privacy as are those of any citizen at all. Senator Walsh, during the course of his statements, made a number of allegations. First he referred to Mr Sinclair. Mr Sinclair was indicted before the courts by a Labor Government in New South Wales. He went before his peers on charges and was totally acquitted. The fact is that this Parliament exists on one very important principle that honourable senators need to be reminded of, and that is that if indeed a court of law acquits a person it behoves those who uphold the rule of law to accept that verdict and to honour it and not to try to denigrate it at all.
—Are you denying that he has still got the stolen money?

—I can quite understand these interjections. They are aimed to distract; they will not. I want to make it perfectly clear that those who seek, as Senator Walsh does, to take a verdict of a court-that is a very important principle of law on which we live-and then seek to pervert it or to deny it are doing a great injustice not only to the individual but also to the principles of law. It could not be a sadder thing that a man finds that one of his family, unbeknown to him, has in fact committed breaches of the law. It could not be a sadder thing. It so happens that day by day in various parts of this country members of parliament find that. I invite Senator Walsh to read the Press and see some very sad circumstances in recent times. I do not intend to name them. I should have thought that the ordinary human decency of a person would be to understand that because somebody else in a family has committed a breach of the law one does not seek to reflect upon that.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, as I understand it, that Mr Sinclair has undertaken to make restitution of that money and has proceeded so to do. I cannot understand how anyone in this place can continue to cast aspersions given, firstly, the tragic circumstances of the family situation-I would have thought one would have deep sympathy for a person in that regard-and, secondly, the fact that a jury has reached the conclusion it has because it is ordinary human decency to uphold the jury's verdict and say: 'Here is a man who has been acquitted of these charges', particularly as he has taken it upon himself to rectify what was a breach of the law not of his own but by some other person. I hope we will never again in this place have cause to hear that.

Senator Walsh then proceeded to discuss Mr Nixon. Mr Nixon is a farmer in the course of his ordinary business. I understand that for most people it is a respectable occupation to be a farmer. For some I have some doubts. Mr Nixon, being a farmer and producing products, operates within a law in which we allow co-operatives and in which membership of a co-operative involved in the purchase and distribution of primary products means that members must hold nominal shareholdings-not massive shareholdings for dividend earning purposes but shareholdings to belong to the co-operative and so to operate. TALK.START.PARA: —I will do it tomorrow. I will accept that invitation tomorrow.

—I will make another invitation available in a moment which I hope I will hear Senator Walsh say he will accept tomorrow. A reference was made to a former member of this place, Senator Webster. SPEECH.PARA: During his remarks, Senator Walsh referred to a number of people, including a Mr Collie and a Mr Sheedy. I do not know either of these gentlemen. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister is inviting me to seek a writ. Truth is not necessarily a defence against defamation, as he well knows.

—Mr President, I take it that that is no point of order but a speech of rhetoric. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that financial grants by the Commonwealth Government or its statutory authorities should not be provided, either directly or indirectly, to those organisations in public health areas the officials of which advocate that abortion is an acceptable or desirable form of 'fertility control'.

First of all, I point out that this motion has not been suddenly dropped on the Senate. Every honourable senator, even those relatively new honourable senators, should know that this motion has not been dropped upon him or her without warning or notice. I first raised this matter in the Parliament during the sittings of the last Parliament. I placed a notice of motion in identical terms to this notice of motion before the Senate on 21 February 1978. That notice of motion eventually surfaced on 24 August 1978. I explained then what I was trying to achieve. I refer honourable senators to the Senate Hansard of 24 August 1978, page 425 and following. Debate on my motion was adjourned and it subsequently disappeared from the Notice Paper when Parliament was prorogued prior to the 1980 election.

Immediately after the resumption of the new Parliament, I placed an identical notice of motion on the Notice Paper. That was on 5 December 1980. Now, 15 months later, it has come up for debate. So, let there be no misunderstanding about the fact that this matter has not been dropped on the Senate. It is a matter about which there has been adequate and substantial notice. In effect, there has been four years gestation period for this motion. Honourable senators who have been here for some years and even those who came here in 1980 have had ample time to consider the implications.

The motion is in reality an expression of principle to let everyone know where the Australian Parliament stands and where the Australian Government should stand. It is, in effect, similar to a United States congressional resolution which prohibits United States AID funds being used for abortion. The motion refers to financial grants. What are those financial grants? If adopted, the motion would apply to grants given to family planning organisations in Australia and to grants given to international organisations working in that same field.

Let us take a look at the national grants for a moment. Details which were supplied to Estimates committees by the Department of Health show that these grants would cover the $780,000 of grants for the 1981-82 year under the family planning program of the Commonwealth Department of Health and also the related health program grants. I refer to pages 45 and 46 of the Estimates of the Department of Health. So far as the international grants are concerned, these would cover the $300,000 granted to the International Planned Parenthood Federation in 1981-82 and other similar grants which show up in overseas aid projects-for example, the international population and family planning project in Bangladesh. I refer to pages 67 to 69 of the Estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs.

Are family planning organisations advocating the idea that abortion is an acceptable or even a desirable means of fertility control? As stated in my speech on 24 August 1978, to which I referred previously in this discussion, some key people associated with the family planning organisations in Australia have stated that abortion is an acceptable form of fertility control. This might come as a surprise to some honourable senators who did not hear it at that time. If one has a think about that statement, one will see that it really shows that they are admitting some failure. When they say this they are giving equality of treatment to abortion. They are treating it in somewhat the same category as the pill.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is not the policy of the Family Planning Association, is it?
—Officials are on record as saying that. They have been somewhat quieter since this motion was put forward.
—Which officials? Could you just indicate the officials?
—I refer the honourable senator to my speech.
—I have read it. Are those the people you are talking about- Professor Charles Kerr and Judy McLean?

—Yes. I remind the Senate of what was, in fact, said at that time by Professor Charles Kerr who was asked about this matter in a television interview on Tuesday, 7 February 1978. The interviewer asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What's your attitude to abortion?
Professor Charles Kerr responded:

Abortion is accepted. It's legally accepted as a means of fertility control; just one option available to women in this state and its fitted into the health system and the medical system. And the Association-if there comes a person who may require an abortion it would proceed in the normal channels, just like doctors doing work anywhere else.

I refer to the statement of the then Director of the New South Wales Family Planning Association, Judy McLean. She was interviewed on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's Broadband program in March 1977. At that time she stated:

. . . the information we are gathering now on abortion seems to be pointing that this is a very safe method of birth control. If it was done for instance like Family Planning Clinics that are dotted right throughout the metropolitan area the cost of it would go down and it would be a feasible method of birth control. . . .

Admittedly, since I gave notice of my motion such statements have not appeared broadly. But, as I will point out, the evidence points to the fact that in certain areas this particular philosophy or approach is adopted. If persons in the family planning area adopt this approach, they are also proving that they have failed one of their stated functions that is, the prevention of conception. Abortion is not the prevention of conception. It is the destruction of the unborn child which has been produced as the result of conception. Abortion is not contraception-how could it be?-unless, of course, we are not talking the same language.

Let me deal with the question whether abortion is a form of fertility control. Is there evidence that abortion is growing in its acceptance as a form of fertility regulation? In other words, is the ready availability of abortion being used as a convenient form of family planning? There are very few figures available on rates of abortion and related aspects. Unfortunately, so far as the FPA is concerned, South Australia is one State which does keep reliable figures. To my knowledge, leading figures in the FPA in two other States and in the Australian Capital Territory have a worse record on this issue. The South Australian figures for 1980 were released in November 1981. In the Adelaide Advertiser on 18 November 1981, it was reported that 342 women who had had abortions in 1980 had had previous abortions under South Australian legislation. That represented 8.4 per cent of the total performed. But almost a quarter of these women were under the age of 20 years.
The committee which produced these figures reported:

The Committee had discussed this in depth and considers the education of young people in responsible parenthood is still inadequate in SA . . . The Committee also believes the lack of motivation to avoid pregnancy in high-risk situations is a problem which can only be dealt with by greater awareness of the problem and by public discussion.

Obviously throughout Australia, despite the hundreds of thousands of dollars poured into the Family Planning Association bodies, they are not having the effect that they desire. Therefore, it makes me wonder whether abortion is viewed by some of these people in the Association still, though they do not say it publicly, as a convenient way out for their failure.

Let me take the other area where there are detailed figures, that is, the Northern Territory. Those figures are kept by the Northern Territory health administration and published in a quarterly statistical bulletin. The Northern Territory law was changed in late 1973 or 1974. The percentage of repeat abortions in the Northern Territory has been: In 1975, 4.1 per cent; 1976, 7.6 per cent; 1977, 10.1 per cent; 1978, 11.9 per cent; 1979, 13.8 per cent; and 1980, 15.8 per cent. It is undeniable that a significant and increasing proportion of women are being influenced to the view that abortion is available to be used as a convenient means of limiting the number of children they have. In my view, that is a contradiction in terms when it comes to the question of family planning associations. That is why it is important for this Senate to declare at the earliest possible moment that it will not be party to the provision of funds which might be used to promote such an attitude.

The major organisations active in this area, are, of course, the family planning organisations and, as I have indicated, there are some people in prominent positions in those associations who are already on public record that they see nothing wrong with the attitude of using abortion as a means of fertility control. That is an extraordinary statement to come from those people, having regard to the objectives of the associations. As I mentioned in my previous speech, there are some associations which do not take that attitude but there are others whose officials do. This is shown up in statistics.

Let me now turn to the international grants. I hope that this matter comes to determination this evening. As I mentioned earlier, the Australian Government will contribute some $300,000 to the International Planned Parenthood Federation this financial year. That is a 20 per cent increase on the previous year's grant . I have correspondence from Ministers for Foreign Affairs about the IPPF. I have not been satisfied with the denials in that correspondence that IPPF is involved in the promotion of abortion. I have an IPPF working paper which advocates:
Those FPAs that consider it necessary to fight for abortion law reform should have support from the regional and central organs of IPPF.
An article by Donald Warwick in the Hastings Centre Report of April 1980 claimed that IPPF:
. . . has been the most outspoken advocate of legal abortion services in the developing countries.

It provides 200 kits in the Phillipines and 5,000 abortion kits to Bangladesh as well as similar kits to Korea, Singapore, Hong Kong, Thailand and India. Donald Warwick is an institute fellow at the Harvard Institute for International Development. This is the very body which the taxpayers of Australia are funding to the tune of over a quarter of a million dollars each year-$300,000. Of course that, in the overall, is not an enormous amount. But it is the principle that is at issue. It is a principle which the people of Australia would go to the barricades on. They certainly would not have a bar of it if they knew that the Australian Government funds an organisation with this sort of objective.

The IPPF has also been accused of involving itself in the internal affairs of developing countries. It has been accused of being involved in the sacking of the Health Minister in Zimbabwe last October. I have a copy of an article from the New Zealand Tablet newspaper of 6 January 1982. It reports that the Health Minister, Dr Herbert Ushewokunze, had been sacked from his position because of his opposition to abortion on demand and an attack on the local family planning association for its use of the drug depo-provera as a contraceptive. The Minister for Health had, in fact, expressed his opposition to abortion on demand . He had, in fact, raised the question as to the appropriateness of the local family planning association using the drug depo-provera as a contraceptive. I have previously raised questions about depo-provera and its dangers. I know that Senator Haines has also asked questions about its use. The Tablet report states that because of his attack on the local family planning association, the Health Minister in Zimbabwe attracted the opposition of the international agencies including IPPF 'who saw in him a threat to their plans for the development of contraceptive and abortion facilities in the region'. The doctor was in overall command of the Zimbabwe African National Union medical teams during the bush war and joined ZANU in 1963. His revolutionary credentials were unchallenged, I imagine, in the eyes of the Government. But here was an international organisation on the bandwagon able to ensure that he was got rid of. This man, in fact, trained for the medical profession also in Durban and Natal.

It is a temptation for family planning agencies to become involved in the abortion industry because that is the soft option. But to accept abortion as having a legitimate role to play in the family planning area is, as I have said before, to admit defeat. I know that the family planning associations are very quick to point out statistics which they say claim that they have reduced the number of pregnancies, particularly teenage pregnancies. But having regard to what I said a moment ago about the statistics in South Australia and the statistics in the Northern Territory, if comprehensive figures were available, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, the main problem areas, and in the Australian Capital Territory, I think they would show the same trend and we would find that this had occurred through the greater employment of abortion. That is something that this Senate and, indeed, the whole of the Parliament should be concerned about. Not only does that deny the very objectives of the family planning associations and the purpose for which the grants are being given, but it also creates a mentality which is surely foreign to those of us- that is all of us-who believe in the principles of the right to life and the right for a person to develop with freedom and dignity and to ensure that person 's rights are maintained.

I do not believe for a moment that Commonwealth funds should be used to prop up those family planning associations which are simply acting as conveyor belts for the abortion industry in Australia or elsewhere, and I mean elsewhere. If time permitted tonight I would be able to provide the Senate with details of the situation that exists in Bangladesh. That information would raise some very important questions as to whether this Government should have a very good and clear look as to where its funds are ending up in Bangladesh. Recently I had the opportunity overseas of having discussions about this issue. I have a number of details which I would like to provide to the Senate, but obviously time is against me tonight. Suffice it to say that I consider that once that sort of information hits the deck then I believe the whole question of the provision of funds should require greater scrutiny. I believe that the people of Australia, once they are aware of the facts of the situation, would, in fact, demand greater scrutiny of expenditure of their funds in these areas.

It irritates me no end that these agencies, both the internal agencies and the external agencies, receive substantial funding from both Commonwealth and State governments. Yet, the natural family planning associations are, in general, given the brush-off. I wish that the Minister would do me the courtesy of listening to me and understanding what I am saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have advisers here. I turned to them for advice. What you have said is really unreasonable.

—I apologise. I hope those advisers will advise the Minister why they cannot tell him why more money is not available for those organisations which, both within Australia and on the international sphere, are engaged in the dissemination of information relating to the natural family planning methods. I know for a fact, for example, that Doctor John Billings, an Australian doctor who is probably the world expert on the OM method, has put submission after submission to the Government. In my opinion these submissions have not received the treatment and respect that they deserve and which he is, in fact, accorded throughout the world.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Amendments to Northern Territory Evidence Act-Design of Senate Chamber: New Parliament House

PROCTEXT.PARA: Amendments to Northern Territory Evidence Act-Design of Senate Chamber: New Parliament House

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I became aware this afternoon, as many other Australians did later this afternoon as a result of the PM radio program, of some legislation which was introduced yesterday into the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and which is intended to be rushed into law by that Assembly next Tuesday. That legislation has caused me, and I suspect a great many other Australians, profound concern. I believe that it should cause equally profound concern to this Government and more particularly to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), with whom I have already discussed this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation in question amounts to amendments to the Northern Territory Evidence Act designed to allow the suppression by the Northern Territory Government of certain documentary evidence in legal proceedings-namely, documents which the Northern Territory Attorney-General certifies not to be in the public interest to disclose. The description of those documents makes clear that what is intended are documents involving proceedings of, or communications to or from, the Northern Territory Cabinet or Executive Council. It is clear that these amendments are designed to overturn the effects of two very important High Court of Australia cases and also to overturn the application in the Northern Territory of some very important Commonwealth legislation.

In the first place, it is obvious-indeed, Mr Paul Everingham, the Northern Territory Government leader, said as much on radio tonight-that the initial intention of the legislation is to overcome the effect of the Sankey case, which enables a court to overturn a claim of Crown privilege in relation to Crown documents, including Cabinet or Executive Council documents, when that court perceives it to be in the public interest to do so. I note in this respect that when the New South Wales Government enacted a similar amendment to its evidence Act in 1979 that attracted-quite rightly in my opinion-a storm of criticism. I believe that kind of principled criticism is equally applicable to the actions now being contemplated by the Northern Territory Government.

It is also clear that the legislation in question is designed to overcome, among other things, the effect of section 54 of the Aboriginal Land Rights ( Northern Territory) Act, which vests power in the Aboriginal Land Commissioner to require the production of documents relevant to the determination of land claims. Therein lies a very serious matter indeed. The Aboriginal Land Commisioner, Mr Justice Toohey, is presently engaged in, or about to be engaged in the hearing and determination of what is known as the Kenbi land claim relating to the Cox Peninsula adjacent to the city of Darwin. In hearing that claim he has a very great interest indeed in getting access to certain government documents, more particularly certain Cabinet-Executive Council documents.

The land claim to which I refer is the contest with respect to which there occurred, I believe, one of the most notorious exercises of government cynicism in the history of this country. I am referring to the gazettal in 1978 of the whole land area of the Cox Peninsula geographically adjacent to Darwin as being alienated for Darwin town planning purposes. When one considers the nature, the character, the location and the size of the land in question-in fact, three times that of Greater London-it is evident to any observer of the situation what a wildly implausible claim that was, that what was in issue here was the gazettal of land to extend Darwin boundaries for town planning purposes. It was manifestly a cynical exercise to alienate the land in question to take it out of the domain of the Aboriginal land claim to the Cox Peninsula being mounted by the Kenbi people.

As a result of that gazettal of the land in question Mr Justice Toohey, when initially hearing the Kenbi land claim, found himself obliged to regard the land in question as having been technically alienated and, therefore, as not being able to be any longer the subject of a land claim proceeding. He declared the proceedings terminated. That decision by Mr Justice Toohey was then taken to the High Court of Australia by the Northern Land Council and in a decision brought down just before last Christmas, on 24 December-one of the more celebrated decisions of the High Court-the High Court decided that the Commissioner could not--

TALK.START.PARA: —Without disagreement, I believe.

—Without disagreement, indeed, as to the basic determination. The High Court decided that the Commissioner was not entitled simply to terminate the proceedings in that way. Notwithstanding the apparent successful alienation of the land in question by gazetting it under the town planning regulations, the High Court said that the Land Commissioner was obliged to go on hearing and considering the merits of the Aboriginal land claim and in particular he was obliged to turn his mind to the legality, the legitimacy of the particular town planning exercises; the regulation promulgation in question. More particularly- herein lies the enormous potential significance of the Toohey case in many other areas of public law-the High Court also said for the first time that it was permissible for someone in the position of Mr Justice Toohey, or any other court determining the legality of legislation or regulations promulgated in this way, to look behind the face value of such legislation or regulations and to determine whether, in fact, that legislation was validly passed by reference to the purposes for which it is possible to pass legislation, as specified in this case by the parent Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words the bona fides of the Northern Territory Government in gazetting this area could be taken into account. In fact, since the issue had been raised the Land Commissioner was obliged to look to the question of those bona fides. To the extent that that involved the compulsory production of Government, Cabinet and Executive Council documents he was obliged to take that course of action. There are varying degrees of precision with which the judges make these various points. I will not go into the technical detail. Suffice to say that the effect of the decision is perfectly clear and it was on that basis that Mr Justice Toohey was about to begin again hearing and determining the Kenbi land claim. It is obvious to me, as it is obvious to many in the Northern Territory and as I hope it is obvious to the Attorney-General-who I am indebted to see visiting the chamber-and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that we are seeing here a deliberate attempt by the Northern Territory Government, although it is clear that Mr Everingham will not admit it in so many words, to flout the High Court decisions I have referred to, to tear up the relevant provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and to make it impossible for this extremely important land rights claim to be heard and determined on its merits.

I do not know whether this new Northern Territory legislation, if it comes into force next week, is capable of legal challenge. It might be, although it seems to me to be the case in the short time I have had to look at it that it is possible for a Territory law, passed as it is in the exercise of legislative power delegated to the Territory by the Commonwealth under section 122 of the Constitution, to override the effect of another Commonwealth law provided that the Territory law is later in time. It might seem odd that a territory law like this, not much more in its terms that what we have hitherto thought of as an ordinance, although now described as an Act under the self-government situation now applying, could override an earlier passed Commonwealth law. But I suspect as a matter of strict legal interpretation it probably can, there being no provision in the Constitution to ensure that valid inconsistent Commonwealth legislation overrides the Territory provision with which it is inconsistent. This is unlike, of course, the situation in State law; section 109 of the Constitution does enable inconsistent validly passed Commonwealth law to override a State law in question. While I am not clear about that-I express some hesitation-I do believe that probably this Northern Territory law, at least at first sight, is valid. But what I am clear about and I believe the Attorney- General to be equally clear about is that that law, if it is passed, is equally capable of being overriden by another Commonwealth law if this Parliament chooses to pass an overriding law to knock out, to neutralise, to defeat the purpose, the intention and the effect of this Northern Territory evidence provision.

I believe that it is perfectly competent for this Commonwealth Parliament using its constitutional power-at least section 122 of the Constitution and perhaps also that under the racial powers of section 51 (xxvi.)-to override the Territory law in this way. The mere existence of a situation of self-government in the Northern Territory does not, in my view, alter that. The Territory self- government arrangements are themselves a creature of legislation passed by this Commonwealth Parliament. They can be removed-either wholly or partially-as easily as the powers in question were granted. I believe that in this situation this Government, through its Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Senator Baume, and no doubt the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, acting in consort and, no doubt, in consultation with the Cabinet, should issue an ultimatum to Mr Everingham immediately informing him that if his Government proceeds with the passage of this intolerable law, it is this Government's intention-the Commonwealth Parliament's intention-to pass the necessary remedial legislation immediately to override, to wipe out the effect of that Northern Territory law. I have no doubt that in taking that course of action and ultimately, if it proves necessary, actually introducing into this Parliament and passing such a provision, the Government would have the complete support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to what Senator Evans has said tonight, I will respond on behalf of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). One of the nice things about attending dinners arranged by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, with people like you, Mr Deputy President, and many others, is that one can sit down with Senator Evans and the Attorney over dinner and discuss matters in a more informal way. By the way, I must make one apology to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Attorney-General aware that all future applicants for the Queensland Public Service will be screened by police and that such screening will be directed more towards character rather than records or criminal or other convictions; if so, what would be the Attorney-General's attitude to possible approaches by the Queensland Police Force to either the Commonwealth Police and/ or the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation seeking such personal information?
(2) If the Attorney-General agrees that such information should not be passed on, what assurances can he give that this will not happen?
(3) Does the Commonwealth Public Service seek similar reports on character when considering a person for employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The only information I have concerning this matter is that set out in the question. Those parts of the question that seek my attitude on the matter are hypothetical and I do not propose to respond to them. However, I should point out that the effect of the ASIO Act 1979 is that:
(a) ASIO may only supply security assessments for a State Government for use in dealing with applications for employment where the employment would affect security in a Commonwealth matter;
(b) such assessments may not be passed by ASIO directly to the State Government but may only be passed through a Commonwealth agency; and
(c) the Commonwealth agency is subject to the requirement of the Act that in normal circumstances an adverse or qualified assessment shall be notified to the subject of the assessment; and
(d) that person has a right to apply to the Security Appeals Tribunal to review any such assessment.

(3) In accordance with established procedures, enquiries made of the police by the Commonwealth in respect of a prospective employee are limited to obtaining details of criminal convictions and such enquiries are made only with the consent of the prospective employee. The Australian Security Intelligence Organization is not requested to provide security assessments except where the person, if employed, would have access to information or places access to which is controlled or limited on security grounds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Mr R. K. Todd and Mr M. J. Cusack of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in decision No. V80/14 (Harris and Director-General of Social Security) state 'the ''rolling fortnight'' method of approach may be a very useful administrative scheme for the purpose of the payment of pensions on a fortnightly basis, but at the conclusion of the pension year, when the facts are known, an adjustment must be made to equate pension entitlement and pension received. The Department has a continuing and difficult administrative problem in the payment of pensions, but the problems of estimation that therein arise should not in our opinion be allowed to dictate the measurement of rights and obligations once estimation is overtaken by knowledge.'
(2) What action has been taken by the Minister or his department to implement this interpretation of the law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The practice of the Department of Social Security, in calculating amounts of pension entitlement on a retrospective basis, is to have regard wherever possible to actual income. To this extent, there is no difference between departmental practice and the interpretation of the law adopted by Messrs Todd and Cusack of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in Re Harris and Director- General of Social Services.

However, acting upon the advice of the Crown Solicitor for the Commonwealth and counsel, the Director-General of Social Services has instituted an appeal to the Federal Court of Australia against the decision of the Tribunal in Re Harris on the grounds (inter alia) that the Tribunal erred in law in holding that the basis for calculation of pension entitlement under the Social Services Act 1947 should be a year commencing on the date of the first grant of pension and thereafter on the anniversary thereof. No steps have thus been taken by the Department of Social Security to implement those aspects of the Tribunal's decision which are the subject of those appeal proceedings, pending a final decision of the Federal Court of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the diminishing reserves of water in the artesian basin in south-west Queensland posing a threat to future water supplies in this region.
(2) What research or investigation has been carried out into an accurate measurement of these water reserves.
(3) Are there any plans to develop alternative water storage methods.
(4) Will a subsidy be considered for the installation of polythene or other types of storage facilities in the event of a serious water shortage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Queensland Water Resources Commission has advised that there is no threat to future water supplies in the Great Artesian Basin. It is well known that prior to the aquifers being tapped, they had become distended under the pressure of water. The drilling of bores has enabled the release of water from these distended aquifers. As aquifers have contracted, flows and pressures in bores have diminished, and will continue to do so until a balance is reached between natural replenishment and use, plus natural losses.

It has been estimated that the state of balance will be reached when the total output from all bores has diminished to 590 megalitres per day. This will be adequate to satisfy the needs of the pastoral industry.
Present output is 815 megalitres per day and, at the current rate of diminution , it will be at least 35 to 40 years before a state of equilibrium between use and replenishment is reached.
Some bores now flowing naturally may cease to do so but adequate water will still be available by pumping.

(2) An extensive investigation into the Queensland portion of the Great Artiesian Basin was carried out by a Committee appointed by the Queensland Government. Its report, 'Artesian Water Supplies in Queensland' was completed in 1954. Findings of this report have subsequently been updated and confirmed by the Queensland Water Resources Commission.

Flows and pressures throughout the Basin have been continuously measured and investigated. The Bureau of Mineral Resources has also carried out extensive investigations including the development of a computer model of the Basin.
(3) and (4) As there is no threat to supplies from the Basin, the question of alternative storages and subsidies for such storages does not arise.
